content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												I don't recall the last time I've ever had so much fun on an SP only game. I want to start this review off by saying that the developers released a patch for the game to use DirectX11 and better support for 64-bit systems, about two years after it's release. These guys deserve your money.Now, like many fans of the old Shadow Warrior, I was a little worried because I heard about all the changes from the gameplay to Wang's character himself, but the game still does have some "old-school" elements. While the levels are much more linear than the original, exploring and going off trail is still worth it as there are many secrets to be found and the gameplay is still very fast, intense and immersive. You can still find hentai chicks bathing themselves and singing, and even find secrets taking you back to levels from the old-school Shadow Warrior.You're gonna use that katana a LOT. It's just so damn fun to use! Throughout the game, you'll be upgrading your katana and learning new attacks for it which will keep the sword feeling fresh. If you want to try out something new, in the pause menu you can change what kind of Katana you can use, including some laser/lightsaber thing and even the Excalibat from Rise of the Triad!The guns are a lot of fun to use as well and you'll be upgrading those too. It has some of the same weapons from the original, such as the demon heart, demon head, rocket launcher (which freakin' kicks‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•in this game), Uzi's (and dual wielding of course), a tearing‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•shotgun (which gets a 4-shot chamber just like the original) as well as some added ones like a sexy and powerful Revolver, a big crossbow that can be upgraded to detonate explosions at will, and more.Aside from weapons, you can also upgrade Wang himself and gain some other special powers that you will find out for yourself.And obviously, there's Lo Wang. Duke Nukem's bother from another mother. I don't think this was intended, but I like to think of this as Lo Wang when he was younger and how he became so wise and powerful. The way he shaves his head and gets tattoos later on in the game makes him look like the classic Wang we know, so that was pretty sweet too.Lo Wang is still an‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•(he even claims to be in the game) and he's still full of awesome one-liners that you'll want to remember and use on people later on in real life because it's cliche. His voice acting is just great, from the cutscenes, to his trash-talking enemies, to his occasional scream from swinging the Katana so hard, to his screams and cursing when taking damage. It makes you feel like you're Wang almost. Oh yeah, the cutscenes. I'm never a fan of cutscenes, or even stories in video games in general, but I did not skip a single cutscene in this game. The story is solid and will suck you in! (the cutscenes are skippable if you don't want to watch them.) Lastly, the graphics in this game may be the best I've seen yet. The normals, bumpmaps and lighting in this game is insane, very impressed on how it keeps the framerate so fluid especially with hordes of enemies attacking you in these overwhelmingly beautiful worlds.There's so much I want to say, but so much that I don't want to spoil for you. You must try this game for yourself. If it means waiting for a sale, fine - but this game is worth more than it's usual $9.99 when it's 75% off (which is usually the discount it has). So if you want a modernized throwback of one of your favorite old-school games, grab this, you won't be disappointed. If you want a throwback to an old-school game that still keeps the old-school non-linear fast gameplay but with modern and pretty graphics, then grab Rise of the Triad. Wang is there too!

number of helpful: 17 of 19 people (89%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												More of a sequel to Hard Reset than Shadow Warrior, and it's all good.People who played Hard Reset might remember that the basic abilities you started with were stale, but by the end of the game you'd have expanded your arsenal to a wide variety of unique weaponry. Shadow Warrior wisely starts Lo Wang out with just about everything the player needs to have fun from the word GO and brings back the odd blend of monster kiting so that you can blow up environmental hazards, like cars, explosive barrels or electrified objects, to create a cascade of explosions and bloody chunks.Lo Wang is a big idiot, but that's what makes him fun. The dialogue is surprisingly casual and made me laugh plenty of times in the midst of the demonic invasion. The voice acting is great and his cluelessness and comic book fantasies are both endearing and hilarious. The end of the story took a tonal one-eighty that was too heavy handed after the casually kitchy tone, but it sure beat the utter cliffhanger that Hard Reset ended on and resolved the story of the vengeful spirit and constant companion, Hoji, and Lo Wang.Probably my favorite bits of dialogue were the set of whiny, pained lines tied to taking too much damage... A constant reminder that Lo Wang is still comedically human despite becoming his own original character.The game still has some similar UI pitfalls retained from Hard Reset by allowing the player to craft their game into a boring one... A quick recap on Hard Reset: You started out with practically nothing, and you were presented with an upgrade tree that could route the player into using very boring weaponry for a very long time if they didn't experiment with unlocking alternate-fire-modes that vastly changed the behavior of the weapons.There's an unintuitive paradox between picking what I think are important passives, and the immediate reward of unlocking the ability to use all the Sword Arts and Ki Powers. For example, FIND MORE MONEY is critical to feeding into your ability to unlock more fun weapon upgrades... Especially their ALTERNATE FIRE, which is tantamount to unlocking a new basic ability... Otherwise, you're left with a passively powered-up toolset that would probably get stale.All in all though, it's a fun game that has some odd quirks (Lo Wang can't swim, some checkpoints are poorly placed later in the game, and dashing off of a ledge can apply deadly fall damage).I spent my time dashing around hordes of demons to corral them up into the largest groups, jump in the middle and then cut them all down in the midst of an explosive firestorm.

content:
Posted: August 19, 2014
Summary Shadow Warrior is a action packed single player that offers the best katana gameplay I experienced. Wang is the protagonist, a bodyguard of Zilla Enterprises, looking to collect parts of a sword and assemble it to create a very powerful weapon. Unravel the mystery of the demons who are invading the human world. The sirens who protect the sword from the demons, and the guardians who protect the sword pieces from being gathered.HumorThe companion that follows you around is actually pretty amusing and the dynamic between him and Wang work well. Constantly making jabs at you throughout the game really adds humor that actually works with the game rather than against since it doesn‚Äôt feel out of place. An example of this is on chapter 12, you teleport into a new area, nearly fell off the mountain and lived by grasping onto a broken bridge. Wang: You suck!Wang: Do you enjoy dropping me like that?Companion: Just trying to land you in the air, it beats materializing a couple of feet undergroundWang: Your logic is soundWeaponsThe katana and powers are far more effective against enemies than guns except in some instances where having distance between you and a mini-boss is beneficial. Guns are mostly used for bosses even though they could be used for interesting combos to get a higher score during fights for more karma and better position in the leaderboard. I highly recommend using the crossbow, rocket launcher, and shotgun throughout the game.MovementBe constantly on the move or you are going to take quite a bit of damage. The game has enough enemy variations and threats to make you constantly have to be on the move to avoid being hit.The jumping in this game is pretty average which in case you're wondering means its bad. The dashing is far superior in this game which you will always use in combat since its far more effective for getting away from enemy attacks. The jumping I found was only useful when i used explosives near me to blow up groups of enemies i threw down when using the tiger skill. Overall movement in this game is a big step up from the previous game this engine was used for Hard Reset.Level DesignThe level design itself is not as complex as others would like however there are many areas to explore which rewards you with money. There are also secrets that have a retro graphic theme style to it which pays tribute to the game the remake is based on. The only issue I have with the level design itself is that certain maps have elements which can be incredibly annoying like the platforming level where you can fall if you are not precise about where you jump.EnemiesThe variety of enemies mixes up the gameplay and allows the player to come up with interesting ways to deal with multiple enemies at once or certain types that would otherwise kill you. What makes the enemies really stick out is their ability to rage. Their rage ability makes them go much faster and hit for more which means you need to either take them out fast or calm them down before they strike you down.  People tend to use the Divider of Heaven for most enemies seeing as how you can kill enemies in a row with its  piercing effects while being in constant movement. BossesThe bosses are towering impressive looking monsters of death with nice animations and environments that you fight them in. Ultimately the bosses feel boring as a result of their ability to regenerate armor back on the weakness spots exposed. It really becomes a chore to constantly take down the armor off bosses just to hit the crystal which has a iffy hitbox. DifficultyHeroic mode offered a great challenge of having to clear a whole level without dying once, or you would be reset to the start of that level. It was quite hard at times considering that the staircases could kill you if you dashed down them too fast. The chapter 12 was particularly bad since there were many gimmicks like limiting your vision and spamming tons of suicidal monsters to attempt to kill you while you were limited in movement since you were stuck on a train.ConclusionIf you are a fan of games that are like quake,painkiller,serious sam, look no further for another dose of crazy action just don't expect the bosses to be climatic...

number of helpful: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
												Why should you buy Shadow Warrior?Two words: level design.I know that sounds like an odd reason, but for me it's the games greatest strength. Visit my profile page and go through my screenshots. The game is GORGEOUS.So what about the rest of the game? Well from a long time and avid player of the FPS genera, it's a mixed bag. I played the game twice all the way through. Once on "normal" difficulty and then again on "insane". On normal I used the Katana the entire time. That was probably stupid, but the melee combat felt extremely satisfying. The Ki powers were also a blast to use. That wore off about 8 hours into the game. Little did I know there's 8 more hours to grind through. I got that feeling of: "Is this over yet?"Well after some consideration I felt like I should give the game another try. My inner achievement hunter had something to do with it too! :-)The second time I went with insane mode and used all the weapons. With the inclusion of the 1.5 optimization patch the game looked and ran better than ever. However, the weapons felt weak. Extremely weak. Even the bad‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•looking quad barreled shotgun. Once I got my hands on the crossbow and the its chargeable shot upgrade, the game became cake. With fully upgraded healing powers and the one shot crossbow, yet again I got that feeling of boredom.So why am I recommending this game after calling it boring? Because it's like a really pretty bowl of oatmeal. There really isn't anything "wrong" with the game. It just middle of the road with a great number of sights to see.My main gripe with Shadow Warrior is it tries to please everyone at the same time. The attempt of fusing old school and new doesn't seem to work for me. The game contains the Bioshock "Look everywhere for cash" loot system. It also has RPG elements, unlockables, and a low assortment of opponent's to kill. My opinion is if you going to make a FPS, choose a school and stick with it.Pro's ++ Level Design + A huge range of environment's and aesthetics to enjoy! So many sights to behold! + Optimized + Looks great and runs really well!+ Characters + The chemistry between Low Wang and his demon friend is quite entertaining.+ Story + Easy to follow and keeps your interest.+ Arsenal + Large variety of weapons and powers to make combat interesting - for a time...+ Melee Combat + The Katana is really fun to play with!+ Secrets + A must for any FPS.+ EX Mode + Allows you to keep all your upgrades after you beat the game.Con's - - Enemies - Offers a limited amount of baddies to slay.- Unbalanced Weapons - On the highest difficulty some of the weapons are pretty weak.- Loot - If you want your weapons to have additional features, you better look EVERYWHERE for cash.- Game Length - Game progression is entirely "gated". Everything is locked until you kill each wave of enemies.Shadow Warrior goes on sale frequently at 75% off. Well worth it at that price. If your playing for the first time, play the game on either easy or normal. Don't do what I did, use all the weapon's in the game!

number of helpful: 13 of 15 people (87%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2013
												This is easily the greatest shooter I've played this year and I don't mean that ligthly since this year was amazing for shooters. First there was the wonderful homage to the 80s known as Blood Dragon and then there was the very faithful Rise of the Triad reboot, but Shadow Warrior rose above even those great games. As a HUGE fan of the original 3D Realms classic, this new Shadow Warrior filled me with so much delight. Never before has melee combat been more satisfying in a FPS. The guns were badass, but the real star of the show was your trusty blade. Shadow Warrior rose the bar (or katana) when it comes to getting close and personal. The katana is just so incredibly fun to use. I was even suprised by this game's story in how it actually managed to grab me. I was expecting some kind of silly excuse plot which is par for the course for retro style shooters, but Shadow Warrior actually had a very well-told story that made me care for what was happening. Instead of just having a reason to kill some demons you've got this wonderful tale that's both tragic and beautiful. Instead of just being a walking sterotype, Lo Wang this time around is an actual character. During the course of his adventure he develops and goes through a character arc. He's both witty and badass. Also there's his demon friend Hoji. Hoji was just wonderful. This new Shadow Warrior not only manages to do the original justice, but might actually be superior to it. Much thanks to Flying Wild Hog for delivering this amazing game. I'm really looking forward to seeing what else they deliver in the future, Whether it be more Shadow Warrior or something else. They're defintely on my list of favorite developers.Last thing I'd like to mention is the game's satisfying length.  The game is a nice solid 14 hours long and has a lot of replay value. The RPG-style upgrade system makes for a lot of replay value.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
 "Who wants some Wang?"Shadow Warrior is a first-person shooter video game developed by Flying Wild Hog and published by Devolver Digital. It is a Reboot of the old Shadow Warrior that was released back in 1997.  Lo Wang's Bizarre Adventure	The story is simple and straightforward, You play as Lo Wang, A Modern Assassin who works for a powerful guy named Zilla. Lo Wang is sent to purchase a legendary Katana, The Nobitsura Kage, From a guy who collects Japanese antiques called Miziyaki. Unfortunately, Miziyaki refuse's the offer, So the only choice Lo Wang had was trying to take the sword by force, Everything goes wrong and Demons from Hell has invaded The Earth. Join Lo Wang's adventure as he tries to claim The Nobitsura Kage and save mankind! Gameplay This is an old-school shooter, It's amazing and It's very Challenging, The Katana action is great, And there are a lot of Skills and Powers that you can obtain. The weapon upgrades are really useful. It's a solid old-school shooter. The easter eggs are also a nice touch to the game. Graphics Superb, Fantastic level design, Runs very smooth and really great visuals. Soundtrack Krzysztof Wierzynkiewicz, Michal Cielecki and Adam Skorupa did an astonishing job with the soundtrack, It really fits the game. VERDICT This is a hidden gem, I enjoyed this game and I recommend it. A very solid FPS.8.7 out of 10.PS. Lo Wang's cheesy quotes are really hilarious.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
												In 1997, Shadow Warrior released for PC as a spiritual successor to Duke Nukem 3D, and starred a terribly racist Asian caricature named Lo Wang. This isn‚Äôt a premise that sounds like it would be able to endure nearly twenty years later, and yet developer Flying Wild Hog revived Shadow Warrior last year on the PC, which has now made its way to the Xbox One and PS4. Lo Wang‚Äôs return is a successful one, with all of the purposely-offensive humor and over-the-top gameplay you‚Äôd expect from it.Amazingly, Shadow Warrior‚Äôs plot is not to be overlooked, as it is engaging and becomes more serious and grounded as the game goes on. This is tempered by the silly combat and hilarious dialogue throughout the game. The player takes on the role of Lo Wang, a gun-toting, sword-wielding, ninja mercenary working for the mysterious Orochi Zilla, a powerful Japanese businessman. What starts off as a routine mafia transaction quickly spirals out of control into a demon-filled murderfest wherein Lo Wang uses his last name to reference his‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•on a regular basis. Accompanying Wang is the smart-mouthed demon Hoji, who serves as Lo Wang‚Äôs guide through the world of pseudo-Japanese culture and mysticism. The plot works perfectly with the insane gameplay and general silliness that Shadow Warrior provides.The combat in Shadow Warrior can be described as fast, bloody, and insane. The player is given ninja stars, a samurai sword, and a lot of guns to blast through hordes of ninjas, police officers and demons in one of the messiest first-person hack-and-slash experiences I‚Äôve ever played. The guns can be a little difficult to use, as the aiming system can be a little unwieldy and some guns feel underpowered, but the swordplay is a lot of fun and is intended to be Wang‚Äôs tool of destruction for the majority of the time.Lo Wang also gains magical abilities to aid him, which include healing spells and telekinetic push abilities. My personal favorite is an ability that allows Wang to spin in a whirlwind attack that decapitates everyone around him. These abilities help to round out the combat and give players a multitude of ways to go about any given combat scenario, although I was mostly content just slashing enemies to bits.Lo Wang has many upgrade opportunities at his disposal as well, which are cleverly broken into different categories that can be upgraded by different means. Karma, for example, will allow the player to purchase certain modifiers, while money allows the player to upgrade their equipment. The options for how the player can evolve and upgrade Wang are pretty vast, meaning that the each person can upgrade according to their play style. I like to run in swinging a sword, so I need to be able to take a lot of damage, so I upgraded healing spells, damage resistant perks, and maximum health modifiers. This upgrade system can be a little complicated, but is well-worth taking the time to learn, as it‚Äôll make Lo Wang an even bigger badass according to each player‚Äôs personal style.Shadow Warrior looks great on the Xbox One, for the most part. Slicing a demon into multiple pieces has never felt more rewarding, but some elements, like human characters are low-res and a bit fuzzy. The sound, however, is great. The music is fast-paced and has an Eastern flair to it, and the sound effects are top-notch. The voice acting is also surprisingly good, especially from Wang‚Äôs sidekick Hoji who helps out with a lot of the exposition and banter.The combat is awesome, the dialogue is hilarious, and the excessive gore is a guilty pleasure that never gets old. Shadow Warrior is one of those games that reminds us that gaming, at its core, should be fun, and it delivers fun times in a big way.

content:
Posted: April 12, 2015
This is a game I'd been meaning to get my hands on for a long, long time now, and the wait has definitely paid off. Shadow Warrior is a game that was revamped from its original 1997 counterpart (which you may download for free on Steam) featuring the main protagonist, Lo Wang, and was originally produced to test improvements on the same game engine used to create Duke Nukem; this game shares the same studio that created Duke Nukem. This game takes a slightly different turn of events from the original, in which Wang takes on demons that are pouring in through portals while trying to retrieve the Nobitsura Kage: an ancient katana of immense power that can be used to strike down Gods. Lo Wang is aided by a masked demon named Hoji, who also requires this ancient katana.There are several points of interest in this game:The Upgrade Systems - There are several things in which you can upgrade, and several subcatagories within each. The upgrade system is pretty immerse, as you have several versions of currency to go into each; for instance, Money is used to upgrade your Weapons, while Karma Points are used to Upgrade your Skills. Within this upgrade system-which, unlike most games, doesn't make you feel under-powered if you 'specked yourself wrong'-allows the player to create the way they want to play. This menu can be accessed any time, so feel free to pour all your points into a needed skill during a boss battle!Swordplay - At first, you gain the basic abilities of quick slices (LMB) a charged heavy strike (hold RMB.) However, as you purchase upgrades through the menu, you gain more combinations and bonuses. Most of the combos you learn involve double-tapping a direction key and holding LMB (for instance, a jabbing strike that is later used to break specific statues is mapped as W,W+LMB) on the keyboard, but I have not yet tried it for controller. Also, you can throw shurikens (which are unlimited in amount) while wielding the katana so that the enemy can feel the pain before arriving to your blade.Gunplay - Since Wang moves really quick-as do the enemies in this game-the gunplay is very reminiscent of a classic shooter, which involves a lot of strafing. However, you may hold as many weapons as you want. and each one has such an interesting and unique playstyle that I will guarantee you Will revisit weapons you thought were outdated due to a new pickup. Plus, you receive weapons as somewhat of a store theme; for instance, you pick up a submach that was just sitting in a police car.Humor - Think Duke Nukem in this one, except without Jon St. John's voice-acting and an Asian themed character that blatantly points out his name is Wang. Though childish at times, the humor in this game is...well....funny.Story - I really do not want to post up too many spoilers on this one, but the story in Shadow Warrior is actually pretty good, which decent backing to the original.Graphics & Gore - Though my computer can only do so much due to its 'graphical hindrances,' I was not able to fully appreciate the full potential of this title when it comes to the looks while trying to play it smoothly; that is not to say that I didn't crank up the graphics for a brief time to enjoy the beautiful rendering of this hardcore world. Everything in the world (though it launches you in a single direction at times) looks great, from the trees, to the bamboo, to the creature designs. Also, this game is clearly not for kids due to the amount of gore, and is believed by some to be the bloodiest game of all time due to this. However, if you press 'R' while wielding your Katana you can wipe the blood off, so there's a bright side to these grim features.TL:DR -There are so many other things I'd like to recommend about Shadow Warrior, but you should honestly just play it for yourself. I bought it with a bundle from another site for $10 and regret nothing. Shadow Warrior is a great game, with some of the most interesting mechanics you will ever find in a title. Do not think about Duke Nukem Forever if considering the purchase of this title, because this reboot does right by nearly everything. Thanks for reading.Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews	.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
												I came to Shadow Warrior with no knowledge of the original, buying it purely because it's made by Flying Wild Hog who made one of my fave shooters, Hard Reset. And they've done it again. Shadow Warrior is a visually excellent first-person shooter that encourages you to utilise all the various skills at your disposal. Swordplay, shurikens, and magical attacks and defences as well as the usual arsenal of impressive guns. Take it from a fat-fingered gamer, the combat is elegant and easy to use. As other reviewers have noted, the voice acting is of a decent standard, with humour that is often crude but (most of the time) manages to avoid immaturity. Cutscenes are short and can be skipped if you're impatient, and there is excellent replay value in the form of EX Mode, which means you can replay the game with all the upgrades and weapons you earned in the first playthrough. And trust me, you will want to play it again. Once will not be enough.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												I recommend this game to anyone who's tired of modern shooters. It takes a step back towards the golden age of FPS when its predecessor was released. It doesn't take itself too seriously which I found refreshing and it's packed with immature humour and one-liners that make you giggle every time you hear them. In contrast it is also unbelievably bloody at times which mature gamers might appreciate. The levels are still mostly linear but they are rarely interrupted by scripted events and cutscenes. Level variety is good and the environments are gorgeous. Enemy and weapon variety is average but the game has a nice melee combat system and you'll probably end up using the sword more than any other weapon. The graphics are solid and work really well with the overall design. The story is what you'd expect from a shooter but it doesn't disappoint. The price is also quite reasonable considering the length of the game. I'd recommend getting it even at full price but if you're patient you might want to wait. It seems to go on sale fairly regularly.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2016
												Almost brilliant.Shadow Warrior is, of course, a remake of the 1997 3D Realms shooter, and after doing their 90s-styled shooter, Hard Reset, Flying Wild Hog was a natural pick for the task. And at its heart, Shadow Warrior does the most important part best, presenting first-person katana antics well. You can unlock different moves, each with a double-tap and a left-or-right click, that allow you to do spin attacks, wave attacks, or just do more damage. In addition, you can unlock various spells that can stun your enemies, heal you, or put up a shield. And when you're using all that to slice through hordes of soft, squishy enemies is where Shadow Warrior finds itself most satisifying. There are various guns, and though effective, they don't feel nearly as satisfying as applying your blade. Still, mixing up the two can be fun and this game has you constantly switching gears.A fact the game doesn't really point out but that you need to know, and badly: tapping shift while holding a direction does a quick dash in that direction. Crucial, but if was in the opening tips, I missed it.It really does the feel of a 90s shooter well with innovation on the side, blood gushing from delimbed enemies with no guilt or introspection, just more enemies to cut down. But it does have notable issues. Switching between special moves and quick-dashes cramped my hand badly. Maybe it works better with a controller, but to me the controls were a literal handache, something I don't feel often. Furthermore, it throws a lot of what I term "stop sign" enemies - enemies with shields, enemies with a weak spot in their back, enemies who teleport in and out, enemies that turn invisible,  bosses with weak spots to reveal - and those aren't very fun. Though you've given the tools, it constantly feels like having to unlock doors to have my sword fun. "Okay, yeah, I'll launch you in the air, now can I kill you?" "Can you reappear so I can kill you?" The bosses in particular become exercises in tedium - I can excuse having to repeat a process three times (Zelda, for its many weaknesses, taught games this golden number), but having to do it 4-8 times is no good. The game overall is longer than it probably should be, having shown its hand by about 2/3rds of the way through the game and then just pretty much serving up the same fights, but with increasing numbers of big guys as you get towards the end. Having the middle of the game be a slog through grey industrial environments doesn't help it feel any shorter, either.That being said, it does bring a lot of new elements to the shooter genre. At times I almost wish it had been more of a third-person brawler akin to a Platinum game, but it does do the melee work aptly and throwing a wave of murderous chi energy through a wave of onrushing enemies and seeing multiple decapitations go flying doesn't stop being satisfying. The story is serviceable, but the length of the game meant I had trouble keeping track of who certain characters were or where the plot was when it stopped after hours of play to barf up a story animation. Thankfully, though, it avoids a lot of the Orientalist racism of its forbear. While it doesn't avoid it entirely - the "Wang" jokes certainly seem here to stay, and the mythology seems to be a confused mashup of Japanese and Chinese elements - it works internally and there was only a few throwaway jokes that got a cringe out of me. Speaking of which, the humor is pretty hit or miss, with the fortune cookie gags serving up the worst of the misses. The game is best when it's just wryly sarcastic, and Lo Wang thankfully ends up being a pretty likeable guy whose identity isn't just solely hung on "Asian".Overall, it's worth a playthrough if you want a strong hit of nostalgia, or if you really liked Serious Sam, Painkiller, and their ilk. While it doesn't quite transcend its roots, it translates them well into the modern era and does enough that's innovative to be worth a whirl - just bear in mind it's very much a diamond in the rough.

content:
Posted: August 2, 2016
												Sometimes every now and then a game comes along that surprises you - renewing faith in a genre and reminding you exactly why you liked it in the first place.With expectations low thanks to the prolific consolization and emphasis on creating cinematic experiences to the detriment of the game-play, Shadow Warrior benefits greatly from being a game that understands, first and foremost, a first person shooter is about combat.A reboot of the 1997 game of the same name, aside from a few references, it's decidedly different style shooter. While the original had no story to speak of, with protagonist Low Wang, much in same vain as Duke Nukem acting as a pop culture spouting archetypes of 80's and early 90's action heroes, Lo Wang in the reboot, while retaining much of this is more fleshed out by virtue of having a personality - and a sense of purpose.The story motivation itself is relatively simple. Low Wang must recover several blade parts, while a mystical story of demons from another realm unravels around it. Comparative to another FPS revival such as the New Order, with continual interruptions to game-play, long monotonous mumbling of self-important up it's own‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•nonsense, Shadow Warriors story-telling never feels like it's a detriment to the gameplay or taking itself too seriously, remaining concise with an appropriate tonal shift towards the end the game - that sort of becomes poetic, without being Bioshock Infinite levels of pretentious, it's surprisingly moving considering the game is about a man who repeatedly makes‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•jokes.The story is there, if you want it - never over stepping the mark into obnoxious.Much like Kurt Russell in Big Trouble In little China, (which was a clear inspiration for the first game), Low Wang is a goof, a legend in his own mind while paradoxically tripping over himself on a continued basis. An avid collectors of comic books, at one point the player will enter his weapon laden Batman cave, as he shaves his head in a self aware reference of the alpha male figures he aspires towards - it's both a reverential acknowledgment to the genres influence, while directly relating to the player, who probably isn't the coolest dude in the world.Expecting old school shooting may lead to a huge disappointment for fans of the original, gone are maze like levels, replaced by Painkiller style arena battles. While old school elements are retained, such as rewarding exploration, simultaneously carrying a multitude of weapons, item pickup's in the form of health and armor and minimum plot, it carried over elements from Flying Wild Hogs previous game, while expanding upon it with action RPG elements - in many ways, it shares more in common with a game like Diablo or Devil May Cry than the original Shadow Warrior.Essentially, player enters area, kills creatures, progresses, rinse and repeat.This may sound repetitive, and towards the end of the game it can be - much like Diablo it's alleviated with a constant stream of crums in the form of upgrades, new enemies and sporadic bursts of narrative as well a changes of scenery to give the player just enough momentum to continue playing.It doesn't seem hyperbole, to call the combat, sublime. On the lower difficult, spamming a few shots, or a few sword swings will quickly led to redundancy. On the higher "insane" difficulty, the context changes entirely.In a similar games like Serous Sam - it uses huge environments with much of the combat at a distance, when enemies reach the player, it's almost entirely a case of pushing the backward key with largely inept weapons, Shadow Warrior on the other hand uses tighter environments to minimize downtime - implementing a dodge keys to make any direction viable, encouraging the player not to retreat but to actively move around mitigating crowds using their head on the fly. Very rarely will the player be still, or monotonously pushing the backward key, even healing itself can be done while going on the offensive, simultaneously shooting at the same or upgrading KI attacks to act as direct healing - respectfully limited .Much like Kurt Russell in Big Trouble In little China, (which was a clear inspiration for the first game), Low Wang is a goof, a legend in his own mind while paradoxically tripping over himself on a continued basis. An avid collectors of comic books, at one point the player will enter his weapon laden Batman cave, as he shaves his head in a self aware reference of the alpha male figures he aspires towards - it's both a reverential acknowledgment to the genres influence, while directly relating to the player, who probably isn't the coolest dude in the world.Expecting old school shooting may lead to a huge disappointment for fans of the original, gone are maze like levels, replaced by Painkiller style arena battles. While old school elements are retained, such as rewarding exploration, simultaneously carrying a multitude of weapons, item pickup's in the form of health and armor and minimum plot, it carried over elements from Flying Wild Hogs previous game, while expanding upon it with action RPG elements - in many ways, it shares more in common with a game like Diablo or Devil May Cry than the original Shadow Warrior.Essentially, player enters area, kills creatures, progresses, rinse and repeat.This may sound repetitive, and towards the end of the game it can be - much like Diablo it's alleviated with a constant stream of crums in the form of upgrades, new enemies and sporadic bursts of narrative as well a changes of scenery to give the player just enough momentum to continue playing.It doesn't seem hyperbole, to call the combat, sublime. On the lower difficult, spamming a few shots, or a few sword swings will quickly led to redundancy. On the higher "insane" difficulty, the context changes entirely.In a similar games like Serous Sam - it uses huge environments with much of the combat at a distance, when enemies reach the player, it's almost entirely a case of pushing the backward key with largely inept weapons, Shadow Warrior on the other hand uses tighter environments to minimize downtime - implementing a dodge keys to make any direction viable, encouraging the player not to retreat but to actively move around mitigating crowds using their head on the fly. Very rarely will the player be still, or monotonously pushing the backward key, even healing itself can be done while going on the offensive, simultaneously shooting at the same or upgrading KI attacks to act as direct healing - respectfully limited .Unlike a game such as Borderlands, where RPG elements boil down to "press X", which is nowhere near enough depth to justify it's game time, Shadow Warrior uses the traditional incremental increase of weapons coupled with weapon upgrades, sword upgrades, skill upgrades and ki upgrades, easily accessible, easily comprehensible, without being reduced to a single key press.Borderlands boasted very much about it's touted millions of weapons, yet all arguably feel the same without in anything other than a minimal alteration, comparatively, Shadow Warrior has half a dozen, with upgrades significantly changing both the damage output and play-style of the weapon.To alleviate the problem of swinging disconnected melee synonymous with other games i.e. Bethesda titles - rather than spamming light and heavy swings as the primarily means of combat, Shadow Warrior focuses on double tap charge ups with single hit bursts minimizing the sense of disconnection and using the KI as a means to justify non connected attacks.In a modern shooter - enemy variety typically consists of, shoot Arab man, shoot Russian man, or shoot man who has betrayed the American Dream.Sadly, steam sucks‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•so this review is cut off. Great!

content:
Posted: July 28, 2014
												The keyword to describe this game is "Love". I couldn't tell you where exactly the love is going towards, be it the old Shadow Warrior, the old shooter genre in general, martial art action/drama films, Eastern pop fiction or just good game development practice. But one thing is certain: this has got to be one of the most surprisingly high quality games I've ever encountered. While initially excited about Shadow Warrior making a comeback, I had my doubts about this game, I had thought that Devolver was going to try and ride on the success it was getting with Croteam's Serious Sam 3 and milk games of similar genre for all its worth in the style of Activision's usual workings, and after playing Hard Reset I had once thought Flying Wild Hog a group similar to The Farm 51 in that they were a studio no longer in the glory days of People Can Fly, and while trying their hardest weren't quite yet at that standard of quality people like me would be paying attention to.I was wrong. I was wrong on every front. Not only has Devolver proved me wrong and established its a publisher willing to put time and money into a product as absurd and obscure as Shadow Warrior, but Flying Wild Hog has also proven to me that they were the studio that cleary are the best of the people that fled People Can Fly, and have managed to take an old magic to soaring new heights.This game is something of a small miracle; its the video game equivilant of The Lego Movie. It is baffling just how polished and sophisticated this game's mechanics are. The sword combat is sharp and absolutely sublime, so much that it feels alien, like it should belong in another genre, in a game that would play like Devil May Cry or something from the works of Platinum Games. The moves and powers you can pull off with the sword are visercal and satisfying, and enemies will dismember like paper mache origami made from blood and internals. The guns meanwhile feel like the best parts of Painkiller and Bulletstorm with the visercal satisfaction of the former and the stragetic rewarding of the latter. There's no gun that's a giant stakegun or a weapon that'll let you steer sniper rounds up the taints of enemies, but there's a gun that'll shoot high-velocity, explosive crossbow bolts, and baby, I couldn't ask for anything more delightfully enjoyable.And its all because of that keyword: love. There was no reason this game should have been this good, or even good at all, but because of the love from a small American publisher and an even smaller Polish developer, this game has hit completely out of the park in every possible way.I cannot stress this enough: you need to try this game. Its a perfect 10/10, and its forever put Devolver and Flying Wild Hog on my radar.

content:
Posted: January 13, 2016
												Much like the new Wolfenstein games, Shadow Warrior is a modern reimagining of older FPS games (with health/armor pick ups and non-regenerating health. You play as Lo Wang, a master of the katana and dirty jokes. After a business transaction goes awry, a demon apocalypse ensues. Pros:+Great melee combat. With all of the different special katana moves, it feels like playing a fighting game. +Good variety of weapons and upgrades. +Hoji and Lo Wang have some hilarious dialogue. +Levels are pretty big and have a lot of secrets hidden within them (such as extra currency for upgrading your weapons/skills/powers).+The power/skills system is pretty in depth. You can unlock different abilities, such as the ability to trap enemies or heal yourself.+Good variety of enemies. +The animated story scenes are awesome.Cons:-Game feels like a shooting gallery. Complete a task and enemies spawn. Rinse and repeat. I know this is a homage to older games that threw tons of enemies at you, but this formula just gets old. I never felt this way in the new Wolfenstein games.-The boss fights. All of them except for one play out the exact same way. Shoot a weak point in the armor until they are crippled. Then you shoot the exposed weak point to damage it. Rinse and repeat. I wasn't expecting Dark Souls-caliber boss fights, but I wish they would have been more varied than this. -The level where you have to wear the gas mask is terrible (it obscures your vision). Overall, Shadow Warrior is a fun FPS. It has some rough edges, but the pros definitely outweigh the cons.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												Started out strong: funny protagonist, the awesome recoiless submachine gun, big chunky enemies for you to pump your lead into, and last but not least, wang cookies.And then midway through the game, you will find that the game's initial charms start to wear off. The game never deviates from its initial path: the same 'wang' jokes are told time and again, the new jokes err more on the side of cringe-worthy instead of funny. The cool weapons become underpowered as the game starts to pile more and more fatties at you at any single point in time. The level design is dreadfully uninspired and boring. You run from point to point triggering the game's setpieces in order to spawn the various over-used enemies which the game throws at you in every chapter. In between the points, you will almost never find any enemies lurking or patrolling. The katana is the game's saving point, severing limbs and decapitating heads never gets old. However, the hit boxes for the larger sized enemies are a little wonky, so you might find yourself supposedly slashing at the back of the bugger, only to be disappointed that none of the hits registered. Final rating: 4/10

												This game kicks‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• I was actually surprised how much‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•it kicks. The combat mixes up those traditional elements of first person shooters to weave in the sword seamlessly, and when you play on harder difficulties, you really are going to be using every tool on your belt. On top of the sharp combat, it's got witty dialog and a pretty engaging plot, not to mention a fantastic choice of characters. Possibly my favorite aspect is the sheer number of secrets nestled cleverly in the game. If I had to be critical, the combat can get a bit grindy toward the end, and I do kind of wish some of the weapons were more creative  (like flamethrower? Really?). Still, for the price, this game is a steal. It's a pretty long game, and looks beautiful, so don't pass this one up.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2016
												Let's compare 3 FPS games with their reboot, remake, spiritual successor, pseudo-sequel or whatever you'd like to call them.First there was Duke Nukem 3D, which led to Duke Nukem Forever, which took forever to be released. Somewhat a failure and received widespread panning.And then there's the classic Doom, which led to the new DOOM (2016) released recently. Not bad, but plays entirely differently from the FPS pioneer.Now look at Shadow Warrior, which claims to be a, say, "re-imagination" of the classic Shadow Warrior. However, it is not much different than Duke Nukem Forever or DOOM (2016). See, by "re-imagination" it always means better graphics, more interesting gameplay mechanics and etc., but you have to remember, if you're expecting the same experience as the classic version of the game, you will not get it.But that does not mean it's not a good game. It's a great game, in fact it's great if you had never played the original classic Shadow Warrior. You'll just have some difficulties adjusting to the new mechanics if you are playing this because you played the original.Did I also mention there were not many games in the market where you can graphically dismember demons? "Were", because that was before DOOM (2016) came out.SW/10.

number of helpful: 11 of 15 people (73%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												Well, I finally finished this one.  Shadow Warrior is f**king great. <walks off stage>---Okay, fine... Shadow Warrior is the reboot of Duke Nukem 3D's companion game, Shadow Warrior, a Build Engine FPS from the Doom-clone era of shooters.  This game was overlooked back in its time with Quake literally rendering 2.5D engines outdated and only Duke Nukem survived to become a fan favorite, but as Gearbox bought the rights to Duke Nukem and sold it out for Borderlands 2 funds, it seems that the tides have turned with Shadow Warrior coming out on top.Lo Wang is as stereotypical as it gets.  While it may be quite toned down in comparison to the BuildEngine classic, Wang is a parody of Eastern films and action flicks alike, with a sword and ego to match.  As an origins story and precursor to the original, this game also introduces a mix of Chinese and Japanese mythos, and with it a companion character that grants you magic powers.  This undead character also happens to be a snark, and the dialogue between the two characters is priceless.The combat features 7 guns with upgrades, 2 consumable weapons, 1 badass katana with three combos and two swing types, and 4 magic powers, as well as a shuriken or quick-stab key.  As many of the guns have alternate fires and the sword or magic powers can be used in your left hand with any gun, there's plenty of room for diversity.  The enemies themselves range from wallrunning to tankish, exactly as you should see, and the combat keeps fresh for the duration of the game.  Every aspect of the game is incredibly well thought out and the game never feels artificially difficult.As a retro shooter, there are also countless secrets and easter eggs throughout the levels, including fortune cookies that generally read out to something incredibly immature or stereotypical in proper 3DRealms fashion.  These give you progression points for your magic powers, extra perks, or even just money to upgrade weapons.  By the end of the game, you'll most likely have a good 70% of the weapon upgrades and will be missing around nine power/perks, assuming you aren't a completionist whp needs to find every single secret before being satisfied.  It plays very similarly to Hard Reset, minus the strange machine interfaces.As for the story, it's very well-written, though a bit hard to follow, especially with the sub-plot of Hoji's relatives and the Whisperers' memories.  It's definitely worth listening into, but you're not looking into Dark Souls levels of deep lore.  The story is also very well-acted and full of dark but silly over-the-top action.  FWH nailed the 3DRealms style of this game in every way.  It'll take you about 13-15 hours to complete on average; a replay may be closer to 11-12, but a worst-case scenario with loads of screwups will probably be around 14-17 should you get horribly lost.  It doesn't happen often, but occasionally the placement of the door seals combined with some areas' mazelike design can get annoying.Overall, there are certainly flaws you can nitpick out of the game, but what's important is that it's a fantastic game that definitely is worth a look.  It's like a retro shooter the way you wish you remembered them, and doesn't disappoint in the slightest.  There isn't too much for replay value-- singleplayer with survival and new-game+-- but the main campaign is great enough to justify the price of admission alone.  Devolver is a great publisher and often has excellent sales on this game, but I wouldn't wait that long, especially with Shadow Warrior 2 coming soon.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Shadow Warrior is as much a 90's throwback as it is a modern game, and the hybrid of styles results in an immensely fun experience!Wang‚Äôs story takes a backseat to the action for the majority of the game but is still interesting enough to keep you moving along. You start off on a quest to obtain a piece of a rare sword, which eventually escalates into an all-out war between the demon and human worlds. Early on you obtain a companion in the form of a demonic spirit named Hoji who provides some great humor and exposition during the slower parts of the game. The gameplay is exactly what you hope for in a retro remake like this. You have a nice (and upgradable) health bar and can heal up with health packs and armor pickups. You won‚Äôt find yourself hiding behind a dumpster waiting for regen after taking three hits in this game! The weapons feel equally awesome, from your trusty and versatile katana to the classic rocket launcher, they all feel like they pack a nice punch and give good feedback when used. The weapons also include a very nice upgrade system that does a lot more than just add more damage or ammo to your clip. Want your shotgun to have 4 barrels? How about upgrading your rocket launcher to fire three rockets at once, or a crossbow with explosive bolts? Done, done and done!On top of your equipment, you will obtain passive and active skills to further customize your experience. The skills are a lifesaver in the more intense areas of the game, with the ability to heal on the fly, or knockback a group of enemies; and the passive abilities such as more health or improved critical rate help you to feel progressively stronger as the game gets tougher.At the end of the day, Shadow Warrior scratches that itch of being powerful in an FPS while fighting equally powerful enemies. You won‚Äôt be taking cover, you won‚Äôt be playing wack-a-mole with enemies who are also in cover, and I wouldn‚Äôt want this game to play any other way!

content:
Posted: April 19
												Shadow Warrior is one hell of a good Single Player game! The plot: You (a high ranked... assassin-type of guy) have the mission to find a sword. You find it, bring it to your boss, and suddenly hell brakes loose. Demons, skeletons, mafia [...] there are countless enemies to fight. The story develops very nicely and keeps you entertained - not only because of the sarcastic spirit that is following you around. You will want to know what happens next after each chapter! The gameplay is more or less always the same. Different areas, different enemies, different ways to beat them. But, your arsenal of skills and weapons, plus the various enviromental extras do make each fight different. It kept me entertained for 10 hours straight! (excluded sleeping pause). By defeating enemies you will be able to learn new skills, upgrade existing ones, upgrade weapons and buy bonuses such as extra money, the ability to pick up specific demon heads as weapons etc. There were only 2 level were i felt annoyed, but that was only because they were incredibly long and had repetetive fights. Overall the gameplay is very good! Music & graphics are nice as well, i didn't have any complaints whatsoever.  After completing the game you will be offered to restart with all your existing upgrades - a good thing, but it also has a downside. You will have to play the game again. Which is, at least for me, a nono right now, because i do not think i would enjoy slaughtering all those demons again, just for the sake of completing all achievements. Overall? Recommended! It is a very fun fps shooter / sword fighting game that can keep you very busy. The countless secrets and various easter eggs just add to the fun. Beware the bunny of doom.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2013
												This game seduced me first because of katana (one of my favorite weapons for melee in L4D2, Killing Floor, Hotline Miami, etc etc.). Then I fell in love with the asian settings. And that game got me in the core with the katana again. Because hey, I'm bad with melee weapons and yet, with Shadow Warrior, I'm mastering the art of slicing demons. Shadow Warrior is a sort of remake of Shadow Warrior... the 90's game, that was a FPS with ninja weapons and demons or aliens or I never identified the race of the enemies. Here, in the remake, it's clearly creatures from the Asian mythology, from the other world.Lo Wang, the hero, is somewhat macho, very sure of himself and very dedicated to his task. He acquires some powers and he has companion, Hoji, whose story is revealed during the game.Like I've said, it's the first time that I feel great with melee. While Lo Wang has nice guns (necessary when you're swarmed by enemies), the katana is still very useful and deadly.Shadow Warrior is a very good game.... and could have been perfect if it didn't feel like an arena game. You can't advance in the story if you don't clean the area. And after a moment, seeing always the same is kinda irritating. Some passages are really hard even in the easiest difficulty. Yet, you find yourself wanting to push through.And Shadow Warrior kept his humour. I played the Shadow Warrior Classic Redux and the original version and that remake is keeping the tradition of fortune cookies with silly sentences. And the rabbits are also there. And the anime girls too.The graphics are beautiful. Some landscapes are really good. Besides, they're diversified: from Zilla fortress to his docks to the other world to the city...I loved the soundtrack. I really enjoyed it.I recommend that game. You have to try it.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												I can't say enough good things about this game. Let's take a look at it piece by piece. Characters The main character is Lo Wang. He's a wisecracking super-hero fan that views himself as a badass. Although that seems somewhat cliched, he IS a badass and can hold his own from the very first fight. His one-liners get better as his personality evolves which is also pretty badass. He's a hitman working for Zilla who is essentially the most evil, most powerful, deadliest man on the planet. Zilla makes an agreement with some demons that starts the demon apocalypse, though both sides intend to double cross each other. Lo Wang meets and becomes partners with a demon named Hoji. Hoji has been banished from the Shadow Realm for unknown reasons. Lo Wang and Hoji journey across Asia assembling pieces of the only sword that can harm the demon leaders. On their journey they discover more about who Hoji is, and the story becomes more about Wang and Hoji each trying to redeem themselves in their own ways and distance themselves from the somewhat nefarious villains they each started as. You can genuinely see their attitudes and morals evolve over the course of the game and it's awesome. Hoji: You have a cave with a suit of battle armor under your house? Glad you're keeping your superhero complex in check.Lo Wang: It's a demon apocalypse out. Not a bad time to be a superhero.  Gameplay The game at first seems like a hack n' slash with guns swapped in, but is actually really deep and diverse in gameplay. By the end of the game there are six guns in your belt along with your katana, and you can also use demon body parts against them if you upgrade your skills properly. On top of that there are seven super powers at your disposal. Weapons, skills, and super powers all use different systems with a variety of different upgrades trees. There's a huge variety of enemy types which keep you mixing all your abilities frequently to tackle them all. Nothing is overpowered because everything has a factor that keeps it from fighting uncontrollably. The game is mostly linear, though the side paths are there for those that want to explore and find collectibles, which are key to the uprade system. This game is a blast through and through.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
												Shadow Warrior is a modern reboot of a 3D Realms 1997 classic of the same name by Polish developer Flying Wild Hog which was founded by former employees of People Can Fly, creators of Painkiller. Shadow Warrior is set in modern day Japan and tells a rather convoluted story about a demon invasion. The players assume the role of assassin Lo Wang who works for a powerful Japanese industrial magnate Orochi Zilla who is tasked with retrieving a legendary katana called Nobitsura Kage. Things start to go very wrong very soon and Wang will have to fight his way through hordes of hired assassins and demons.The storytelling is mostly a miss because the game can‚Äôt decide whether it wants to be a parody or not. Lo Wang himself is a walking parody who will make fun of familiar gaming tropes, but on the other hand you have these prolonged and wholly uninteresting cutscenes about some demon family and their issues. It‚Äôs an awkward mish-mash that just doesn‚Äôt work and the writing is pretty weak in both cases. The serious story is just boring and while the jokes will make you chuckle here and there, they will also sometimes fall flat.The real reason to play this game is its setting and gameplay, both of which make Shadow Warrior stand out from most modern action games. The graphics are colorful and vibrant, the wonderful game world makes both the combat and the exploration a joy. You start off with an ordinary katana and a pistol, but you will acquire more and more weapons as you go along and you get to keep them all, there‚Äôs no weapon limit here. All weapons can be upgraded not only to become more powerful, but also to gain an alternate firing mode which is usually just completely over the top. For example, you can upgrade your two-barrel shotgun to a four-barrel shotgun and the alternate firing mode will enable shooting all four barrels at the same time resulting in complete carnage.While the shooting is great and wholly satisfying, the best part of the combat is slicing up your enemies with your trusted katana. You will have the opportunity to unlock a wide variety of different moves which will make the combat even more visceral and exhilarating. You‚Äôll actually do pretty well just by button mashing, but if you want to get a better performance score and additional karma points, then you will have to use these special moves. They‚Äôre actually rewarding to use in and of themselves because they just make you feel like a total badass. And that is something that Shadow Warrior does extremely well.Shadow Warrior provides a nice selection of different enemies ranging from hired assassins, low level demons to bigger and badder demons and huge bosses. The bosses actually don‚Äôt represent the highlight as they use the tried and true expose-and-hit-weakpoint type of design. They‚Äôre pretty good, but the best part is fighting droves of different enemies in big environments where you have melee enemies charging at you, ranged enemies throwing fireballs at you and flying enemies wreaking havoc from overhead. Managing these huge battles is just incredibly exciting and trying out all the different moves and weapons that are at your disposal is just unbelievably satisfying. The combat system is simply excellent.I found the pacing to be awesome. The game doesn‚Äôt constantly drown you in enemies which I often tend to find exhausting. After you clear an area, you are free to explore it and there‚Äôs a reason to do so as the world is littered not only with necessities such as health and ammo, but also secrets and easter eggs. However, if you‚Äôre only in it for the combat, you can just head on forward and you will be fighting non-stop. The game world is not consistently delightful, about halfway through you will have to trudge through several brown and bleak sewers, shipyards and some sort of a science facility. However, the design and the combat remain strong throughout making this a relatively minor gripe. Shadow Warrior is also quite a lengthy game, unlike most modern action and FPS games, it took me 16 hours to finish it on the normal difficulty setting.Flying Wild Hog simply understand action game design and Shadow Warrior is a truly great action game with a fantastic and visceral melee combat system, satisfying shooting mechanics and a wonderful game world.8 OUT OF 10 (GREAT)

number of helpful: 10 of 14 people (71%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 16, 2016
												Everything that "Duke Nukem Forever" tried/wanted to be and failed, "Shadow Warrior" is. It's both interesting and ironic, because the hype for "DNF" was so extremely high after all those years, last being seen as the height that was "Duke Nukem 3D", in the so called golden age of the FPS. And then everyone was dissapointed by the release, not mainly because it was a severely bad game, but because the hype was so exagerated. It was an okay game, but with a bad taste of out of date & misogynistic jokes & not fully realised or embraced gameplay which had too few highlights.No one expected anything from "Shadow Warrior" though, and it turned out to be everything we wanted (more or less). It has both a fresh updated feel to the graphics, while at the same time staying true to the roots and being honest about what it is. Nothing more nothing less. Which makes it so succesful!Though I liked Lo Wang as an elder man in the original, that he's a younger version here isn't a hinderence, merely a less original concept. After all, the story isn't the important thing. We want to kill hordes of demons & big bosses with cool and fun weapons within exotic settings. And that's exactly what we get to do!The weapons and powerups are a delight, the settings & maps are varied enough, picking up items when you've allready interacted by opening something is a matter of just moving your mouse over them which is a superb mechanic that I wish all games would implement, the controls are responsive, voice acting good, humour spot on. Ironically this game filled with‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•jokes & splatter is also one the most scenically beautiful games around. Extra plus for being able to replay the game with all power ups gained enabled!The only complaints I have are that it does drag on a bit too long, especially if you're going for all secrets like I was, and the music is repetitive and boring. And the little "drama" there is is really hard to get in to. My companion didn't do anything for me personally as a gamer, once I'd realised his healing ability stayed even after he was gone, I couldn't care less about his fate tbh. Which didn't bother me in the slightest, but of course it would have elevated the experience if it had. If my complaints had been met, this would have easily been a contender for game of the year!

number of helpful: 15 of 24 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												A very fun, very gruesome fps. If you have ever wanted to play with a sword in an fps game this is probably your best choice.I primarily enjoyed using my sword whenever possible, there are a variety of attacks you can do with it including a ranged one so you can almost always complete an entire fight with it without much trouble.   The guns are all upgrade-able with a variety of improvements and utility upgrades,  the ability to dual wield on the smg or explosive bolts for the crossbow are two of my favorites.  It has very satisfying though not overly difficult combat, that managed to keep me engaged throughout the 10 hour campaign.The artstyle and graphics are good.  Nothing really sticks out about them besides the fact that you can slash anything that can explode with your sword and see the results.  There are enough different enemies to prevent you from feeling like you are doing the same fight over and over.  You can blow limbs or cut your enemies in half, which results in blood everywhere and is one of the most enjoyable parts of the game.The story is coherent and entertaining, while the player cracks jokes at every opportunity he can, usually about his name.  Overall I had a lot of fun with this game and would love to see more games like this.  The campaign didn't feel too long or too short, and I think it would be re-playable enough for another run.  It's very hard these days to find a satisfying fps these days, but at least we have this one.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 15, 2014
												This is a review coming from someone who has never heard of Shadow Warrior or it's series.The story first and fore most seemed completely ridiculous and off the hook at first, but the more I played the game I found myself liking the game play but was really into the story line. The main character is ridiculous and if you like corny jokes turn up your speaker and listen to some classic Wang huehuehuehue type jokes. The game works as so. It's a first person smash em' up type game where your main weapon of choice will be your sword and as well as guns that are acquired throughout the game (launchers, pistols, machine guns, crossbows, demon heads you know the usual). The game play is addicting to those who like mindless violence and like seeing how well they are rated on their violent tendencies. There are three type of upgrade categories : one which uses money to upgrade physical weapons (dual pistols, dual machine guns, crossbow tips with explosive bolts, mini nukes as your rocket launcher), the second which uses ki to upgrade luck and mental factors of the protagonist, and the third which uses karma to upgrade sword abilities or stamina. Thanks to this upgrade system the mindless violence isn't so mindless as you actually have to use your mind to think which perks would actually benefit you. Enemies vary in shapes and sizes (small and big demons) but are all kill-able. Sometimes it's annoying as heck as some parts can become quite hard, but there's always a way to win.The graphics are as best as they come. They do not hinder, stall, or skip in any way. Cinematics are just as good. Don't expect any graphical errors here unless you have a problem with your computer.What happens after your done this game though? Well not much. You can run through it again but I had my fun with it and my friends are now enjoying it off my library. It was a fun game nothing against it, just wish I had more reason to go back to it. I may get some heat for my rating but even though this is a good and recommended game, I feel it's a honest rating :RATING : 7.5/10Gameplay B Story / Campaign B Visuals / User Interface B Sounds / Music B Replay-ability C+ Overall  B-FYI - I got this game on sale.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2015
												I must say, this game was pretty unique when it came to gameplay. At least to ME it was. Shadow Warrior is definitely a game that keeps you playing and can be a lot of fun! After about 3-5 hours though, the game can get pretty repetitive and boring, but once it jumps off the train, it jumps right back on for some more fun and‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•kicking!      It took me a good 10-15 hours to beat this game, and I wouldn't call it "holy grounds" but I definitely give it a thumbs up 4x. Now, some people may come to the conclusion that I just gave this game a 4/5 or a 4/10. Both of which are WRONG. The game starts with Lo Wang, protaganist with a clearly phallic name and almost blatantly racist background, walking up to an even more blatantly racist background while making a joke at it's expense. ("Hmm, I was expecting a more cliche setting, but I guess Koy ponds and Cherry Blossoms will have to do.")Then Wang procedes into the huge dojo filled with momentos and valuables that serve no purpose but to brighten the atmosphere. Then he walks into a room where he meets a man who has a pretty cool sword that Wang's master, Zilla wants for his sword fetish (Or so it seems...), and Lo Wang will stop at nothing to get it for him. Only to have his plans thwarted by a demon pest named "Hoji" who ends up killing the man and taking his sword, and‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•Zilla off in a Skype conference call. Long story short, stuff happens... blah blah blah... very important storyline... blah blah... Sword hacky slashy... blah... Boss battles... blah... explosive weapons... blah. That's pretty much the storyline!Well, aside from all of that, the game has quite a few Boss battles like the original Shadow Warrior (1996) had, and many secrets that also pay respects to the classic game like pixelated babes showering and pixelated secret rooms, that resemble certain areas from the original game. This game is in NO WAY a remake of the old one, it's a reboot. It takes Lo Wang and makes him more serious than funny, but it's not TOO serious, he's still able to crack a few unnecessary jokes now and then, but not like the original where everything was a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing joke. But all jokes aside, the Story telling is very deep, the atmosphere is warm to the touch (great), and the gun play is fun and funny! The voice acting... Eh, not up to par with most games, but it still gives you a feeling that you're there. The game includes Single Player and Survival modes. None of which incorporate multiplayer into them. This a 1 player game, and this was the big downer for me. After you beat the game, the replay value is there, but it's not very fun to go through again without a friend to enjoy it with you. The game is worth the buy, but not the $40 price tag. Wait for a sale and THEN get it. OVERALL: I'd say this game is a 4/5. HA HA! You thought I wasn't hinting at the final verdict, but I was! I got you sucker! Anyway, the storyline for Shadow Warrior was an enjoyable one and it made me want to beat it. The guns made for excellent hack/slash or bullet riddling fun and the explosives was just the icing on the cake! Voice acting could have been better, but it doesn't kill the score. What DOES is the lack of multiplayer. This game feels like it needed a multiplayer mode like Co-op or maybe a Deathmatch mode and that would've probably given this game a 4.5/5 or even a perfect score in my book. This is my opinion on the game. Some opinions may vary, but this is why I like Shadow Warrior. A must buy, but only when it's on sale.
