number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 12, 2016
												This is an excellent revision of an old, dated and rather socially awkward game. In many ways, Shadow Warrior seems to have learned all of the lessons from the failed Duke Nukem Forever in updating a classic game for a new audience. For one thing, Shadow Warrior takes everything that was great about the original, like the over the top violence, large sprawling level design, hitting things with swords and drops the things that were rather not good: Like the blatant racism. There are still plenty of puns and other ridiculous jokes, after all the protagonist is still called "Lo Wang" but it's clearly laughing with the protagonist - not at him because of his race. By far the greatest thing about Shadow Warrior is the intuitive, fun to use and well implemented sword plus magic system. While there ARE guns in Shadow Warrior, I kept consistently forgetting they existed by hacking demons apart with magic and the sword was just incredible fun. The sword strikes depending on how you're moving, allowing you to very precisely dismember various demons, police or yakuza once you become skilled with it. Add to that a series of magical ki abilities for your sword, plus magic spells that let you heal, stun enemies, float them in the air and so forth. This adds a tremendous amount of depth and strategy to the games combat, which is so much fun to use I - as mentioned - forgot there was actually firearms in the game. I easily just got through 90% of the game using only the sword and various ki abilities.This isn't to imply the guns are bad in any way, because there are numerous upgrades available to make them more effective, gain interesting secondary firing modes and so forth. I just found the sword so much fun to use and so effective, that I never felt the need to use the guns outside of a handful of specific sections where they are useful. Unfortunately, this might also be a comment on the general lack of enemy variety present in Shadow Warrior. There aren't a lot of enemy types in the game, so you will be facing the same combinations of demons and mini-boss demons a lot. This is especially vexing, because while there are armed human enemies in corrupt police and yakuza, they aren't used very frequently in the game at all. Minding, there is one particular section near the end, where it throws a huge amount of ordinary human fellows at you while you have a fully powered up sword. That was quite satisfying, especially after some of the difficult previous encounters.What I found interesting was that while the gameplay is fantastic, what surprised me and pulled me through the game in the end was the extremely well crafted story. Lo Wang has an actual character arc, with proper growth and some really great dialog with his demonic companion Hoji. There is actually a pretty compelling plot underneath all of the hacking people away with Katanas, with some great and genuinely emotive moments towards the end especially. It's especially rewarding getting some artistic cutscenes after finishing each of the long chapters, then facing off against some particularly well designed and fun to fight bosses (none of which felt frustrating, which is a genuine compliment). Overall this is a great update to an old game, which is also packed with great secrets (including sections designed to look like the original Shadow Warrior). Definitely recommend, especially if you like first person melee combat in a game.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												This is a highly recommended and fun game, though it is very gory. If lots of blood is not your thing, then you should probably avoid this title. That aside, Shadow Warrior ticks many boxes and has impressed me. First of all is the story. While many FPS games do not necessarily require a good story in order to give you some enemies to shoot or melee for a few hours, Shadow Warrior includes a very nice campaign, with some quite memorable characters and dialogue fleshing out the surprisingly high quality plot. With your protagonist named Lo Wang, one should expect some crude humour, and Flying Wild Hog do not disappoint. The cutscenes are also very nice,while also giving you the option to skip them if you so desire.The art style, particularly the basic enemies you fight, may look a little... crude? That's fine though, the dismemberment or other assorted violence will soon put that out of your mind. But the graphics of this game are quite brilliant, and the environments are truly spectacular - be they urban, forest, or snow. This also extends to the design of the weapons, which you can get a close up view of when you upgrade them with in-game cash you can find scattered all over the various levels. With a large variety, all of which you can carry at the same time if you are up to that point of the story, the weapons all look incredibly interesting, and play well too - bonuses for the visible changes in the weapons as you upgrade them, be it a laser pointer, or a larger tank, or the ability to fire multiple missiles at the same time...The levels all look impressive, and are very vast, although they are essentially linear. Not all of the secrets are incredibly well hidden, but they can be challenging to find them all. And the nod back to the original game and other old-school shooters in the form of secret retro areas is a very nice touch. Especially when Lo Wang breaks the fourth wall. One of the few complaints I have with this game is that the large nature of the maps means that sometimes you will be forced to double back, and sometimes it can become quite difficult to find out where you actually have to go to progress.That said, where this game truly shines is in the combat. Visceral, brutal, and with a variety of enemies to keep you on your toes, from standard humans with weapons, to demons with claws, wings, enemies who can teleport or turn invisible, to mention nothing of the mini-bosses or bosses in the game. This is not a truly realistic game, where cover is irrelevant, and you can tank damage by just healing it up again with one of your abilities, but it's fine and fun because you can just smash face first into enemies.The game revolves around finding a legendary katana, and so swordplay is a central point of the game, with skills to improve your character and the ability to hack and slash quite satisfying - dismemberment and decapitations galore. The ability to acquire both skills and other passive bonuses, as well as upgrading your weapons also gets a tick. The guns are also quite special, from more standard revolver and shotgun to the more esoteric quad-barrel shotgun and crossbow, each with 3 upgrades, and the ability to purchase extra ammo if you're in a pinch. This is complemented by the completely insane, but incredibly fun possibilities of using demon parts as one of your demon extermination tools...EDIT: The other problem I've found with this game is the boss fights: they become quite repetitive, and the same strategy is used to beat all 3. In addition, some of the "mini-bosses", especially the Berserker, can be annoying and time consuming to kill.Huge fun, with good replayability too. +1 recommendation.

content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
 Rating: 9/10, better than Bioshock Infinite. Good gameplayBadass swordplaySolid StoryGood graphics and art directionFunny dialogueThe makers of Hard Rest (Flying Wild Hog) are responsible for this excellent re imagining of Shadow Warrior. I played very little of the original Shadow Warrior, but it is basically an asian duke-nukem. Maze like level layouts, funny one liners, puzzles, culture references, all that sorta‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Now the reboot here is a lot different. The levels are less maze like and more straight forward, like newer fps games. There is some backtracking once and awhile, but in my opinion I didn't mind it. You can carry all of the guns you get and there are secrets and you fight hordes of enemies, no cover shooting at all. Health packs and everything too. Some minor character elements are still there but with a lot that was added to it. There is still some funny one liners and such, dont worry. Also they added a good story with good writing. Now the first part to cover is the gameplay. The gameplay consists of navigating Japenese inspired levels, doing small objects, and shooting and slicing up hordes of enemies. You have your health and stamina bar. Sprinting and a sort of ninja/dodge/dash with a press of the shift key and either (w a s d). The main focus in this game is the melee combat, which is amazing. A mix of light and heavy attacks, with double presses of either (w a s d). It is a very fluid and satisfying combat system all the way to the end. The enemies also slice up into little gibs, its cool as hell! The guns in the start are a tad underwhelming in the beginning, but it takes upgrades for those guns to make them more enjoyable. There is an upgrade system as well. One tier for powers, another for guns, and a last one for skills. The powers are a double tap (w a s d) right mouse button mechanic, for example self healing or using a force push ability. These use Ki crystals to upgrade by the way. Guns are for what you expect, upgrading your pistol, machine gun, cross bow and other guns with money. Skills are a mix of katana abilities and buffs for health, and killing demons and such, skills upgrade with karma, which you get by fighting enemies and secret karma stashes.The graphics are also amazing in this. I am using a Nivida GeForce GTX 770 with this game, Ultra, FXAA on, and it is nice looking. From vast mountains, bamboo trees, ponds, old Japanese architecture, huge temples, and towns. Nice lighting, textures and overall design. Only thing that could have had a bit more work is the faces of the people, they look sorta bad but they work. There is also some amazing cinematics, sort of like a visual moving novel. They tie into the story with the characters in it.The last part I want to go over is the story, its good. Its about a Japanese man named Lo Wang, a bodyguard for a corporation called Zilla Enterprises. Lo Wang is tasked to retrieve a sword called the Nobistura Kage for his boss Orochi Zilla. All hell breaks loose and the sword is taken by a demon like ghost. And demons rain all through Japan and murder everyone. You then are met with a demon entity named Hoji. Which he tells you the end of the world is because of the Nobistura Kage. There is a mix of Japanese spirit world lore in this too, and surprisingly an interesting and captivating story for a shooter like this.Now should you buy this game? Yeah, if you like hack and slash games with an old/new school fps twist with a good story. There are not very many games that are fps and have hack and slash elements: and its solid. I would even say I enjoyed this game more than a triple A title like Bioshock Infinite.

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
This is a long review so if you want a brief summary of why I recommend Shadow Warrior skip to Results and read from there.Flying Wild Hog makes a beautiful continuation of the Shadow Warrior saga brining the story and gameplay to heights unseen. Shadow Warrior brings so much that could not have been imagined from the original series to life.Story:If you have played the original Shadow Warrior games you will feel a large sense of nostalgia as well awe when you play this brilliant rendition of the series. You of course play as the great Lo Wang who is a guns for hire working for Zilla Enterprises. It is your quest to retrieve the fabled Nobitsura Kage, to you a simple task, but in reality something much more. After agreeing to purchase part of the sword from a rival group you figure out that what you have done is unlocked the gates to another realm. It is up to you and your companion Hogi to push through and retrieve all the pieces of the Nobitsura Kage and end the daemon onslaught. The brilliantly articulated story starts the game as a rather playful action-comedy then drifts into a deep action-drama. Campaign:Shadow Warrior was by no means a short game; it took me about 12-hours to beat the entire campaign. In actuality the campaign was incredibly easy (even on Hard), but in part this made the game entertaining. You could play this game a lot quicker by avoiding secrets and not exploring the surrounding area, but some of the secrets provide XP boosts which are handy for leveling up your skills. There are seventeen chapters and a prologue which start off in Japan and take you all over the place as you travel through time and space. Some of the chapters are relatively short, while others are incredibly long. I could imagine that even on Insane this game wouldn‚Äôt have been difficult because you can make so many saves. Although I didn‚Äôt figure this out till the end of the game, you can even save in the heat of battle meaning if you mess up you don‚Äôt have to start all over again. This may come in handy with the boss fights, but most of the other battles are simple enough. Gameplay:The game was challenging in that it kept you pressed into combat, but easy in that you could manipulate yourself to make any battle rather simple. I played the entire campaign using almost exclusively the Nobitsura Kage. In fact with certain upgrades you could make it so the Katana can heal you allowing you to destroy enemies without having to worry about health limitations. This game was clearly mapped for PC as the controls are so fluid with a keyboard and mouse. I would imagine using a controller for this game to be a terrible handicap. Each of the commands is mapped around your movement and you have complete control of which way you swing the sword by how you manipulate your mouse. This makes melee combat incredibly intense and rather skillful. The only time I found myself using weapons was to fight the bosses who were designed so that you could not use the Katana. The boss fights were incredibly entertaining, but they were rather similar in how you defeated them. Find the weak-point in the armor, destroy the weak-point, and finally shoot the crystals under the armor. Character Customization:The campaign offers you a player tree which allows you to buff yourself with the following: Skills, Weapons, and Powers. Skills offer Katana Mastery, Knowledge, Movement, Luck, and Mind. These allow you to enhance yourself by increasing weapon/money finding, stamina regrowth, maximum health, katana abilities, and so on. Powers include: Shockwave, Protection, Healing, and Flux. These allow you to essentially cast spells either on yourself or enemies. Weapons offer Katana (Nobitsura Kage), Tosainu Type 13 Revolver, Zi-Type 23 PDW, Mamushi Type-14 Crossbow, ZICS-C Shotgun, Onibi Flamethrower, YARI Type-24 Rocket Launcher. These can be upgraded with money you find in the game making them more powerful and versatile. By the end of the campaign I had only found enough money to upgrade the Shotgun, Rocket Launcher, and Zi-Type-23 PDW to maximum without putting any other upgrades in weapons. This means you may want to be careful what you spend your money on as you don‚Äôt get it by killing enemies you have to find it. Two additional weapons are Daemon Heads and Daemon Hearts, which you can only carry one of at a time and cannot be upgraded. Results:Shadow Warrior is a brilliant game that offers so much that I couldn‚Äôt see how anyone could dislike it. I never played the original Shadow Warriors when I was younger, but only recently had I purchased and beat them on steam. All the Shadow Warrior games are entertaining and I would recommend this game even if it wasn‚Äôt on sale. The campaign is fantastically well written, the level design is amazing, the combat is flawless, the puzzles are riveting, and the story is phenomenal. All in all Shadow Warrior is a great game where you can either hack your way through, burn up, shoot holes through, and even blow up thousands of enemies. Pros:+Beautiful scenery and level design.+Fantastic combat system which is incredibly fast paced.+Great graphics and visualizations.+Character customization, which allows you to really mix up how you play.+Amazing story, dialogue, and cinematics.+Good length campaign which has great replay value.+Puzzles, secrets, and mysteries around every corner.+Large variety of weapons which allow you to destroy enemies in all sorts of ways.+Boss fights and arena battles which keep you on your toes and constantly striving for greatness.+Battle scoring, each battle is rated out of five shuriken and bonus XP is offered based on your score.  Cons:-Sadly you must dash before you can sprint which sometimes results in flying off a slant in the ground and dying, which normally you would just run down. -You may want to have a keyboard than offers high level multi-key press support, because the combat can be very pressing (haha) and can result in a lot of commands being sent from your keyboard at one time.

content:
Posted: April 6
												I just finished my first playthrough on this game. Took me around 16h with cutscenes (no skipping) and the occassional secret here and there on insane difficulty.There's another difficulty available that i didn't try, don't know if it was available at the start or after first playthrough. It's more difficult then insane and removes checkpoints and quicksaving. You have to beat each level on one playthrough which takes about 1 hour per chapter and might really be difficult on certain levels.Total of 17 Chapters.It's a pretty bloody game with lots and lots of dismemberment. The story is actually good and enjoyable. Artwork and Artstyle are good looking and it's a very good looking game too, considering it's age. Performance on my a10-7850k with 8 gb ram, ssd and 270x 2gb vram configuration was absolutely good. no framedrops or slowdowns, not a single crash. nice and fluid 60 fps all the time (i capped it there).Pros:- good visual style- bloody and gory- good story- very fluid gameplay- fun- lots of difficulty settings- new game+ mode (ex mode, you keep your skills and weapons except for the absolutely uber katana you get before the last boss)- killer, heavy metal rabbits from hellCons:- chaotic and messy near the end (lots of enemies etc)- a bit repetitive, especially at the end- boss fights work all the same (shoot shiny spot to expose weakness, shoot spot)- last boss was a chore. not difficult or anything but annoying and taking longer then i enjoyed fighting it.If you like bloody and gory katana/weapon carnage with a good story and nice artstyle. Get it, play it, enjoy it.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												"Killing is easy, giving a‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•is hard" - Lo WangShadow warrior is an FPS game with very dynamic, fast and action packed gameplay, First of all, what you really may enjoy in this product is unique and fresh katana combat: there are plenty of moves and special abilities, that can be utilize while wielding this weapon. Plus, additional powers and skills, that can help you in your stylish crusade against demons. Secondly, the plot and characters. Protagonist is a hitman with good sense of humour, that must redeem his honour and save the world at the same time. Nothing new here, actually, but the story makes up because of main hero and his comments on what happens throughout the game. And finally, the bad thing. Combat getting repetitive and boring at second part of the game. The problem is, that there are 18 chapters, if I remember correctly, and, surprisingly, this whole massacre that you will be doing at first with smile on your face and that I praised before gets annoying with time. You see, a game with such insane and action packed gameplay cannot be entertaining and long at the same time without any cool stuff reserved for late game. And Shadow Warrior, unfortunately, lacks that stuff for second part of your journey.Conclusion:If you like good and fast FPS - buy it, but better on sale. If you play that kind of genre occasionally, you should pass this  one by.Gameplay and katana combat +Characters and plot +Graphics +Game is too long for that kind of genre- Combat may get repetitive and boring with time for someone -In the end, I would give that game 7/10 on the Wang meter.

												What a solid product we have here. Pretty much loved it from start to finish. *Some of the best first person melee combat out there*Extremely vivid visuals the entire campaign*Honestly funny, yet immature dialog. Hoji cracks me up.*The devs recently updated the game with 64bit and DX11 support, which made the game run like a dream for me.*Very lengthy campaign with a good variety of environments, enemies, equipment, abilities, etc.*Retro FPS sensibilities that are sorely lacking in today's genre.*A ninja star to a semi-truck's windshield makes the whole damn thing explode.*Easily satiates anyone's Wang quotient.I can't think of many gripes. I suppose some basic multiplayer or coop modes would have been nice. It does have a New Game + mode, should you want to earn every upgrade for Wang that you couldnt afford the first time through. After the new patch, the only technical issue I had was the cutscenes, which are rare, all played only from my center speaker on my 5.1 setup.Considering how insanely cheap this game is on sale, I insist that every steam user own it. The devs deserve more attention for this one.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2014
												This game is an absolute blast!  I'll admit I've never been the biggest fan of the original Shadow Warrior (Though it had some fun moments) but truly this game is barely related to the original Shadow Warrior outside of the fact that the protagonist is a wisecracking sword wielding badass named Lo Wang (Who is thankfully much, much less annoying and racist than his 90s counterpart), there's a corporation named Zilla, and it's an FPS.  I do hesitate calling it a true "Old school" shooter as I kind of take issue with modern games thinking that old school FPS games were all horde based games where you'd progress to another horde that spawns in legions before moving on.  I suppose you could call it old school in attitude though, but otherwise it's more of a modern arcadey-horde shooter in the vein of Serious Sam or Painkiller, but either way it doesn't matter - all that matters is that this game is good, gory fun.  If you want a great looking, hard hitting, bloody, nasty, violent and challenging shooter that doesn't take itself serious then get this game!

												This game is fun to play...for a short while.  After the first few chapters, you'll realize that you've seen just about everything the game has to offer.  The combat is boring once you come to understand that you'll be fighting the same enemies over and over and over.  It's difficult to take a strategic approach to the combat as most foes simply materialize out of thin air.  The time and place for encounters are also predictable.  If you find a large, unoccupied room, expect the enemies to start materializing any second.  The developers could have knocked this one out of the park.  The weapons are fun to use and the special powers are nice also.  It's just the variation that is lacking.If the price was around $5, it would be worth a look.

content:
Posted: February 19, 2015
												Let me just add my positive review to the pile...Frankly I'm surprised the metacritic rating is so low for Shadow Warrior. It's a well-polished game with very nice graphics, good game-play, interesting combat that rewards not spamming the same technique all the time, has a really nice and emotionally involving story (that ending!), includes Easter eggs referring to the original game for nostalgia (and refers to other popular games too), and it somehow balances a line between being ludicrously cheesy (try to keep count of how many Wang puns there are, or better yet: take a drink every time there is a Wang joke!) and being somewhat self-deprecating because they know how stupid it is, but for Shadow Warrior to not have Wang jokes and over the top cliche'd settings would just not be Shadow Warrior.This is how you breathe new life into a game franchise. Other devs should take notes on this game, because there's a lot of childhood favourites that I would like to see get this kind of treatment.Edit: I bought the special edition because I love Hotline Miami, and really it wasn't worth the extra money, even on sale. I'm not sure what I expected with that promo sword, but it's just not worth it. Definitely buy the standard edition.10/10 would play with Wang again (hur hur hur).

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												So many great memories with the first shadow warrior, many years ago, heh.Well, putting my nostalgia away i will try to make a short review on this one.They wanted to create something modern, but not very modern.They wanted to create something classic, but not that classic.Did they achieve their goal? Hell YeaThis wasn't meant to be something very unique, not at all, they wanted to make a modern sequel to the original game, they've done it well.Graphics, damn good.Gameplay, even more damn good.Combat system, awesome.You have a katana, and you have lots of weapons (just like in the old one), but to be honest, who would play with fire weapons in a game where you have a melee weapon? Heh. But it's nice they've added them. I didn't use them too much, only to fight bosses. I didn't use fire weapons to kill flying demons, i was just throwing my katana.The feeling when you slice a demon.. is priceless.It has around 10 hours of gameplay, Actually, i even forgot that i had the sledgehammer from Serious Sam 3, and other nice melee weapons, since i've got the special edition, aaaand, i've finished the game. I really got caught up by it.I really recommend this to any Shadow Warrior 3D Fan, or to any nostalgic guy. This game is really worth the money. I am very happy with this one, and i am waiting for future sequels.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2013
												The further and further I get into the game, recommending it gets harder. The combat is fantastic, combining swordplay and faceshooting by rewarding the player for killing groups of enemies in convoluted, awesome fashions. Lighting a group of enemies on fire and then decapitating them all is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing awesome! However, around hour five is when things start sliding into ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ville, because that's when the enemies with glowing weak spots appear to destroy the momentum by being a trope of gaming that sucks. Hour ten is when the writing shines, and by that I mean the game overstays its welcome while trying to wrap up its overwritten, boring story with nothing new to offer. It's still better than the original by a wide margin!

content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Oh God, what a disappointment. The original Shadow Warrior is one of my most favourite games and hearing all them people masturbating each other with the 2013 Shadow Warrior by Flying Wild Hog being a "true iteration", "real old-school" shooter, I thought that it's a sure bet to get it. Jesus Christ, this game is so disappointing it gave me the biggest blue balls ever. From trailers and quick glimpses at some short gameplay videos I thought I will indeed get a somewhat classic shooter. Hardly. It's a game trying to be a classic shooter, but not doing the most basic thing required from the 1st gen fps game - a proper level design. It's a Painkiller of 2013, which had the same problem.The level design in this game and everything involved (weapon pacing, resource management, combat) sucks. It sucks so much, that there's no reason at all to play this game more than the first few levels, because every single level in the game is the same. A corridor - an arena that limits you in space, where a fight accurs - a dialogue and tedious looting for cash. Rinse and repeat. Yawn. It has nothing to do with anything that made the original a classic game. I've played, like 8 hours now, and every single level (except the Gozu fight) was exactly the same. Run in circles and shoot HP bloats (and I do mean HP BLOATS). After the few first arenas it grew old to me. I can't push myself to finish it, although I really wanted to like this game.The terrible gun-play and wild design decisions don't help, either. For the first few hours we're stuck with a powerful katana sword and an useless revolver, a weak‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•handling smg you have no reason at all to use. Later you get a crossbow that covers half of the screen, and much, much later you get a shotgun that's basically useless against hordes of enemies you encounter. I've just put my hand on a rocket launcher that covers, like, 2/3 of the screen. What? I didn't even use it in the fight that took place right after I had picked it. Ah, there's a flamethrower you won't ever use. Every weapon except the katana with its combos feels underpowered, because every single enemy is a massive HP bloat. You will put many, many, many magazines and rockets into a single warlord. There're no tactics, no resource management, no real level play involved due to combat pattern that follows a simple "lock a player in an arena and spawn enemies". Secrets are mostly useless cash bonuses and Karma bonuses (in-game currency for passive and active skills) with occasional cheap nostalgia gimmicks. They don't benefit you in a way original's secrets used to (you can get a granade launcher 30 seconds into the first level). In 2013 version you have nothing.And there are your Ki powers. A simple katana combos are pretty neat. For first three times you use them. But the healing power is just a game-breaking issue. You can heal up yourself up to above 100 HP after investing karma into passive HP skills. You can get second winds, enrages after getting below 30 HP, etc. There's no suspense, no challange at all in this game. Only tedious gunplay versus HP bloated enemies.I don't think you could miss more with making a true Shadow Warrior game than Flying Wild Hog did with their game.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Shadow Warrior stands as a testament to the fps genre that just because a series is old doesnt mean a person cant fill it with nice things and make a damn respectable game. this isnt your big brothers shaodw warrior, or your daddies. this is a modern take on what shadow warrior can be if given the tools and accessibility we have available in current era fps's and its the nail in the coffin for mainstream fps sp experiences. i shudder to think about picking up another call of duty or battlefield for their singleplayer or any other franchise that gets totted around a lot.you play lo wang. a comic book collector hired by a rich buisnessman to claim an old sword from another collector. however things quickly fall apart as the demons from another plane of existence start spilling through the gaps in soace and time. and very quickly you are left to pickup the pieces, complete the sword, defeat those who would use the blade for evil, and close their path to the human worldvisually the game is done well enough that their is little to complain, though i felt that at times lighting was relatively poor and your flashlight was not suited well for the task of illuminating anything. shadows on water, and destructible environments and enemies are awesome. other things like cloth and glass are also good. simply put flying wild hogs have made an above average visual game considering this is an old cryengine revision they are dealing with here.the audio is also good. this feels lively and banter between the main characters can be funny or make u stop and comment yourself at times. but there are some parts where it falls a little flat or dull and their are some cliche moments but for everyone one of those their is normally a stereotype breaker and those often elft me feeling that maybe those down moments werent so bad after all. i can look past these faults, you might not.combat.. where should i start. to put an analogy out there if CoD and battlefield are considered the pinnacle of fps combat; this is a cut above. simply put their is few games released on pc that have the other qualities this game does that do combat as well or slightly worse. the list is small i could probably riddle them off with one hand after thinking about it. the katana is your melee weapon and you have a variety of ranged weapons as well. all of which feel fun and exciting and encourage experimentation and have something for everyone. i myself found a lot to like in the sub machine guns and flamethrower. but others may enjoy the shotgun or rocket launcher more. to each their own and their is enough to spread the love.level design is flawless, this is where shadow warrior feels the msot true to self with homages and references to the origional game by 3d realms, and lots of multi-pathing around areas, this makes the corridor shooter aspects of the game feel less confined and encourage you to go back and grab extra ammo or search for secret rooms or collectibles. and for this it gets an applause.no for some downsides. at launch this game had lots of crash bugs. these have since been msotly rectified and for that the developers have my thanks, made the game more enjoyable. the games weapons also feel very udnerpowered at times. you will be left wanting more from your guns relying more on your sword to kill foes and this after a while takes the fun out of using what is perhaps its most novel weapon. furthermore some may see their use of rooms again and again in alter levels as lazy or poor taste. i dont see it that way but your welcome to think what you want.all in all i highly recommend this game and strongly suggest that if you want to feel like your playing a first person shooter again and not having your hand held through a corridor while you grip an M4 with tired franchise one liners and cliche fight sequences passing by you. BUY THIS GAME, dont wait for a sale BUY IT NOW! lo wang reaches out and touches 5 hearts.. out of 5 XXXXX/XXXXX

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2013
												A incredible fun game, with a lot of focus on Sword fighting and just gernerally murdering stuff. You get a Katana as your first weapon, and i personally found it to be the most fun to use. You get a lot of the normal old-school FPS weapons (SMG, Pistol, Rocket launcher, Crossbow etc.) But they all felt very stiff. But they're not the interesting part of this gime.You have 3 things you can upgrade, your skills, powers, and weapons. Skils are for stuf like more health, faster run speed, new katana abilities, Something that a normal person would be able to develop generally. Then there is the powers. 4 different in total. They are all executed by doing a movement key twice then right-click (Movement key twice + left click is for the katana skills). This might seem difficult at first, but it actually works really well, and gives you easy access to all your abilities. My favorite personally, was the flux. By Pressing S twice, and then right-click, you would charge up your first. When you released right-click, it would throw a long line into the ground, that would lift enemies up in the air for several seconds. Its amazing using the flux, then blowing someones head off with a shotgun.The enemies are a bit weird though.They're mostly Demons.Not a concept i enjoyed too much, but you find a few human enemies in some sections too. The demons all have specific abilities, and there are major and minor.The minor are the ones you might be able to slash to pieces in one or few hits, while the major can take a while to kill.Of the minor demons, we have your usual run and hit you zombie. The radioactive that explode when you get near or shoot them. The shielders and the invisibles.The shielders has to be the enemy i dreaded the most, not only do they block your attacks, they keep looking in your direction and you have to either throw them down, or hit the shield until it breaks. It can take a while and really breaks the flow of the game, when you're spinning around and killing litearlly everybody around you, except for them.Of the major enemies, there are 3: The Warlord, The Charger, and the Shaman. The major are a bit more interesting, so i'll talk about them.The shaman will summon and resurrect nearby enemies, and just keep doing this until you kill him. After hes around halfway dead, he will create a green unbreakable barrier, and summon some skeletons that flash with green colors. After you kill the skeletons, the shield breaks and you can finish him off.The Warlord will enrage nearby eneies (Which is, make them darker, and make them more powerful. Enemies can also be enraged if you use abilities or powers near them, even if there isin't a warlord there) He will also try to smash you, a lot. So every few seconds, he will throw a really fast red line, and if you touch it, he will pull you to him, and he will smash the ground.The final one is the charger. Hes simple, and kind of boring to be honest. He will charge you, you evade it near a wall. He hits the wall. You slice his back a few times. Rinse and repeat. It just takes so long to kill these guys, that the fun quickly dies from fighting them.But of all enemies, the most interesting one is the bosses. There are a total of 3 Demon bosses, and they're all amazing to fight. They're HUGE, and the shadow realm is just right-out eyecandy. They are all very Zelda-ish, and its very fun.All in all, if you have ever played Red steel 1 or 2, and enjoyed it. Or just want to enjoy a throwback to the old FPS with a mix of very interesting sword fighting, you should pick this game up.9/10

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												A remake for 1990s classic Shadow Warrior. This game came out of the bushes and all that I  thought about it was going to be no more than more or less okey made successor for some game fossil, but after reading couple of reviews and watching gameplays, I decided to add this to my collection.Shadow Warrior showed me how these prejudices can be anything but right. The game is absolutly magnificent!! The easily mastered mixture of melee and long ranged fighting works better than any game I've played and numerous fighting moves picked from different skill trees quarantee the most entertaining fast, upbeat battles. So, the fighting is smooth and there is a lot of it: tens, even hundreds of enemies fall during one map, filled with several secret places to search for, just like in the original Shadow Warriror, where the game keeps refering to. As for the plot and characters, they are well written - the storyline though is quite typical, but they are the characters which in my opinion hit into the jackpot! Player playes Long Wang, who is an exceptional anti-hero, followed by a companion and sidekick: the demon Hoji, and these two rascals form a couple whose epic conversations I used to crack up so many times.Shadow Warrior is not only one of the biggest surprices of 2013, but also one of the best games in 2013. In addition IMO it's one of the best games ever! So whether you were or not a fan of last milleniums Shadow Warrior, I'm definitely going to recommend to check this out!

												A shining example of a First Person Shooter done right.No wee-wee-spunk-gargle here.All the weapons feel diferent, and no one of them seems ultimately better than another. They all have a good impact as well. And the sword? I pretty much used the sword 99% of the time my first playthrough. It's fantastic. content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
												This game is a really hard to explain... It is a sort of hack'n'slash / first person shooter. All the levels are way more beautiful then I thought they would be. The gameplay feels solid, the tone is serious while keeping it comedic. It has a bunch of references to the first shadow warrior that I played a bit back when I was younger such as almost naked pixel girls bathing  scattered through the land and rabbits that wont stop ****ing. They give you a lot of options to customize the game, Almost everything in the environment is intractable and can be destroyed and I have yet to find any problems or bugs other than the frame rate problem that is noted below.Before buying this game there are some things you should note: 1. The game somewhat makes fun of chinese culture. Not as much as the first one though. 2. It is somewhat of a gore fest as you chop people in half with your katana. 3. MOST IMPORTANT this game has frame rate issues. I tend to think my PC is fairly good. It can run most games at a solid 60fps and if not turning of shadows or vsync would help. But no matter what I do I cant get this game to run any higher than 30~45fps. After looking around it seems you need a somewhat beast computer to make it run smoothly due to some issue I didn't look into much. So if you have a Xbone or PS4 I would recommend buying it on one or the other, But if you have a good PC go for it.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2014
												Maybe one of the biggest surprises in the year 2013. Most people didn't had this on their plan. Shadow Warrior is a complete breath of fresh air in the shooter genre and thank god it proves that the shooter genre on the PC is not dead yet, but let's start from the beginning. What is good: Shadow Warrior is Flying Wild Hogs interpretation of the original Shadow Warrior. I must admit those guys are perfect when it comes to shooters on PC (they proved their awesome work with Hard Reset earlier). Just when you think there is no more hope for shooters FWH releases the second piece of software to show the world what shooters are made of. Positive to mention is that the difficulty is more moderate than in Hard Reset which was really challenging. The dialogs are very good and fun to listen to. Maybe not everyone's taste but definitely funny. Secrets are placed across the levels which are fun to find since they are kept in retro look. What is great: - The engine is amazing. Playing this game on ultra settings making the game a blast. IMO the engine seems to be scaleable and seems pretty good optimized since I'm able to run the game on lower settings on an older PC. - It's the first game where a melee weapon can be so much fun to fight with. While in other games melee weapons have a limited range and low damage values. the Katana in Shadow Warrior is very powerfull and fun to fight with and gets upgraded with special abilities which makes it a blast to use. What is awesome: the complete game is very well balanced. Sometimes I have the feeling that the Katana is a bit too powerfull compared with the other weapons what makes the game more fun to play instead of destroying anything. The great engine, the funny character(s) with its amusing dialogs, the very good level design and non-stop action make this game a great FPS in a genre where "looking through an irogn sight" dominate.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 20, 2014
												I have enjoyed this game WAY more than any other single player FPS I have played. The sheer amount of power you feel while playing as Lo Wang is just great.There's a lot of nuance to its experience that most reviewers fail to mention. Now maybe it's better if you are surprised by them once you play the game;however...IF you're on the fence and want to know what makes this game STAND OUT..., THEN keep reading.**ONE story-related SPOILER AHEAD, but it is something you find out in the first chapter**(it's the 3rd '+')*******************************************************************+GREAT for relieving stress+can chop off enemy's leg just to watch him hop around and grab his leg in pain (each enemy is sliced n' diced exactly how it should be, with directional slices)+have this 'spirit' ally with you & it talks to you throughout the game (with comedic results)+/- it's an arena shooter, meaning you will kill a group of enemies, then explore/relax until you run into the next batch+can heal yourself with a magical skill (heals up to 60% of your max hp, but can be upgraded to more)- a few of the chapters are too long IMO (3 or 4 chapters took ‚âà2 hrs to complete)- no co-op or multi-player+are secret items to collect in every level+well balanced enemies/combat+can simultaneously do magic in one hand and use weapon in the other. oh yeah!20-23 hours to complete (story mode)for most people, but took me 25 hrs. in-game timeEdit 1:fixed typosEdit 2: After beating the game, I edited the line about "a few of the chapters [being] too long..."Edit 3: added approx. time to complete campaignEdit 4: took out "I love this game!" so you don't think I'm totally biased. & added more explanation of the 'slicing and dicing' mechanics of this game under the pros & cons section

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Despite its old-school aspect Shadow Warrior manage to add something different to the FPS genre: swordplay! Drop your gun and draw your katana! A real warrior should rely on his melee weapon and not on his long range weapons. The humor in Shadow Warrior is full of pop culture content! Don't take this game too seriously! This game was made for pure enjoyment! If you want more old-school action FPS after Serious Sam BFE pick this one up! The game doesn't include multiplayer but don't worry. For 40$ you will get at least 15 hours of gameplay if you crank up the difficulty to the maximum. In the FPS field this game lenght is almost inexistant. Boss fights are memorable as they are humongous. Don't forget to add up replayability as you can unlock more skills more powers!Rating:9.0

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												A extremely fun game with beautiful graphics, atmosphere and detailed world. One of the best games I have played in a long time. The combat is so much fun, slashing and destroying with your katana and powers, you have the ability to destroy almost everything around you. I prefer mostly using the katana, I find it much more fun than using guns which almost feel pointless as they don't seem as strong, effective or fun as the katana.  It has quite a good story line with amusing dialogue from Wang, upgradable weapons, powers and skills and hidden things to find for those who take the time to explore thoroughly.The only thing I didn't like is that you have to double tap a direction then hold and release lmb or rmb to use a katana ability or power which makes it feel a bit slow to execute.This game is a definite must play  I give it a rating of 8/10.

												Probably the most enjoyable first person action game (not saying shooter, because it has fantastic katana) of 2013.It's not just that it has incredibly satisfying both melee (with kombos and amazing enemy dismemberment) and shooting mechanics, full of upgrades, or that it has a KI magic moves as well, and plenty of character progression. No, what surprised me the most, is that this silly, crazy looking (and playing) game also has a wonderfully funny (and at proper times touching) story, with some of the best "buddy movie" style banter I have ever seen in a game.Oh and don't get me started on the shotgun. Oh, the shotgun. After you upgrade it, it is the most satisfying shotgun you will ever shoot.As far as technical stuff is concerned - I played entire game on GTX560Ti with x360pad, connected to 55" TV, and it was a grand experience. Played perfectly and suffered zero bugs or crashes.Click on that buy icon, now.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
 Positive + The sword gameplay is simply a blast; the gore effects especially make sure that chopping up enemies is always satisfying+ The upgrade system enhances both sword and gun gameplay, as well as giving a large variety of ways to give slight improvements to your character+ Graphics are very well detailed, including both gorgeous backgrounds and high quality textures, without a single drop in frame rate+ Manages to effectively capture the charm of the original game and Lo Wang himself (minus the racism), including many comedic references to the original game and pop-culture in general+ Lengthy campaign for a modern first-person shooter (approximately 10 hours on Normal difficulty), with interesting characters and a neat little story making sure to keep you entertained until the end. Negative - The guns seem lacking in firepower for the most part (especially the submachine gun); the sword gameplay completely overshadows it. Verdict ‚ÄúEasily the best FPS from 2013, and one of my all-time favourites. The extensive swordplay alone makes the game fun and memorable enough, as well as the character Lo Wang reinstating his place in the modern era of gaming. If you‚Äôre a fan of first-person shooters or games in general, I‚Äôd highly recommend it.‚Äù 8.5/10 TJBs

content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
												Just finished playing and I have to say the game was great!  9/10.  There was only 1 or 2 areas that felt like a bad case of plot-itus driving Lo Wang to do something that I thought was off.  But otherwise it was a fantastic FPS kill/slash/maim experience.  The backdrop storyline and 8 bit Easter eggs were an appreciated extra.  If you played and beat the 1st game then this is going to knock your socks off, if you didn't then this might entice you play the first one.  As for level design and graphics I thought they were solid, it wasn't one of those hey lets update an 80's / 90's game with cool graphics so you spend 100 years going through endlessly huge levels that compensated for bad graphics back in the day.  There were a couple environmental's that were a little weak in design or rendering but the lighting is the best hands down I have seen for a FPS (Splinter Cell does not count in that genre).Get the game you will enjoy it!

												This game is a legitimately cool FPS in the style of old. Linear level design, but great design with loads of secrets hidden inside them. content:
Posted: July 25, 2014
												This game has so much to offer.  I will point out the only thing that could have made it better for me is a few additional monster types, however, the way the game is setup, you can dispose of them in many different ways and I can see where each enemy would involve a lot of animations and coding.  The enemies exhibit a good of moves that change the pace around and are very detailed, as is the whole game really.  I took as many screenshots in this game as I did with games like STALKER and METRO because I was just in awe.  It also features a very unique to FPS system of being able to upgrade your weapons as well as passive and active abilities and sword attacks that all have there own relation to dispatching various enemies.  The story is fun but features a great skip scene option for those of us that don't wish to watch it all.  The developers put their heart and soul into this game, it is fun, exciting, beautiful and unique.  A rare combination to find these days.  I rate it a 95%.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												pros: great visuals & graphic options, epic soundtrack & sound effects, interesting characters with great voice acting, satisfying & visceral melee combat, varied abilities & skill tree, great humor especially the fortune cookies, visual changes when upgrading weapons, scoring after combat incentivizes the player to vary his/her attacks, you get faster upgrades/money/ammo from finding hidden loot which incentivizes the player to explore the map, plenty of easter eggs & references, massive boss battles (although I would of liked some innovation), quick save/load & frequent checkpoints, score attack mode & other modes for replayabilitycons: parts of the game arbitrarily cap the fps at 30, lacking borderless windowed mode, linear map progression (not expansive enough for my fancy), skyboxes doesn't look as good as the rest of the game, invisible walls & instant death when stepping into certain water areas (although some water you can step on without dying - it's trial & error to know if what you are stepping on is safe or not...), hitboxes are wonky & sometimes unresponsive (shotgun doesn't even work on boss weakpoints), obligatory turret sections, story & ending could of been implemented better Overall, Shadow Warrior (2013) does a great job with reinterpreting the original 3D Realms classic (can't say the same for DNF). I found the katana combat way more satisfying than the gunplay, although how you build your character is entirely up to you. The combat, cast of characters, & the amount of humor kept me interested in progressing through the game, and playing it all the way through to the end was well worth the time! Shadow Warrior has my highest recommendation, a must play especially for fans of the classic!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2013
												Shadow Warrior is a really smart game. The writing is geniunely well done, groan inducing when it wants to be, funny when it wants to be, and awesome when it wants to be. Lo Wang is a character that I didn't expect to have any kind of growth, but the story and character arcs in this game were surprisingly big hooks for me as I played further in.Of course, the big draw is how well it does combat. SW paces the introduction of new mechanics and weapons at a steady enough rate that just when you've gotten a pretty good understanding of how one works, and maybe even sunk an upgrade or two into one, you'll have a new toy to play with. These toys range from new sword attacks you personally choose from your Karma based skill tree, Chi based abilities, not all of which are offensve, from your Dark Ki Crystal (Collectible items found in the world) based skill tree, or new parts and alternate fire modes for you guns that you flat out purchase from the gun menu. All these menus and trees are accessed at any time  by just pressing U, so quickly adding to your arsenal is never an issue.The Katana is powerful, but not to the point where it renders other weapons obsolete right out the gate. That being said, players who take advantage of the games skill and abilitiys being mapped as they are will find they can probably play through SW without firing a shot, if they so desire. Sword skills are performed by hitting two direction keys and then holding M1 to charge the attack, where as Chi abilities are done the same, but with M2. Keeping in mind just how good the swordplay feels, and those systems interact with each other beautifully.If the idea of Bulletstorm with traditional old-school FPS weapons (and a crossbow, katana, and magic), with character progression that immediately affects the gameplay sounds appealing to you, Shadow Warrior is your game.

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
												A game that re-imagines 90‚Äôs classic, and though it changed the angle in humour a bit, it is a great successor. Gameplay-wise it is FPS with added fairly developed swordplay mechanics (but don‚Äôt expect much, it is a roller coaster not instructional course), some RPG elements allowing you to develop skills of your character, ki powers, and weapons.Level design is quite OK, neither linear nor too free to roam. Though some of the secrets are just ‚Äúwalk around the corner‚Äù and others are ‚Äúknow where to turn back or door behind you closes and you can never get secret that only became available when you stopped through it‚Äù, both of which aren‚Äôt too much fun.Enemies AI is sufficiently complex, but I am easily satisfied with just the amount of them, though there were couple of battles with ridiculously many waves of enemies and insufficient ammunition.Story has some strength, meaningfulness and depth, overall look is painting-like good, music is quite OK. So, while having some flaws here and there, the game gave me some 20 fun hours.P.S. And also thanks to this one the original ‚ÄúShadow Warrior‚Äù got re-released on Steam. Go get it, too.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
												This Re-interpretation of the classic 1997 shooter actually pleasantly suprised me in several ways in just how good it is.The combat system for a start is immensely satisfying, The sword combat is implemented so well that along with chivalry it's the most fun i've had doing first person melee combat.Guns are also really fun to use thanks to the dismemberment of all enemy limbs in the game as well as some of the more unique weapons from the original game such as the enemy heart and head.The graphics are relatively eye pleasing featuring a lot of colour, rich texture quality and a nice variety of environments to explore in, although monotony does set in at times through either the same type of environment repeating themselves too many times (Enough of the damn Bamboo Forests) or a level going on for too long.The plot was also somewhat suprising in how intriguing it was and the characters are funny/interesting enough to not be annoying, it's also a decent sized game at around a dozen hours and you can get plenty of replay value maxing out all of the characters abilites and unlocking all of his skills.So in summary as long as you don't expect a true remake of the original shooter you should have a blast playing this and for me this was one of the best shooters of 2013.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 18, 2013
												non-ironically one of the best FPS games ever.  Pick up if you like FPS games and have a pulse.It does melee combat better than any FPS prior to it, including Zeno Clash.  The combat is viceral, bloody, and rewarding, the upgrades are good and worthwhile.  Bulletstorm's rewarding-stylish killing mechanism makes a partial return, giving you more karma to upgrade for combat mastery.The main and support character are both well written for what they are, and this is geniuinely one of the funniest games I've played in a long time.The only downsides are that there is something of a lack of enemy variety after a certain point, but the game more than stands up for itself regardless.Also I wouldn't recommend playing on a difficulty higher than normal, it kind of makes enemies into bullet sponges.  I'd have preferred a difficulty that made enemies do more damage than take a shitzillion bullets to kill, but regardless, it's not really a problem.All in all, if you're a fan of the FPS genre, you owe it to yourself to play this unique gem of a game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												‚ÄúYou‚Äôve got Wang!‚ÄùThat‚Äôs right folks, Lo Wang returns in Shadow Warrior, a reimagining of 3D Realms‚Äô classic FPS. Flying Wild Hogs has re-created another old-school shooter in a generation where many AAA shooters have evolved to eschew health packs for health regeneration while focusing on big, grandiose set pieces. Shadow Warrior bucks the current trend by having health packs, linear gameplay, and smaller scripted events.As Wang, a corporate agent for Zilla Enterprises, I was sent to broker a deal for the Nobitsura Kage ‚Äì an ancient sword. However the deal went south and I suddenly found myself enfolded into a story filled with dark and mystical forces while trying to recover the sword. No longer was I fighting just human thugs, but demonic minions too; all with a spirit sidekick. And while the story might start out simply enough, by the end the scope broadens.But don‚Äôt let me fool you into thinking that this is a completely somber story. True to the classic game the re-make contains a lot of humor that kept me smiling and laughing as I played. From the dialogue, quips from Wang, and even the fortune cookies I picked up, I had a lot of fun from beginning to end. I‚Äôd have to agree with a particular cookie that read, ‚ÄúA Wang in the hand is worth two in the bush.‚ÄùTo read the rest of my review visit Press2Reset: http://press2reset.com/reviews/review-shadow-warrior/

content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												Fantastic game. I didn't like Hard Reset all that much (it had good ideas, but overall gameplay was really badly put together) and did not expect Shadow Warrior 2013 to be any good. I expected it to be way too "modern" or misunderstanding why mid-90s FPS games were good. But the game turned out to be a pleasant surprise.It is, probably, the best modern reinterpretation of the oldschool FPS, as I liked it. Not just a linear gorefest with arenas, but a much more diverse, fantastically looking FPS with pretty huge levels and one of the best first person blade combat systems ever. Genuinly fun humor, good old one-liners, fantatic mix of the old health pack and manual regenaration healing systems, unexpectedly good storyline, fun to find secrets... In many ways, this is what should have been done with Duke Nukem Forever, if developers of that game wanted to "modernise" it.Wang out of wang. Would wang again.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												I really enjoyed this game quite a bit. I've played some of the original Shadow Warrior, which I have mixed feelings about (the main downsides to it, for me, were the incredibly immature humor and the sometimes cheap level/enemy design). This game however, I think is in a league of its own. Story-wise, I actually thought this was pretty enjoyable for what it is. At times it felt sort of like a Suda 51 game, with regard to how crazy the story/combat could get, and the massive number of‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•jokes. The humor is still irreverent and silly, but for the most part I found it much more clever and amusing than the original's. I also loved the old-school over-the-top action of this game's combat; there's a lot of projectile-dodging, and combat in general is focused on being very agile and getting into the fray, rather than hanging back behind cover and taking pot-shots at enemies. I also like the way regenerating health is handled; it's not automatic, so you have to initiate it yourself, and it never fully heals your health meter, so there is an incentive to not get hurt, and to find med packs around the level.One thing I... didn't necessarily dislike, but wish could have been handled a little differently, is the integration of combat into the game's levels; most levels fall into a formula of moving through an unpopulated area, finding chests filled with money and ammo and the like (with some secrets if you take the time to explore, though it's never essential), then getting into what is essentially a combat arena, where you fight hordes of enemies. I personally would have liked to see more opportunities to engage in combat that wasn't arena-focused; perhaps having enemies sneak up on you from behind as you're exploring, or having to fight enemies while traversing platforms? It also would have been nice to have some traps to maneuver around, as well as more mazelike environments/puzzles; I feel those aspects of old-school design would have been nice to see. As it is, this game feels sort of like an arcadey beat-em-up in first-person, with sections clearly marked for combat standing in sharp contrast to sections marked for exploration; which isn't necessarily a bad thing, but I wish more variety with regard to level design could have been done. Some of the environments look amazing, but for the most part the actions you do when traversing them don't really switch themselves up much.Overall, I do think of this as being a great game, though it's worth noting this is not exactly a classic-style FPS, despite definitely taking some influence from them. If you can accept that, then this is definitely worth playing.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												Shadow Warrior is a modernized retelling of the classic 3DRealms shooter from 1997. It features the ninja protagonist "Lo Wang" on his journey to retrieve an ancient sword after hell breaks loose in the city. It features beautiful asian landscapes, plenty of demons to kill and first person swordplay that is actually incredibly fun and innovative. Oh, and there are guns, but who wants to use those? The raunchy humor and blatant stereotypes of the original have been significantly toned down for this remake which might be disappointing to some hardcore fans such as myself.THE GOOD+Swordplay is fantastic+Secrets are fun to find+Upgradable Weapons & skills+Enviroments are beautiful & amazingly detailed+Cute little references to the original game+The soundtrack is actually really good+Campaign is a satisfying lengthTHE BAD-Unless the jokes are coming from a fortune cookie, they usually fall flat.-Guns dont really have much kick to them.-Story was kind of hard to follow (at least for me)-Protagonist seems bland compared to the original-Objectives and enemys become repetitive after a whileTHE UGLYBunnies ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing eachother (Don't ask)BOTTOM LINEShadow Warrior does a damn good job at what it aims to do, from the superb sword fighting to the amazing enviroments. Despite the fact the game can become repetitive at times, it dosent subtract from the fun you can have here.PROTIP: I recommend playing with the HUD and Crosshairs off for maximum immersion. :)Recommended: 7/10

content:
Posted: March 17, 2014
												I did not expect a remake for a classic such as Shadow Warrior. But after their cyberpunk FPS, Hard Reset, Flying Wild Hog decided to keep the old school shooter formula and use a more recognisable name. I like how the game does not take itself seriously - while the story is somewhat serious (suddenly demons appear out of nowhere) it does not stop our protagonist, Lo Wang, from delivering one-liners here and there (usually, after a successful slicing up of an enemy). Even the conversations he has with his companion make you smile and some of the references to other products of the entertainment industry can be hilarious. In the golden era of FPS games melee combat was uninteresting. In fact, after a level or two the melee weapon was never used again. Shadow Warrior used an equally weak weapon in the form of a katana and this is what the remake keeps; in fact, with the abilities and upgrades the player can acquire later on this weapon becomes even more useful. Also, while the rest of the arsenal consists of the usual firearms (submachine guns, shotgun, grenade launcher etc.) this array of weapons is also upgradable so here you also have some nice surprises - in order to have all upgrades and skills in place you need to finish the game once more in new game plus mode.Hard Reset was rather repetitive. Both the environment and the tasks you needed to carry out remained pretty much the same throughout the story. Shadow Warrior employs different surroundings each time and with the scripted events and various tasks you have the desired variety at hand throughout your quest. And while the game was not developed as an AAA title some of the levels can be jaw-dropping. The music accompanying your missions is equally good. Then of course you have a lot of collectibles and dozens of achievements.Shadow Warrior is one of the best old school style FPS games out there. The developer support is also commendable - they do listen to you and ever since its release date last September they have kept upgrading the game and constantly fixing any issues players encounter. Thumbs-up!

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
												After a great Hard reset of flying wild hog came time for Shadow Warrior. Original released in 1997. I have not played the original so I will not be compared. But I will try to say something about the new version. You can see similar arrangement as in HR. Sprint, fight,bosses and different functions weapons. However, in my opinion, HR is a better game from Flying Wild Hog. But let's get to the meat. The graphics are good but uneven. Picturesque locations delight the eye and not once can admire the work of graphic designers. But up close the graphics are not so great. No less is fine. I don't play on highest graphics settings. Gameplay is good and fight with katana is very good. To bring a special need such a blow, press 2x W and LMB. When it is mastered can make fun. However, a larger number of different enemies will be easier to use other weapons. At least to me it was easier. Weapons are many but some are not very effective and the feeling of shooting in some of the less impressive. Unfortunately, sometimes the game is frustrating. For me it was for this that some of the levels and enemies were poorly designed.  Level of exploding enemies is terribly weak. A fight with the boss very easy and unsatisfying. The music is atmospheric and the sounds of enemies and weapons are at a good level. The game is not really in my style (kung fu) but I have fun. The story and the main character are fine although his statements are not as funny as Serious Sam or Duke Nukem. Sometimes they are childish and not funny. The game has a lot of easter eggs and funny moments like Fortune cookies. Some jokes can be understood only did the Poles because the Polish game studio. But it should not be a big problem for other players. The game also has a survival mode but only single so it's a big minus, and does not have a multiplayer mode. In summary. The game is good and I recommend you buy it at some sales. Graphics 8/10 Audio 8+/10 Gameplay 8+/10 Final verdict 7+/10.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												This game easily earns the title for 'Best FPS of 2013'.Hordes of enemies, crazy weapons, cheesy dialog and one-liners...if you, like me, hate modern FPS games and miss the good old days when FPS games actually focused on the First Person Shooting - this is the game for you!The major strength of this game is the Katana gameplay, which turns out to be one of the best - if not the best - implementations of a melee mechanic in an FPS I have ever seen. The sheer enjoyment of slicing enemies to bits will carry you through the entire game.As much as I enjoyed Shadow Warrior, a few drawbacks need to be addressed:1. The Katana, being such an amazing weapon, tends to overshadow the gunplay of the game. The other weapons don't seem to generate the same level of enjoyment, and the game progression system itself seems to encourage the use of the Katana over the guns. As a result, the only shooting I found myself doing in the game was a forced result of the karma rating and the lack of ability to slice up the major bosses. If I could kill the bosses without using the guns - I probably would.2. Not all of the guns are fun to use. Lo Wang's crossbow, in particular, was a disappointment. The gun has no accuracy advantage over other weapons, has a projectile travel time and doesn't seem to provide a stealth element when engaging unaware enemies. As a result, I found myself using it mainly to detonate "mines".3. Some areas in the game seem to lead into a massive frame rate loss, which is something an FPS game should avoid at all costs.In spite of those drawbacks, the game is great fun and definitely a step in the right direction as far as FPS games go.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												Shadow Warrior is a in many aspects successful reimagining of the 3D Realms classic from 1997. In this review I will describe how it holds up in comparison and try to cut right to the chase.The level design isn't quite as open and doesn't offer as many secrets as the original, but you can tell that Flying Wild Hog put a lot of love and work into this project. The combat is extremely fun and satisfying, especially the different katana moves. The weapons are varied, fun to use and none of them feel unneccessary or even useless. The story is fairly cheesy, so I guess you could say they nailed this aspect. Shadow Warrior and a serious story don't mix as far as I'm concerned. The voice acting is great, even though I miss Lo Wang's original voice. The quips are hit and miss, but overall quite funny. What really impresses me about this game is that it feels like an almost perfect blend of "retro" and modern game design. Many developers have aspired to do that and most of them failed. Flying Wild Hog managed to pull it off, which deserves much respect.I've spent about 21 hours on Shadow Warrior and enjoyed it a lot. I'm planning to replay it at some point.Bottom line: If you aren't offended by strong video game violence and dark, sometimes childish humor, you will have a great time with this game!

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												Might contain spoilers. WILL contain parentheses (a lot).When this came out I was furious that someone had the nerve to call a game Shadow Warrior, exactly the same as the 1997 3D Realms title (as you can probably tell from that attitude, I loved that game as a kid). As the negative emotions got weaker (and the price lower) I decided to give it a try and I have to say it does its name justice. The many references to the original game didn't feel forced (and weren't overdone), and paired with modern engine and eyecandy, it was pretty damn awesome. There were some little things mostly associated with it being a 2013 game that I didn't like (certain gameplay mechanics, but mostly a number of things too small to mention), but overall I'd give this like 9/10 if I were to use numbers.Pros:+ Very good melee combat system. The special moves (including a ranged attack) make the sword a viable and even preferrable weapon for most of the game.+ Good engine. Haven't had any problems with hit detection or gamebreaking glitches.+ Nice aesthetics overall. I really liked the 2D cutscenes.+ Different sorts of environment from traditional japanese to modern industrial, topped with some surreal sky landscapes, much like the original game.+ Plentiful throwbacks to the original 1997 Shadow Warrior (either references or parts of SW1997 levels in secrets).Cons:- A little too linear level design in places. A "secret" is something you find if you wander more than ten feet off the beaten path.- Unentertaining bosses. I only played on Normal difficulty so far so this might not be objective, but they felt not-so-challenging, it just takes forever to take them down because of the tedious weak spots.- Most ranged weapons felt meh. Like, I'm already used to unrealistic shotgun spread in games, but holy‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• the shotgun in this has like a 90¬∞ arc spread - no point using it at any range longer than point blank.

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17
												For a video review go here: 


YouTube‚Ñ¢ Video: Shadow Warrior (2013) - PC - Review¬†

			Views: 835		

			YOU NO MESS WITH LO WANG! PvtHudson takes a look at the reboot of the 1997 classic. Available on Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/app/233130/ Support me on Patreon:...		

A text transcript is provided below.Shadow Warrior is a first person shooter released back in 2013 where you run around with a plentiful array of weaponry with something as simple as a sword, to something as powerful as a ‚Äúduke nukem‚Äù launcher, and to something as over the top as giant demon heads.The gameplay is right as rain for this game. All the controls feel smooth and it is perfect for anyone who likes action. With the exception of some occasional puzzles and the drudgery of trying to navigate the hallways of Shadow Warrior with its lack of directional markers to tell you where to go other than making the doorway you need to progress through glow, this game is constant fighting. The first half of the game is very well paced with short 20 to about 30 minute missions where you get to fight through all different sorts of unique areas and meet all the different enemy types. From these weird flying harpy demons, to giant minotaur looking mini bosses, and to rolling exploding green poisonous de monic balls of death. If you're looking for solid first person shooting mechanics and controls, you've found it.The graphics of this game look great for 2013 and still good today! The sounds compliment it all perfectly and there's a lot of things retro for anyone who is coming from the old shadow warrior game that this reboot is based off of. There's plenty of little hidden easter eggs throughout the game that you can find that I personally don't understand since I didn't play the original, but they still made me laugh every time I saw them. One con to note about the graphics though is that when you get up close and start cutting up human enemies, the animations seem to fall apart and appear retro in quality. I'm not sure if that's a feature or bad animation, but its very laughable in its lack of quality amidst the updated look of the game.The story of the game is extremely comical and interesting if not entirely common to advance due to how much action spaces out story segments. It ended on a bit of a serious note which was a bit unsettling though since the game had tried so hard to be funny that a serious ending didn't really feel like it fit. It was however made comical because its the first time a cutscene ever shows your character in third person, where you get to see that they didn't bother rendering your character's head outside of reflections and you get to see yourself sitting there with nothing but a mouth and eyes, no face to to be seen. There's a lot that doesn't get solved in the game though, making it very obvious that there was going to be a sequel since the ending is very unsatisfying and in the end you really don't feel like you accomplished anything.The games pacing is probably the biggest con the game has. While it starts out nicely spread and manageable with up to 30 minute missions‚Ä¶the later missions take 40 to about 50 minutes each which are extremely tiring when some of them don't even give you a cutscene to help advance the story, just some basic comedic dialogue with literally zero story progression. They start packing each level with larger and larger amounts of the same repetitive enemies jumping out at you after every couple of steps and it really just becomes cumbersome to carry on. What's worse is that they even start repeating the levels towards the end. You'll run through the same rooms and hallways more times than you can count with no sight of anything new.There's a very strange delay whenever you hit the U key to upgrade your weapons and skills. It seems to get worse as the game goes on as well, but it either reverted to its original state towards the end or I just got so used to it I stopped noticing it. I'm not sure what the deal with that is but it was very frustrating to start which is why I feel the need to mention it.Overall I definitely recommend Shadow Warrior. Even by today's standards this is still a good game. I give a 7/10. It was fun. It wasn't amazing, but this is probably the first arcadey shooter that pits you against the world with no friendlies and minimal story progression that I actually enjoyed, potentially the first one I've ever finished. Do not buy it for its full $40 price. You'll be paying $4 per hour of gameplay. Wait for it to go on sale, and then definitely pick it up.
