number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												Loved this game from start to finish. Not a single moment in the game let down once, absaloute perfection!Guns are great, good variety of enemies, gameplay is solid and addictive, story is unforgettable and immersive!--[TLDR Warning]--(Longer review)Where to begin...Shadow Warrior has pretty much everything I want and love. The scenery and settings are gorgeous. The gameplay is smooth and fluent throughout and never gets old or boring too quickly. Infact at all. The game doesn't give you any "here's a ridiculous and pointless puzzle as a filler to make the game longer". It's level after level of onslaught, story and exploration. The story is by far the most impressive and best thing about the game. With some games, the story can totally suck and you feel you just want to get through it and finally complete it. But Shadow Warriors story really is unique and different. It keeps on point all the time and doesn't slow down or make the game crap. Having completed the game, the story is absaloutely beautiful. The characters are unforgettable, the weapons are glorious, the melee combat is by far the best swordplay of any game I've played with the feature, and mostly what I love the most - it's a long game!The weapons. The weapons are awesome to use. At first you may notice they feel a bit... weak. But with future upgrades they feel better and look cooler. Your arsenal will build up from a revolver, smg, crossbow to a shotgun, flamethrower, and rocket launcher. But it doesn't stop there - there's an ability to use Demon hearts and heads against foes for a gruesome but fun attack method. If that doesn't settle, there's always the swordplay which you yield gracefully in the face of combat with some amazing and deadly combos!The enemies have some great variety and change the gameplay drastically. You'll fight common lesser demons for nearly all of the game but you'll run into bigger and more challenging foes, all inwhich have different tactics and attack methods making each encounter a new and fresh experience. You'll come across flying demons, sheilded greater demons, beserkers and more. Oh and did I mention the boss fights?! Boss fights are epic, with giant bosses and huge arenas!The gameplay is fun and addicting, when playing through this - I was personally playing it at 4-5 hour sessions. Which I usually don't do with most games. The story cuts in frequently but it never ruins anything good or slows the game down in a bad way. The characters are great and you get a real feel for each characters personality. Filled with quirky humour and some humerous stereotypes, this game is just so good.I highly reccomend Shadow Warrior to fans of swordplay/sword fighting, japanese related culture, or truely awesome FPS action!I rate this game a strong 10/10

content:
Posted: February 1, 2016
												The gameplay in this is old school shooter, basically very little to no cover, lot's of strafing, enemies spawn in large numbers and play by patterns.However, this is old school at it's finest, the most beautifully well written love letter to old school shooters. Lovingly spit polished, this game is smooth, without so much as a mild under the breath burb, let alone hiccup.The graphics are fun and gory, set your sword to advanced in the gameplay options, slice and dice.I'm really looking forward to the sequel and I'm surprised I enjoined the tightly interwoven story line, being a fan of Bioshock, I have high standards for story.The skills tree is interesting and the weapons mods are fun. A bit disorientating for the first few hours, but once the story and the sword absorb you, it's loads of fun.I highly recommend this game, for me a must have.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2014
												Man, this is a tough one.Shadow Warrior is a game that has a lot of things going for it.  The main gameplay mechanic is the swordfighting, which is incredibly satisfying and enjoyable.  The shooting is fun as well, and the game mixes up enemy types in a way where it encourages variety.  Considering these developers have worked on games like Hard Reset and Painkiller, it's not surprising that the game throws tons of enemies at you at any given minute and keeps up a breakneck pace.However, the problem is that the game is 4 hours too long.  It gets to a point where the game runs out of enemy types, and every encounter feels the same.  In addition, a decent amount of the later levels involve a lot of backtracking that feels incredibly unnecessary, like the developers wanted to make a longer game for some reason but didn't have the time or budget to do so.  It got to the point where most encounters just felt like a slog and I just wanted to get it over with.  If this game were 7 or 8 hours long instead of 12, the pacing wouldn't have felt nearly as sloppy.So, having said that, I would recommend this game when it's on sale (I got it for $10), because it CAN be a lot of fun and the developers seem like really cool dudes who care about their fans, but be warned that it really loses steam in the last third of the game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												There was a lot of skepticism surrounding the news that 3D Realms' 1997 shooter Shadow Warrior would be re-imagined for 2013, not least because the original game faded into obscurity compared with other Build engine games and was really remembered only for its often tasteless humour. Happily, Polish developer Flying Wild Hog went back to the original and rather than slavishly remaking it, did a wonderful job in taking from it what worked and removing or radically re-imagining what didn't. The end result is a hectic, gorgeous-looking shooter in a classic style with just enough of a modern sensibility to make it feel fresh. The most crucial aspect of the game's success? It has what the classic '90s shooters had and what modern ones very rarely possess - personality.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Definitely one of the best games I've ever played, 8/10TL;DR Version: It's an f'in awesome game, but works best if you only do one playthrough of it.Pros:Amazing melee combat-Having an actual knowledge of such things, I can say this game has one of the best melee combat systems I've ever seen in a game.-The ability to clean your sword is awesome, as I haven't seen it in any other game before.Pretty dang realistic physics and gibbing-Another one of my obsessions, this game definitely fits my expectations of what a hack n' slash game should have in terms of body physics and dismembering. Awesome references and humor-The goriest games should always have the funniest dialogue.-Also, the only time I heard "reaction" dialogue repeated was when Lo Wang "hurt his wang", so to speak.Pretty nice story and soundtrack-I've never been good at judging such things, so that's about as much as I can say.-Nice upgrade system-Good graphics-Lots of hidden things-Survival mode's pretty cool-Unlike other games, if you have full ammo and try to reload it will actually show him checking his weapons instead of not doing anything like most FPS'Cons:VV Major problem w/ the Game VV-After playing through the entire game, upgrading yourself and your weapons, it's basically all pointless since you can't go back and replay levels with your gear.-While it does make sense that the weapons might be to OP, this isn't a multiplayer game, so there's no one who would find it  "unfair".-Also, how can you get every upgrade in the game if, when you start at the beginning to get more karma points or ki crystals, your upgrades, the entire reason you wanted to replay the game, are gone?!!?Otherwise, there's just these minor problems;-cutscenes often glitch or won't animate properly-I played through the entire game without actually using any of the extra powers besides the regeneration one, so it's not like getting them in the first place is really necessary-Inconsistent fall damage-The stereotypical "video game weakspot" bull enemies are so d@mn hard to kill I once had to throw shurikens at one in order to kill it because I had literally ran out of ammo in every other gun trying to hit it's back.-While still fun, having to frequently fight a wave or two of enemies can get boring-No markers to tell you where to go-According to the end scene (where you can see yourself/Lo Wang,) Lo Wang apparently shaved off every hair on his body (i.e. he's too damn bald!)-Not enough wang punsOverall a great game, and I'll probably keep it one my computer for a while, but it still has very low replay-ability due to the whole "weapons-and-gear-not-saving" thing I mentioned earlier.

content:
Posted: May 21, 2016
												Shadow Warrior takes everything that was good from the original and repackages it into a modern box. Unfortunately, it also leaves in some old mechanics, that as a long time gamer, I wish they had left in the past. Down and dirty, here are the pros and cons:Pros:1. The self depreciating humor from the original is still intact. While it is not as controversial as the original, it still leaves the player feeling that the game does not take itself seriously. Which is very good, as you are playing a stereo-typical meat-head. From the fortunes of the fortune cookies, to the campy dialogue, the player will sometimes have to pause play to get their laughter under control.2. The controls are tight and responsive. This makes the gameplay feel fast paced and enjoyable.3. Its linear levels are well thought out to minimize back tracking.4. As you progress through the chapters, you feel as if you are progressing the story.5. The weapons feel "right".Cons:1. At higher difficulty levels, the monsters become massive bullet sponges.2. The "mini-boss" and "arena" fights often feel longer than they need to be. This becomes escpecially noticiable at higher difficulty settings. The player often feels as if they keep spamming enemies just to lengthen out gameplay. This tends to break immersion and sometimes the battles become very boring. (This is a mechanic I wished they left in the past)Overall, the game is well put together and despite its sometime immersion breaking battles, very fun to play. If you are looking for an "old-school" type shooter, then I reccommend "Shadow Warrior".

content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
Hack, slash, or shoot your way through waves of monsters in order to get all the pieces of the Nobitsura Kage in this 90's reboot. You play as Lo Wang, a modern day assassin, fighting your way through the chapters in the game alongside Hoji, a demon banished from the underworld. Whether you chose to split your enemies with a katana or with bullets, each kill is as satisfying as the last one. Add some absolutely beautiful environments to that and you get one of the better games of 2013.Pros:+Extremely satisfying sword mechanics, especially if played using a controller +The environments in this game are absolutely stunning, with lighting that can be described as perfect +Multiple difficulties to chose from +Survival game mode has just the right amount of challenge to it+Interesting story with characters that are unique to say the least +Each chapter takes at least 30 minutes to beat, easily making the game last you 10 hours +Weapons are balanced, making the game fun no matter what you use+The katana offers a versatile style of play +Comes with Viscera Cleanup Detail+Did I mention how beautiful this game looks? +Bunnies Cons:-Can get extremely repetitive after a while, though still very fun -Boss battles can be a bit awkward at times, though they are very doable -Though the glowing objective system works fantastically, it is a bit difficult to make out in a few environments To sum up this 90's reboot, it's a must have. The gameplay is fun, the story is entertaining, and the graphics are absolutely gorgeous. Whether it's on sale or not, it is definitely worth the money. If you're looking for fun game, you found it. 8/10

content:
Posted: February 14, 2015
												A great way to describe this game, very simply, is with the word 'fun'. It's a blast. Gorgeous visuals, especially the lighting effects and a nice variety in level appearance. Great variety of weapons, which look and feel good to use. Plenty of upgrades, giving you lots of freedom to choose to how you want to power up. Lots of content too 17 levels and the levels aren't that short. Tons of secrets and amusing hidden easter eggs to find. Very nostalgic but at the same time very modern, for example the fact that nearly every little object in the game is destructible. The way the story is presented is a huge improvement on how it was handled in this dev's previous game, Hard Reset, and it's great fun to hear the banter between Lo Wang and the demon Hoji. Great game overall! (—Å)

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												What can i say about shadow warrior, it is amazing. This game shows that old school games like of course shadow warrior, duke nukem 3D & so on can be done in moden time. Flying wild hog know how to make an old school game & make it enjoyable down to the very last thing. It has the best 1st person melee system i've ever seen, even with all the guns you will more likely use your katana the entire time. Enemies fall to pieces in the most satisfing way possible, arms go flying into the air, torso's get sliced in half & split apart. It is so much fun to play through especially with all the guns & mods for them, for example:Quad barrel shotgun,Quick draw pistol,Dual SMG,Grenade launching flamethrower,Rocket launcher firing 3 rockets & more.The only problems i've seen from my playthrough is missing textures & thats pretty much it. Boss battles are fun but repetitive, story is good & funny, the character Lo Wang & his demon companion Hoji are a great combo with there witty banter. I would get this game if you can, one of the most enjoyable games i've played this year. If you're unsure you can check my playthrough if you want to see the game & how it is if you want.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												If you played the original 1997 Shadow Warrior by 3D Realms and hope that this game isn't some washed up, hand holding, gun wielding simon says simulator, then don't worry. This game is developed by Flying Wild Hogs, developers of Hard Reset, another game I recommend taking the time to play as well. A very underrated game that deserves more attention because of the amount of depth, detail, and focus towards gameplay as well as bringing back a lot of elements used in classic games especially the 1997 version. Yes, there are a bit of cutscenes that you easily skip if you want, but don't worry, the second you start the game, there will be action throughout the entire journey. -StoryIn terms of storytelling, it's pretty basic and straightforward. The game takes place in China, you play as the amazing Lo-Wang who is now younger compared to the original elder Wang. This takes place while Lo Wang still worked for Master Zilla and starts off doing an assignment for him until all hell breaks loose. Story is alright in my opinion, never was a fan of storytelling when it comes to first person shooters, because all I really care about is the action, which this game heavily delivers a satisfying gameplay. -GameplayIf you remember the classic version or if you didn't, do yourself a favor and play it. The developers did a fantastic job at making sure that the Katana doesn't feel like a last resort optional weapon. The Katana is a lot more badass compared to how the sword was like in the original one. Wherever you slice, you will see your victims limbs cut off in the exact geometric shape, it's ridiculously awesome. You get to upgrade your weapons, skills, and powers whether it's increasing stamina and health, or increasing the amount of damage your Katana can bring. -VisualsThis game looks absolutely beautiful. There were moments where I had to actually stop and look around to see if this is a game or not. Sure it's not Crysis 3 or anything but I had to applaud the art team for delivering artwork. -VerdictThis game is a shining example of how to either modernize a classic game, or create an amazing single player First person shooter. If you enjoyed the original Shadow Warrior like I have, then you will not be disappointed with this game. Plus, there are secrets in game, meaning that the developers actually want you to explore. I remember finding a hidden path that led me to the actual first level of the original Shadow Warrior, they're not joking when they that they were fans of the original game. This game is exactly what Duke Nukem Forever should of been. Aside from the point, Shadow Warrior by Flying Wild Hog is a fantastic game to play, an awesome experience that delivers to fans of any classic shooter.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2014
												A pretty good surprise for the price I got it (10‚Ç¨). However I wouldn't recommend it at full price since the game has some problems that hold it back a lot. First, I didn't play the original Shadow Warrior, so for all the nostalgic, you can already skip this review, I probably don't want the same thing as you do.So, to sum up this game in one sentence, Shadow Warrior: cut them all! That game asks you to use a lot a sword, it's the best weapon in the game and you have skills and attacks to unlock with it. You also use sometimes some guns, but they feel so weak because it needs so many amos just to kill one thing and they sound quite bad, seriously, guns are used mainly for ennemies attacking from the air. On the plus side, the sword feels so good. It's powerful, you cut the‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•out of ennemies and turn them into a pile of remains with blood everywhere, so satisfaying. The game isn't too long and doesn't feel too short. However the story is meh, the story is just a way to make you kill stuff without thinking why you do that.The game is looking quite good, but on my hardware I had some performence issues (i5 3570k/GTX770), I needed to turn off some options like the mirrors, particle, and physics and even that way, I had sometimes huge frame drops. That was still playable anyway but still. The musics were okay, nothing felt wrong on that side. The game has some good humors too, like begining the game with Stan Bush music calld The Touch. Is the gameplay good? The swordplay is satisfaying yes, but overall the gameplay gets repetitive a lot. It's mainly due to the linear gameplay that keeps the same layout. You run, cut some demons, do your objectives, cut some more demons, grease and repeat. Talking about demons, you spent most of your time killing them. That's a choice yeah but I would have prefered the game being more focused on fighting humans on sword battle. Besides the variety of demons is non existant. You'll be fighting the same kind of demons during the whole game. And the boss battles that could have been awesome are just bad. It's just about shooting them on one blinking spot and then shoot some more in the revealed weak spot. And that's the same way to kill them for ALL of those bosses. Overall, that game isn't terrible, I've played way worse than this but for a game sold for 35 bucks on Steam, I expected something less repetitive, even if I got it for 10 bucks. Is it fun? Yes it is. Can you get bored before the end of the game? Yes, you could get bored fast, but you can still kill rabbits to kill your boredom I guess?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 2, 2016
												I HIGHLY RECOMMEND THIS GAME.Okay so Shadow Warrior is a beautiful masterpiece, the story/plot is very interesting and will really draw you into the game, by the time you've finished the game YOU WILL CRY because it's over.You play as Lo Wang, comic-collector hitman with a sense of humor that produces the most groan-worthy puns and chuckles, the dialog between him and the demon Hoji who's with you throughout the game is brilliant, Hoji's intense sarcasm and insults combined with Lo Wang's own sarcasm and swift comebacks produce pure gold. The gameplay is basically tons of combat which doesn't get repetitive due to the way you get rated out of 5 at the end of each fight and the more ways you use to kill gives you a higher score, as you go along you discover new weapons like how you would in Doom, you gain karma from finding secrets (There are like somewhere between 3-8 each level) and fighting which leads to leveling up skills that'll do basic things like increasing your health or stamina mostly along with the sword techniques section which lets you use special moves such as my personal favorite - Wing of Crane which sends out a wave of ki energy that cuts through loads of enemies, basically a slash that pierces through enemies and walls of maybe a 10m range. You can also find Ki crystals which you can use to upgrade your powers - healing being the one you'll use most probably but also things like flux, a water trap that lifts up enemies into the air rendering them immobile for a while, dragon scales aka a shield and tigers roar which is sort of like a less powerful Fus Roh Dah. Now the sword and magic is a huge part of the game but the other weapons you find you can upgrade with money which you'll also find throughout the game and by the end of it you'll have some f**cking awesome weapons that can cause a hell of a lot of damage, also YOU CAN USE A DEMON'S HEAD AS A LASER!Pros: Lo Wang's singing Interesting enemies Hilarious as Hell BEAUTIFUL PLOT "La la la la laahh" ( Õ°¬∞ Õú ñ Õ°¬∞) LOTS OF SECRETS TO FIND LOTS OF ACHIEVEMENTS  Beautiful scenery even though the actual quality isn't amazing Hoji "Beware of the Wang" Bodies can be ripped into even smaller pieces after they're dead Pretty fun boss fights *Shoots with crossbow* *Enemy corpse flies 34 miles before finally getting pinned against some mountain in the distance* If you set them on fire, they do actually panic.Cons TOO SHORT Ending leaves much to be asked Boss fights can get a bit repetative at times but there isn't many so it's alright How damn hard it is to get off your PC and eat something Music is nice but more tracks could be nice since after a while you get bored of hearing the same thing over and over The sword once fully upgraded you can literally just spam it in the last boss fights making them just boring and not challenging at allDefinitely my favorite game of all time so far. Get it now you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Playtime: 16 Hours (includes secret hunting)Score: 7 / 10Recommended Price: $19.99A remake of the classic Shadow Warrior featuring still the character Lo Wang. It is easy to see that much effort went into blending modern and classic FPS styles. Medkits still litter the levels yet you have the ability to heal yourself at will with a Chi spell unlocked early in the game. Many people will remember the humour of the first game and it is still here, although at a toned down level. Much of the hilarious one liners and jokes are gone or purposefully changed to lower potentional insult certain people might feel and make vocal. Secret areas do exist and are done up in the classic Shadow Warrior pixel graphics. Areas from old levels and pixel-based girls await your discovery!Much of the combat focuses on the use of your sword, which I found to be a huge plus. There is an assortment of weapons as one would expect in classic FPS titles with three different upgrades each. Different Chi-based abilities help you fight your foes. Two skills knock down or suspend foes in the air, various katana abilities help you fight at range or slay foes in a circle around you. All in all I was highly impressed and surprised at how good the overall game was in both quality and length. If you can pick it up on sale for $19.99 or less it's definitely worth it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Shadow Warrior came out of nowhere and blew my mind. It is the best single player FPS game I have played in a long time. The gameplay itself might get repetitive toward the end of the game, but the well written dialogue and great characters kept me interested.Shadow Warrior is a reimagining of the 1997 game of the same name. Some things connecting this new game to the 1997 original is some similar naming of locations, the main character and the heavy use of katana as a melee weapon, but basically you are not missing anything if you haven't played the original or even know nothing about it.Here are some additional scrabled thoughts about the gameWhat I liked-The story, characters, voice acting, visuals and soundtrack.-The story is a mix between drama and comedy. Usually this is a bad idea, but somehow Shadow Warrior makes the mood shifts enjoyable. One of the most important reasons as to why Shadow Warrior has such good characters is that they are a mix of dramatic and comedic traits, which makes them very approachable and human.-Good enemy variety. Different weapons/techniques are also required to beat some of the harder enemies.-Good weapon variety, and you can carry all the weapons at once without needing to swap. There's also a weapon upgrade system in place. The upgrades are kind of scarse, so it's always interesting to get one and the upgrades have real impact, and most of them are not like "+5% accuracy", but alternative firing modes and such.-Flow of the game. There's a good rhythm with the story bits, enemy encounters, humour, serious moments, exploration. It is aslo separated into chapters that range from about 20 minutes to 40 minutes, so it is nicely paced in terms of when you can just shut the game and take a break or do something else entirely.-Melee combat. It has a melee combat system with some executable special moves. The moves are always just double tap a directional key and press LMB or RMB, but still it's fun to execute them.-It has this kind of (but not quite) hint system where you need to always use objects or doors that glow yellow. I thought it was much more pleasant than the reqular arrow or path that shows you exactly where you need to go. When there was not immediate in your face indication of where to go I found myself exploring and taking in the world a lot better than in, say BioShock Infinite.What I didn't like-The boss battles are all the same. You just dodge attacks and shoot at the glowing weak spot.-Some of the chapters drag a bit, forcing you into huge arenas with multiple waves of spawning enemies.-The combat in general starts to become a bit boring when you have first learned all the sword techiques and then learnt when and how to execute them. It starts to become a bit mundane when there is no new stuff to learn.In conclusion it is in my opinion one of the best games of 2013, and it should not be overlooked.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Shadow Warrior is one of those games that didn't catch my interest well enough for me to buy it when it came out. I can't believe it took me this long until i finally saw it on the steam sale and said to myself "¬£2...not bad. Let's do this" I install this, launch the game and i am greeted with the well known song 'Stan Bush - You got the touch' which immediatly brings back memories of me re-watching The Transformers movie for the billionth time.Anyway. You are Lo Wang. Or as he likes to call himself "Mr. Two Million Dollars", you had this one simple job. Get the sword and give the money, but the owner doesn't want to part with it. Maybe he has developed some intimate emotions with it. I dont know...one minute i'm standing in front of all these gang members and the next i'm slaughtering them into pieces, literal pieces that slowly fall off from each other. Think Resident evil laser room scene. This was cool as‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•The game progresses as you find that your boss (Zilla) is trying to find 2 swords, one of which you now possess and the others being elsewhere and these all link in with a Demon Realm and how the 3 swords combined are the only thing that can kill the Ancient Gods. So with the help of the dementia ridden Demon known to you as Hoji you go from environment to environment. Looking for whisperers who can hold the swords (demons can't hold the swords as it will kill them) The whisperers are mechanical beings that are powered by memories that are sacrificed by Ancients and as they are roboty they are not affected. That's pretty much it, find the girl whisperers, kill them and combine the swords for that perk and to get one stop closer to kicking an Ancient Gods‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• Wang style.The combat works suprisingly well, there was some worrying at the beginning as to how i'm going to remember all the moves but eventually you're locking down combos like it's Tekken (or streetfighter if that's more your thing) Want to sexually touch your sword so you can whip a blade ki slash to decapitate your enemies? Doubletap 'S' and hold RMB. Want to immobilize the enemies infront of you? Then Doubletap S and hold LMB. It's very easy to use. You have RMB for sword attack based movies and LMB for Ki based movies such as healing, throwing enemies up in the air, pushing them back and such.One thing that i did find irritating was how secrets were tied into upgrades and perks. I didn't want to be held back in unlocking the upgrades simply because i didn't find that Ki crystal behind those boxes that have to be slashed. I mean, the first time you came upon the Ki crystal, it wasn't even the path you were supposed to take to your mission! It does however change the way you play the game, making you look in every nook and cranny and slashing maniacally at those poor boxes to get that small statue.Lo Wang came off as a serious‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• in fact. I think he was just born an ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• from beginning to end and his transition from "I'm so full of it" to "He's my friend and i'm going to help him" was very quick that i suddenly thought i was playing as someone else! He's quick witted as intended by the developers but man were his jokes corney. I loved them!Shadow Warrior would have been my most favourite FPS if i had played it back in 2013. It's a shame it took me this long to finally get around to playing it, it was worth every penny and i really do recommended it.By the way, if you find two rabbits getting it on. Please don't kill them, that male rabbit will not be pleased... ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing demons...*grumble grumble*

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												Im really split between actually saying its a good game or saying its a bad game. So Im gonna leave it up to others to decide and just am gonna count up everything Ive noticed.The Story. You dont know atfirst but the story is actually quite deep and really nice. Especially because its told from different perspectives. Some parts get clear while others are still strange and I bet cinemasins would die trying to analyse what when and why couldve happened better. I think its nice, even though you have to figure it out yourself mostly, after something happened already.The Gameplay Yeah, what can I say to that.. Honestly, its mostly horrible. Its just a pile of crap. It has a ton of bugs which cause you to die and restart about twenty minutes in the past. The fights get harder but not more challenging, enemies can just be mowed down by buttonsmashing or dont die because their weakspot has a horrible hitbox that obviously was hit but didnt count as a hit. Its good for a hack and slay, but thats all. No real challenge, just doing the same thing over and over again.The Secrets and jokes That and the story are the best parts about the game. There are so many jokes, references, puns and dumb-action-movie sentences which make it hillarious. I enjoyed it much, especially the fortune cookies.The Characters They are all pending between having actual depth but still staying flat to the surface. I mean, they all just seem to want to do one thing but then suddenly, bam, character development. Have all of it. And it worked. Especially here the different angles of story telling are good.The Graphics Now, I dont wanna say that graphic is the only important thing, but its still an important factor, even if the story is awesome. Yet, good graphics and bad story dont make a game good. This game has a good graphic, I dont know why  but I think it was quite awesome, even though its kinda old and just a remake. Some places looked awesome, even though some were repetetive.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Great single player game, campaign lasts anywhere from 15 hours+ depending on the difficulty and how much you look for secrets. Hundreds of enemies thrown at you at once for your almighty blade to slice into multiple pieces. There are also many guns to be used, abused and upgraded which are also very amusing to use. The ranking system after every battle is also a neat system that encourages you to go back and 5 star every map. Overall a great game and not just for fans of the Serious Sam formula, its a great game for anyone looking for a great single player experience. Also, your character's name is Lo Wang.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 12, 2016
												With the binary nature of Steam's recommend/don't recommend system, it can be difficult to review some games (whereas a graduated rating system might be more appropriate but perhaps more difficult to interpret).  And although I can recommend this game to most people with a reasonable degree of confidence, I find that Shadow Warrior is occasionally one of those problematic games. It's not really necessary to be familiar with the 1997 original, since the 2013 version by Flying Wild Hog is a modern reboot.  Lo Wang's previously racist caricatures have been tempered by a more moderate (but strangely endearing) flavor of ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.  But I doubt anybody's playing either of these games for the puns, so I digress.  Just know that Wang and the demonic voice in his head can make for frequently entertaining banter, and that it helps move the story along in a positive way while helping distinguish it from other FPS games that are often devoid of charm or  personality.So Wang is on a quest for a sword (or several swords) that are imbued with magical powers.  This job quickly goes sideways, pitting Wang against everything from Yakuza to gargantuan demons from a "Shadow Realm".  As things progress, Wang accrues money (used to buy ammo and purchase upgrades for weapons), Karma (used to unlock and improve skills) and Ki Crystals (used to unlock demonic powers).  The weapons tree is pretty self-explanatory:  You'll come across new weapons as you work through the story, and each of these weapons (with the exception of two demonic-based tools) has three upgrades for purchase at your leisure.  For example, one of the upgrades lets you fan the hammer of your revolver "Western Style" as an alt-fire, greatly increasing firerate; another lets you wield a second SMG akimbo; a barrel attachment for your flamethrower gives you the ability to lob balls of explosive goo as an alt-fire.  Most upgrades significantly improve the utility of each weapon and can turn a relatively medicore firearm into something useful or flexible, even at higher difficulties.  In general I feel that the arsenal is pretty comprehensive, although even with the upgrades system it can feel a little small at times.  Despite all this, the good ol' sword (which, after a Karma and Ki Crystals, feels awesome to use) will likely be a mainstay of most players' strategies.The "Skills" and "Powers" trees are a little more nebulous.  Skills are generally passive qualities like "find more money" or "do more damage to Lesser Demons", but there are also active skills (such as sword moves) that blur the lines between the two categories.  Powers, on the other hands, are strictly active abilities like healing, throwing up a defensive shield, or projecting a force that knocks enemies off their feet.  Unlike a lot of games, you won't be able to buy/upgrade everything on a single run, nor will you feel pressed to make hard decisions with limited resources--and that's a good balance for the game to strike, in my opinion.Speaking of which, for the initial bit, you'll only have your sword (and a basic revolver not long after).  This is probably one of the lowest points of the game, since you'll be flailing your sword wildly and impotently at NPCs and shooting a sluggish revolver--and probably missing a fair amount--at squirrely demons.  I cannot stress it enough:  The game is really not that fun for the first 30 minutes or so.  For me, things only started to pick up once I was able to invest a few points into some skills, upgrade a few weapons, and accrue a couple of abilities.  The game is strongest when you are beheading crowds with 360-degree sword moves, unloading four-barreled shotguns into teleporting witch-demons, and flinging opponents through the air like ragdolls on a never-ending quest to get the approval of the game's rating system.  The general progression of levels are a distinct mix of classic FPS and arena FPS.  On some of the larger levels, you're free to approach things from several different directions or orders; at other points, the game will give you a more linear series of arena fights to work your way through (a la Painkiller or Serious Sam).  Sometimes the levels--the "Shadow Realm" chapters in particular--are beautiful.  On the other hand, the game often languishes in ugly, dull areas like the interior of a cargo ship. One of my bigger issues with the game stems from the aforementioned arena-based nature of a lot of the levels.  Specifically, they tend to go on for too long.  That in and of itself isn't a huge problem, but when coupled with Shadow Warrior's limited enemy roster, the fights can get monotonous fast--especially towards the end when you'll be fighting the same half-dozen enemy types over and over again, 3-5 waves per setpiece.  Though it's obvious that Flying Wild Hog was working with limited resources, the existing enemies are satisfying to fight (granted the shield-wielding demons can be obnoxious).  Of course, the game shouldn't have dragged on for so long if it wasn't able to keep things fresh with a wider roster of monstrosities.  There are seriously levels where you'll just go from arena to arena, fighting what is fundamentally the same group of enemies over and over again, for 45-60 minutes per level.  It really does a disservice to the game.  Also, despite Shadow Warrior's central conceit being about a sword and the jerk who wields it, the game inexplicably has  sections where you'll be obligated to man a turret as 15-20 flying enemies or several waves of ground enemies come towards you.  They aren't fun and the game throws more of these sections at you than it should, to the point where you'll start cringing whenever you see a glowing turret in a room.     Still, Shadow Warrior is probably the best case scenario of a classic FPS reboot we could ever hope for (especially after the less successful installments of other classic FPS games, like RoTT and Duke Nukem Forever).  Is it a fun game?  Most definitely.  Is it a perfect game?  Not even close.  But it's a great effort and the sequel is shaping up to be a solid game in its own right--something that wouldn't be possible without the success of the former.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												I played this masterpiece of a game with no knowledge of either the original or hard reset, and when i actually started playing i fell in love with the game by the first level. The combat is as satisfying as it is responsive and the katana's hit detection is probably the best i've ever seen in a video game (however special abilities are difficult to use at first), there is no weapon that you feel you won't like simply due to the fact that all of them have niche roles. The plot is interesting as well making mindless killing actually seem like your doing something meaningful however i won't talk too much about it due to spoilers. The game also has a surprisingly good sense of (especially considering the fact that the main character's name is essentially a‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•joke). Lastly the world is absolutely beautiful (albeit it's no columbia from bioshock infinite)Dispite all of that however, the game has a few game breaking AI glitches (like enemies hiding behind cover forever in a place the player can't reach) that make it impossible to advance due to the "kill everything to advance" system that only works if it's well placed in games like castle crashers. Also as i mentoned earlier the abilities are hard to use at first due to minor control issues and the exploration can get pretty boring when you just want to kill everything in sight but there's nothing for you to kill. Another thing to note is the unbareable load times, it's worse than dead rising 2 in this respect.Overall i'd reccomend this game to anyone who likes good stories, mindless killing, non-serious games and good humour but can tolerate a few downsides that prevent this game being perfect

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 23, 2014
												Shadow Warrior is undoubtedly a breath of fresh air in the myriad of FPS games that have come out in recent times. You hardly use cover and must use the spacious environments to your advantage with your high-speed dodges and quick attacks. This game does nearly everything right. NEARLY. What it doesn't do right is a HUGE thing, unfortunately, and left a bad taste in my mouth in the end.Pros:+ The game looks great. To my knowledge, Flying Wild Hog isn't a huge triple-A company, so the amount of assets and how good they look is a real plus. Everything meshes together very nicely. Character models look good and the animations are very well done.+ The violence and gore is lovely.  Really satisfying to slice up, blast, and decapitate enemies in different ways.+ The story is nicely done. Even if my mind was usually rendered numb through all the fighting I had to go through, there was a semblance of a story and I think that it was told well enough.+ Good sense of humor. I got plenty of chuckles from this one, although some parts made me cringe admittedly.Cons:- The soundtrack was not all that memorable, but it fit into the game well enough. This is labeled as a "con" just because I would have preferred something more awesome through the mind-numbing gameplay I had to sit through.- This game is fun for the first few hours as more and more enemies are introduced to you. The thing is, at the 2/3 mark, the game takes a nosedive and thinks that throwing a‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•load of bullet sponge enemies at you relentlessly for hours and hours will continue being fun. There was no more variety once the last of the enemies were revealed (this was around the 1/2 mark), and it was a massive hassle getting through the last chapters of the game. I was constantly praying that it would eventually be over. It dragged out its welcome.- To branch off the con above, the game is too long for the amount of derivative gameplay there is. Serious Sam 3 had a similar gameplay style to this one, but that game was the perfect length and spread out its levels into very interesting designs and introduced enemies at the perfect pace. It also had more fun weapons and co-op.Shadow Warrior is close to not being recommended, but there was obviously a lot of love put into this one, and I enjoyed it enough for the most part to where I think it skirts over the line. For anyone looking for a "modern old-school" title, I hope that you're one of the more hardcore ones. Maybe then you'll have a blast the whole way through.

												I have just completed Shadow Warrior and I really enjoyed it. The game offers classic arena style gameplay and a engaging story that kept me playing. There is a nice selection of weapons such as my favorite duel-wielding submachine guns and katana moves you can use. The keyboard controls and mouse movement are very responsive. I recommend buying this game because Flying Wild Hog have put a lot of care (patches) and attention to detail that pays tribute to old-school fps.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Don't look at the metascore for this one. This  is an old-school shooter with tight controls, satisfying gameplay, and a fantastic-looking environment. It's also full of crude humor and general oldschool machoness. Think Serious Sam or Duke Nukem, but with a lot more melee options. The gameplay is tight, you move fast, the enemies strafe and dodge your fire. The environments are detailed and feel realistic (as opposed to Seriouis Sam, where alleys look like football stadiums). The game is linear, but there are plenty of hidden gems and secrets to be found. It's also full of references to old school shooters.This game is gorgeous, even on low settings. But if you want higher fidelity you'd have to add a bit of heat to your graphics cards. Sometimes the enemies feel a bit repetitive or even bullet-spongey. The characters are maybe a bit too macho to be likeable, the same way that Bulletstorm's characters didn't really appeal to me.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 5, 2015
Hack, slash, or shoot your way through waves of monsters in order to get all the pieces of the Nobitsura Kage in this 90's reboot. You play as Lo Wang, a modern day assassin, fighting your way through the chapters in the game alongside Hoji, a demon banished from the underworld. Whether you chose to split your enemies with a katana or with bullets, each kill is as satisfying as the last one. Add some absolutely beautiful environments to that and you get one of the better games of 2013.Pros:+Extremely satisfying sword mechanics, especially if played using a controller +The environments in this game are absolutely stunning, with lighting that can be described as perfect +Multiple difficulties to chose from +Survival game mode has just the right amount of challenge to it+Interesting story with characters that are unique to say the least +Each chapter takes at least 30 minutes to beat, easily making the game last you 10 hours +Weapons are balanced, making the game fun no matter what you use+The katana offers a versatile style of play +Comes with Viscera Cleanup Detail+Did I mention how beautiful this game looks? +Bunnies Cons:-Can get extremely repetitive after a while, though still very fun -Boss battles can be a bit awkward at times, though they are very doable -Though the glowing objective system works fantastically, it is a bit difficult to make out in a few environments To sum up this 90's reboot, it's a must have. The gameplay is fun, the story is entertaining, and the graphics are absolutely gorgeous. Whether it's on sale or not, it is definitely worth the money. If you're looking for fun game, you found it. 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												I'm really new to the Shadow Warrior genre and I just bought it during a steam sale.My first experience with the game and my take on it.+ Astoundingly beautiful graphics.+ Delicious gore.+ Very original and cool weapon designs.+ Lots of easter eggs, secrets and funny tidbits you can find when exploring the world around you.+ Very fast-paced combat, always keeps you on your toes.+ Wang.+ Very nice artwork and environmental effects. Everything around you is a freaking deathtrap if you're not careful.+ Very nice blend of horror, thriller, suspense and action.Now for the cons.- The head and weapon bobbing makes me a little nauseous. I wish there was an option to turn that off.- The lighting in some are blinding and frustrating to navigate to.- Some of the control schemes just don't make sense to me. Like the regeneration skill. Constantly pushing "D" makes you move while healing, which can be convenient at times but there are some cases where you don't want to go in the direction you're trying to heal yourself in.- Motion blur is going to make me sick. I'm normally used and accustomed to FPS games  but this one just makes me wanna puke after playing for hours for some reason, something that most FPS games do not induce on me.- The death count: Seriously, don't be like GTA or other games that reminds players how many times they messed up in the game. I'm a perfectionist so I had to delete my old save data just to start fresh and go for a no death run.- There are times where Wang is just trying too hard to be funny. The accent is a little bit thick for an asian too.- Lo Wang is not even a japanese name. I don't know Wang's backstory but when I started the game, I assumed he was Japanese. If so, disregard this.- Experienced my first death when I misread the health number and thought it read 12 when it actuallity, it was written as "92". I panicked and ran all over the place, got mobbed and died.Overall, my score for this game is an honest 8/10.Will try to shoot vending machine and dying again.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												What a fantastic game. Very fun and worth the money if you can grab it for <$20. I wouldn't recommend this game if you dislike the "feel" of something like Ninja Gaiden where you see pretty much every enemy you'll fight all game within the first half of the main story. It follows the convention of just throwing more of the same enemies at you instead of different enemies. I'm perfectly fine with that but I can see why it could make others pass it up. The last few chapters become incredibly drudging however. In one section you're forced to fight two very fast and very strong minibosses at once with a vision handicap, and then they do it again in the next chapter, and AGAIN in the chapter after that. Some parts can feel very cheap and some of the mechanics as well. I found myself constantly using the Wing of Crane move because it was so damn good, but I rarely ever used the Flux or Shockwave skills. Some of the guns are fantastically good like the crossbow, but others are absolute garbage like the pistol. Pretty much everything in this game is hit-and-miss, but most of the time the positives highly outweigh the negatives, most of the time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												I'm surprised with how much I enjoyed Shadow Warrior. I knew that I would probably enjoy it because I love old-school styled first person shooters, but it surpassed my expectations. Don't get me wrong, it's not a masterpiece or anything more than your simple shooter, but it really is an expertly done return to the exploration and chaos of older FPS games.The gameplay consists of two main aspects, combat and exploration. The combat, like all old-school FPS games, is fast paced and chaotic. It throws a lot of enemies at you at the same time, which demands quick reflexes and projectile dodging. Lots of little things really make the combat work, like you move a bit faster than your average modern game hero and you aren't retricted to holding only two weapons at a time, you hold an arsenal of varied weapons by the end of the game. It's a nice change of pace from the combat of a lot of recent shooters, namely cover based shooting. Not that there is anything wrong with that style of combat, it's just fresh to return to circle-strafing and blasting away large hordes of monsters with a dozen different weapons. The katana in particular is a joy to use, as it dynamically cuts off the body parts that you sliced and is also relatively powerful; it's really the star of the combat in this game. Another thing that really makes the combat is the upgrade system. You have to save up three different resources to level up Lo Wang as you play: money, karma, and ki crystals which level up your weapons, skills, and powers respectively. These can really change the way that you can handle enemy encounters, like being able to use a slain demon's head to defeat more powerful foes or being able to use your katana from a distance with a light beam attack. At the end of each enemy encounter, you're given a score out of five based on how well you did in the fight. It gives you karma bonuses if you used a variety of attacks and weapons instead of just spamming the same attacks over and over. That alone, if you follow it, makes sure the combat doesn't get too old too quickly. The exploration in this game breaks up the combat nicely giving the game a nice roller-coaster like pace. After you defeat all the enemies in an area, you're encouraged to scour it for hidden secrets which will reward you with resources required to upgrade your powers, weapons or skills. The combat, levelling, and exploration and tie together perfectly to create very satisfying and fun gameplay.I was also surprised by the look of the game. While the graphics are not exceptionally good, the asian art style really helped the game stand out visually from others. Levels are filled with pagodas, candles, Buddha statues, bamboo, samurai armour displays, it really does look unique for a shooter. There are also a tonne of little details to notice throughout the game, like how enemies fall apart after you slice them up. Each chapter of the game also has a different look to it, keeping you from getting tired of looking at the same types of areas. The comic book cutscenes that divide each chapter of the game are also visually interesting, if a bit cliched at this point.The story of the game also surprised me in that it was actually interesting. Again, I'm not saying that it's fantastic, but for an old-school styled first person shooter, whose stories are usually given no thought at all, it was a welcome surprise. The real stand out writing-wise was the game's humour. Dialouge during the story bits is funny, albeit in a very immature way, and Lo Wang will spit out so-bad-they're-good one-liners during combat. The secrets can also be funny with a lot of references to the original Shadow Warrior.For all the good things I have to say about Shadow Warrior, there isn't much bad. I only have three real, but minor complaints. One, with the katana being so much fun to use, the guns seam very boring by comparison, but that's only because they really nailed the katana. Two, I played this game on the hardest difficutly and I only died a handful of times. Some more challenge would be appreciated, especially for an old-school shooter. Finally three, the levels are a bit linear for an old-school shooter, you won't find Duke Nukem 3D or Doom styled non-linearity level exploration here which I feel was a missed opportunity.However, you're supposed to judge things based on what they are and not what you want them to be. I really enjoyed playing Shadow Warrior and was surprised by how well it was done. Granted, I have not played the original Shadow Warrior at the time of me writing this, but regardless, as a stand alone game, Shadow Warrior is very much worth playing through if you liked fast paced, old-school action.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												While I have never played the original Shadow Warrior, I am familiar with its setting and some gameplay footage. I am extremely glad that the borderline racist protagonist was remade without the accent and cringeworthy stereotypes.Shadow Warrior is not a great game. You go through levels, pressing buttons to unlock doors or destroy magical seals in order to move forward. In between all of this, you shoot predictable waves of demons or turn to your trusty sword when you run low on ammo. Fairly basic and rather unoriginal. Level design, while diversified, is at times lackluster and uninspired. When you find the same ammo-crates and closets in every level ranging from random house in random village to mountain fortress of solitude, things get a bit dull. Good thing they didn't put those closets in the shadow realm as well.What makes the game shine is the combat mechanics, especially the swordfighting. While in the early stages, you are best advised to keep your distance and deal headshots, using the sword only sparingly, the sword really starts to shine about 2 hours into the game, after you unlock certain special moves. These not only make dealing with hordes of enemies way easier, but are also pretty fun.Most of the guns, on the other hand, are pretty useless. I relied mainly on the Shotgun (which is borderline useless before the upgrade to 4-barrels) and Crossbow (again, it only really starts to shine after upgrading, after which it becomes a vital weapon for quick kills). They might as well have left out the flamethrower, since it really only seems to make enemies panic without actually dealing significant damage. What in the beginning looks like your garden variety macho-guy-slaughters-monsters-to-cope-with-inferiority-complex story turns out to be surprisingly deep and enchanting. The cutscenes are artistically rendered and the overall story really develops into something serious about 2/3 into the game. Although I wasn't able to understand every last detail, since some of it is told in-game, I was pleased with the plotline.A detail that sort of bothers me are the non-Japanese signs one can find in the harbour level that is supposed to take place in Osaka, Japan. I might be wrong about these, but they are either Chinese or just a random selection of Chinese characters. This along with the protagonist's boss' name Mizayaki (which, as far as I know, is not a real Japanese name - it should probably be Miyazaki), I found to be  a bit unsensitive. Then again, it might be some sort of innuendo or joke that I am not aware of.Overall, I'd rate the game 7/10. It was a fun experience, even while at times being a bit repetitive and dull. Secret-hunters will definitely be satisfied, as well as those who seek a break from generic duck-behind-a-kneehigh-wall shooters.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												For fans of the older Doom-style shooters, Shadow Warrior will be a decent rush of nostalgic fun. The shooting is well done, with the action keeping a fast, flowing pace throughout. The weapons aren't as fun as some of the old style shooters, however, they're all fairly bland, with the katana being the most fun to use. The swordplay is surprisingly visceral, although you will sometimes slice through an enemy and almost nothing will happen, the enemies more often are either sliced to pieces, or react as if they had been hit by an actual sword. The story is coherent and interesting enough to keep the game together, but it's so tonally different from the gameplay that it often pushes you out of the experience. The two main characters do have a nice back-and-forth, with some of their dialogue actually making me laugh. The enemies however, get a bit repetitive, you fight the same 6 or 7 enemies during the entire game, and in the last few chapters, it finally gets a bit too repititive, and the combat stops being fun almost completely. The bosses are also fairly boring, Shadow Warrior doing the big impressive boss thing that telegraphs their attacks so far in advance you'd think they were trying to let you win, with the amount of health and ammo scattered around during these fights, they're just too easy. The ending is also a bit disappointing. TL;DR: A fun rush of slightly repetitive violence with an okay story and a couple of interesting characters.Edit: It's also fairly pretty.

content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												This juvenile pre-remake for Shadow Warrior set in the 80s starts strong and the implementation of sword play works nicely with the special abilities that you gain and use through button combinations (like in a fighting game). Unfortunately the fun level doesn't rise but rather stagnates as you go through waves of the same enemies over and over again. I kept wishing there was some way to do combos like in 'Darkness 2' or 'Bioshock', and also some finishing moves would have been nice. The other thing missing is the stealth element, in the original game you could become invisible and choose when to attack a pack of baddies...hence the title of the game. Here you have to kill everyone in an orderly fashion to open the doors that lead you to the next part of the level (effectively annihilating any replay value). Still the game looks great if not entirely original - sometimes I felt I was playing 'RAGE' or 'CALL of DUTY' with a sword- it's fast and furious speed is noteworthy. In a way it falls shy of greatness, although there are 17 chapters, there are only 14 levels (and 3 bosses) and only 3 different enviromments (Japanese villa/town and forest/cemetery, Shipyard, and mountain lab/castle) clocking around 20h on HARD for a first playthrough. Maybe one day we'll get more Wang with a cool DLC but the fortune cookie says it's doubtful at this point in time.PS: There's a survival mode with 3 levels but no multiplayer all. Sniff.PPS: Whatever happened to the black and white twin sisters?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												Im really split between actually saying its a good game or saying its a bad game. So Im gonna leave it up to others to decide and just am gonna count up everything Ive noticed.The Story. You dont know atfirst but the story is actually quite deep and really nice. Especially because its told from different perspectives. Some parts get clear while others are still strange and I bet cinemasins would die trying to analyse what when and why couldve happened better. I think its nice, even though you have to figure it out yourself mostly, after something happened already.The Gameplay Yeah, what can I say to that.. Honestly, its mostly horrible. Its just a pile of crap. It has a ton of bugs which cause you to die and restart about twenty minutes in the past. The fights get harder but not more challenging, enemies can just be mowed down by buttonsmashing or dont die because their weakspot has a horrible hitbox that obviously was hit but didnt count as a hit. Its good for a hack and slay, but thats all. No real challenge, just doing the same thing over and over again.The Secrets and jokes That and the story are the best parts about the game. There are so many jokes, references, puns and dumb-action-movie sentences which make it hillarious. I enjoyed it much, especially the fortune cookies.The Characters They are all pending between having actual depth but still staying flat to the surface. I mean, they all just seem to want to do one thing but then suddenly, bam, character development. Have all of it. And it worked. Especially here the different angles of story telling are good.The Graphics Now, I dont wanna say that graphic is the only important thing, but its still an important factor, even if the story is awesome. Yet, good graphics and bad story dont make a game good. This game has a good graphic, I dont know why  but I think it was quite awesome, even though its kinda old and just a remake. Some places looked awesome, even though some were repetetive.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 1, 2014
												I was never one to play the original Shadow Warrior, but I think this game captures the spirit of old school fps games with some neat twists. I would love for Flying Wild Hog to expand on the game a bit more, maybe create a more polished sequel, as I feel there were some bits and pieces of this game that felt unrealized or primarily unfinished. And the plot takes a surprising turn near the end. But in the grand scheme of it all these are minor gripes.Where the game truly shines is in the combat. Not quite Serious Sam level, but still more than enough to keep things tense and exciting. The environments have some nice touches, and although the secrets aren't necessarily well hidden, it's more than enough for anyone who wants to take the time to look for them. Unlike other franchises that have rebooted, while forgetting what made them so enjoyable (looking at you Painkiller and Duke Nukem), Flying Wild Hog has not only revived an aging series, but they've done so with good design sensibility, and an explosion filled, blood soaked shoot fest that also happens to have some very satisfying swordplay. 8.5/10.

You fight countless demons from the Shadow Realm and it becomes a very challenging game. Its a worthy title to have in your Steam Collection and it just works. The only flaws it has is the ending, and the overall backstory makes no sense...but that does not matter. A suitcase of money, a blooy sword and fighting endless demons is more than enough to deem worthy of being called Mr. Two Million Dollars. A'oh![PROS] Visually Stunning & Bloody Brilliant. Authentic Asian-style action & musical elements to the surroundings. Samurai-Style Sushi (Everybody was kung fu fighing! ~) Did I mention the blood and guts? You are reading this now and should be playing it instead.[CONS] Story is like...uhh...What happened? On higher Difficulties you will be owned. Don't Zip Run off cliffs, bridges or abyssal slopes. Aiming your guns is a bit stupid and irky jerky. (Couldn't get that to work better developers?) Heroic Mode is just Holy‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• (You Developers are crazy, I mean seriously, really, come on!)Closing: Its all just Baby Farts...

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 13, 2015
												Realy liked this game decent story and the games length is above average.What I liked also is that you can use the sword or use the guns I didn't feel forced to use one over the other.I realy like the weapons in this game because you can "feel" them when hitting enemys.Keys are rebindable and very simple.Myy friend VOJ reminded me of something I didn't realy notice much in game since I used the sword alot.There are some enemies that are like bullet sponges in this game so I lowered from 9 to 7.5/10 WangarangsDetailed explanation below (Spoiler free)GORE:The enemies head , legs ,arms ,etc .. are "detachable".If you take out a enemies legs they will crawl after you while beeding out.WEAPONS:The weapons can be upgraded using money except for the sword (sword has "upgrades" but only unlocks during story progress.Upgrades are realy different swords that you find later in game)The weapons have 3 upgrades each and can be unlocked in any order you wish.Also most of these upgrades change the way the guns behave.Example: Flamethrower has a upgrade that adds a secondary fire that shoots a incendiary bomb that explodes on contact.POWERS :  Powers can only be upgraded by finding speacial Ki Crystals in each level , most can be found without much hassle but  this rewards exploration.These powers are structured like a tree branching in two different directions and can only be upgraded in order.There are four powers that each have two different branched paths that have two upgrades for a total of 4 upgrades each.I excluded the root upgrade because that is what unlocks each power , so five each counting that.You can upgrade everything if you have enbough KI Crystals.Example: (POWER) Protection once unlocked using a KI Crystal you can spend further KI Crystals going for increased protection and/or protection from all types of attacks and shield coverage.SKILLS : Skills can be upgraded using Karma point's. You get Karma points by doing well in combat and getting bonusus and also from hidden fountains of blood (These aren't too hard to find and some are not hidden).There are alot of skills and these can either boost some of the powers or add things like sword techniques and extra stamina/speed/health. There are some cool ones like being able to use the heads from certain enemies that shoot lasers from it eyes.REPLAY:Game has a New game plus mode too.:)Game has a survival mode (Have not tried it yet , will update if I have anything to add)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 30, 2015
												This juvenile pre-remake for Shadow Warrior set in the 80s starts strong and the implementation of sword play works nicely with the special abilities that you gain and use through button combinations (like in a fighting game). Unfortunately the fun level doesn't rise but rather stagnates as you go through waves of the same enemies over and over again. I kept wishing there was some way to do combos like in 'Darkness 2' or 'Bioshock', and also some finishing moves would have been nice. The other thing missing is the stealth element, in the original game you could become invisible and choose when to attack a pack of baddies...hence the title of the game. Here you have to kill everyone in an orderly fashion to open the doors that lead you to the next part of the level (effectively annihilating any replay value). Still the game looks great if not entirely original - sometimes I felt I was playing 'RAGE' or 'CALL of DUTY' with a sword- it's fast and furious speed is noteworthy. In a way it falls shy of greatness, although there are 17 chapters, there are only 14 levels (and 3 bosses) and only 3 different enviromments (Japanese villa/town and forest/cemetery, Shipyard, and mountain lab/castle) clocking around 20h on HARD for a first playthrough. Maybe one day we'll get more Wang with a cool DLC but the fortune cookie says it's doubtful at this point in time.PS: There's a survival mode with 3 levels but no multiplayer all. Sniff.PPS: Whatever happened to the black and white twin sisters?

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I'm not exactly sure how I feel about this game. There are many things I enjoyed about it, but it kept leaving me with a bad taste. I was initially surprised with how beautiful the graphics are, but the themes bored me very quickly for some reason. The combat is focused around your katana, which is fun at first, but too much melee will quickly give you a headache. The characters are funny, but they are given too few lines. The bigger story that they wanted to tell is pure garbage and completely failed to motivate me. The ending was predictable, but it still offered me no closure whatsoever. So, you kill every character that was even slightly developed, just to revive someone with no meaning whatsoever. Who is she again and why is she worth it? Something about rain? Was I supposed to care? I felt like the villain by the end. Characters looked at me with sad eyes as I was killing everything, hurting them while they did nothing to me, all of it over something I completely failed to understand. Shadow Warrior is original enough to stand out, and produced well enough to be good, but not great. You can play it, if you want a good fix of FPS. You're not going to make memories, though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 31, 2015
What I expectedI've been looking for a modern adaption of a fast paced, oldschool first-person shooter, comparable to Painkiller or Serious Sam.What I got+- Story: For a game of this niche the story is surprisingly entertaining. The basic idea: A man gets drawn into the conflict between demon lords and in pursuit of a legendary sword gets the power to not only save his world, but to also change the fate of their shadowy realm.There are a couple of nice looking comic sequences in which the background story is revealed piece by piece, where your sometimes a bit annoying companion becomes a more interesting character over time. Not bad!- Combat System: Fast and responsive. Melee is a big component and you unlock different swordstrikes over time. You have some magic spells (healing, stun, damage) and some enemies require different tactics.- Character System: You have three areas to improve; skills, magic and weapons. Each require a different currency to unlock. There certainly is some room for individual choices so it's not just a feature without purpose.- Presentation/Physics: Even two years after release, the game is still looking well enough. Enemies can be cut to pieces, burned or pushed away, some objects can be broken. The weapons feel strong and give a good impression of power in the game world.- Sound/Music: Just well made. Weapons and enemies sound good, music is decent - a few tracks with asian or jazz influence are even good. Can't complain.- Humour: It didn't make me break down laughing and did not send my sides into orbit. But still, the occasional Wang joke or light hearted comment was certainly good to keep the spirits high during the more repetitive moments of the game.- Hidden extras: Join the old-school fun when looking for the most inconspicuous places. Exploration is well rewarded with money (for weapons) and an XP like currency for skills. Contains some references to the original game aswell.- Difficulty: The highest setting "insane" felt just right for me as an experienced gamer. Enemies are dangerous and you have to be on your toes not to be surrounded my smaller minions or charged to death by the dreaded berserkers. Still, quicksave and the manual healing ability make every fight winnable. Even though you spend some time each fight just running away and healing yourself it still feels way better than those auto healing mechanics.+-- Weapons: Nothing really creative or particulary interesting. Katana, Revolver, SMG, Crossbow, Shotgun, Flamethrower, Rocket Launcher, Demon Heart, Demon Head. Each weapon can undergo at least one interesting change via upgrade.- Level design: Almost a negative point, if not for some beautiful places and those sometimes well hidden extras.Every now and then you re-visit areas that look very similar to other ones. Could be more diverse. Most fights have an arena like feeling where enemies are spawning until you've killed them all and the door to the next area opens.- Enemies: Nicely designed, some require special tactics. They get repetitive over time though. A plus are the big boss battles, although they all play VERY similar. Cool design though.- Characters: Not many interesting characters, which only develop over time. Doesn't take itself too seriously though, which avoids mindnumbing stereotypes.-- Repetitiveness: Consider this as a huge point. Some areas really feel drawn out, thanks to the arena fights and repetitive level design. There have been a couple of places where I was plain bored.- Bugs: I fell through the floor a couple of times and you can die when dashing down stairs. Minor annoyance.My perspectiveI've been pursuing this hobby since the mid 90s. My favorite genres are Strategy games, RPGs and (increasingly less) FPS. I also enjoy the occasional platformer, adventure or other indi game.I like competitive elements in online games, but without the social component of hanging out with friends I'd often prefer offline titles.

content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												This is one of the most fun games I've played in a long time. Shifting around the battlefield slicing up enemies with a magic katana couldn't have been executed better than in this game, though I wished there was more enemy variety. The game has lots of guns too, but aside from the revolver I don't find them that enjoyable. Graphically, the game is pretty good too, but it does lag in big areas with lots of enemies (although this is just my old computer hissing).There's lots of easter eggs and secrets, and after every battle you will be rated on how original/good it was, so there's enough to do for the completionist.Soundwise, it's pretty normal for a game. Somehow you can hear bullets impacting in enemies that are a hundred meters away, and other sounds are nothing special.Overall, I recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of shooters like Serious Sam and anyone who likes games with swords, like Chivalry or even Skyrim. The katana is one of the most fun weapons I've used in any game ever.My rating: 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												Probably the best reboot of an older shooter to date.Rise Of The Triad is more of a new coat of paint on top of the original than a reboot, which is fine (except for those stupid hitscan enemies and first-person platforming segments) but Shadow Warrior has almost nothing in common with the old game except the name of the protagonist and sword-fighting.I want to say right away the sword-fighting is the best I've ever seen in a FPS. Most times I don't even bother with the sparse selection of guns because it's so much more satisfying to play with the game's simple combo system of pressing a directional key twice and then left or right mouse to use a sword attack or special move that knocks down or immobilizes enemies. Chaining together combinations will give you more points to use in a XP system for more moves, but will also make it more likely enemies will power-up themselves. It's a nice on the fly difficulty curve.The original game was notorious for being borderline racist thanks to the protagonist Lo Wang's broken English quips. That's been thankfully cut out and replaced with some genuinely funny back-and-forths between Lo and a mask-wearing demon who follows him. And even better, a reoccurring joke fans of a certain Monty Python movie will love.There is very little I can fault this game for ‚Äì the shooting and sword-fighting is awesome, it looks nice, the difficulty feels just right, it's more violent than Peter Jackson's Dead Alive, it's hilarious, and there's a new game plus mode so you can max out Lo's skills and weapon upgrades.FPS of the year 2013 right here folks.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												I'll have to say, it is probably the best game I had the pleasure of playing this year.Graphics :As a whole, I can say that the graphics for this game were more than decent. Sure, they are not the best, but they make it up with style and gore. The way enemies blow up or get cut into pieces is so satisfying to watch that it never got old throughout my entire playthrough.I'll have to mention, that the cutscenes and animations were great and quite enjoyable. It is rare to see a "comic book" style cutscene done so well.Gameplay:This has to have been one of the most satisfying FPS experience I had in ages. The guns felt brutal and the swordplay is just amazing. The fact, that you can dismember your enemies in so many ways is quite joyful and gives style.Not only, this game has interesting weapons, but Ki powers which add quite a punch to the main character.Story:Although the story is quite simple, I did enjoy it. The characters are a blast and fun to watch talk, argue and taunt each others. Conclusion:This game is for anyone who wants a visceral FPS with alot of action and some somewhat raunchy humour. I truly wish, they will be more games like this in the next years.
