Posted: December 23, 2013
												This game is... amazing. Really. The story is solid enough for what it's supposed to do, which is to give you an excuse to murder lots of stuff. Don't expect to get the likes of Bioshock Infinite in it's regards of story telling and plot twisting, it's the clear winner there. Where Shadow Warrior however is the clear winner is the gun and sword play. More specificly that both of it is perfectly viable. I used the fancy katana moves with it's combos about as much, if not even more than the guns in this game, because it's just so much damn fun to take apart your enemies with all kinds of sword slices. On top of that you also get some powers which allow you to heal or do a shockwave to push enemies back. If you are looking for a nice FPS experience and put gameplay before story, then get this game. Did I mention that the graphics are pretty goo too? So umm... yeah. If you want to shoot stuff to bits, get this.

												Shadow Warrior does exactly what it should. It's an ode to the authentic shooter genre like we've known it from Duke Nukem, Serious Sam or the original Shadow Warrior. Shadow Warrior is a surprise that remains interesting 'til the credits start rolling. The humor and story will keep your attention from dwindling, but the gameplay can get repetitive at times. content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												This game has everything I'd want in a game amoungst the sea of copy-paste cookie cutter shooters we've become used too. This game doesn't take itself seriously, and that allows it to work in  humor and satisfying gameplay that will likely have me missing important meetings and deadlines. Diologue is witty and precise, self referencial and bizzare. It may be said that the maps are generic (as are the enemies), but it's wrapped up smoothly with smooth and easy to use gameplay and controls that makes cutting through hordes of identical demons a thing of joy. I would recommend having a higher end computer (there's only so many blood particles a proccessor can handle), but the game is still functional with minimum  requirements. In short, the game has a few flaws, but with a little work it could easily become a classic, something our generation of games very badly needs. 8/10

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												Shadow Warrior is a first person shooter/hack and slash game that places you in the shoes of Lo Wang who is a contractor for the mysterious organization ruled by Zilla.If you enjoyed games like Skyrim or Dark Messiah but are annoyed by fetch quests, and would much rather go out and dice demons apart using a katana and ancient spirtual powers, then this is the game for you!The shooting elements is very reminiscent of Doom 3 and other retro FPS's (back when you can carry all weapons instead of a primary and secondary) and while I acknowledge that as a good thing, the level design leaves much to be desire, due to it being very repetitive and to be honest, quite bland at times. The humor in this game is something definitely that should be made aware of, as it the kind of kick‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•here and drop F-bomb here while I‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•down your neck. Amidst the tacky humor actually lies an intricate tale of Asian type mythos that may spark some interest in some players.I bought this game when it was on sale for $9.99 and I think it was money well spent. If the price was any higher I probably would've been more reluctant in purchasing this game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												This is what Duke Nukem forever should have been. Very impressive 3D engine but be aware, it is very hard on the GPU. My 7970 frequently was 95% gpu usage. The combat is really well balanced with the swordplay being a standout from the rest of the FPS crowd. Gameplay is mostly old school with tried and true tested method of hordes of enemies one after the other. The enviroments are filled with plenty of variety with things to shoot and explode with very impressive graphical effects. You are able to take down enemies limb by limb disabling them firstly before finishing them off.Even amongst the big budget titles of today it still looks visually impressive. Gun Mechanics are good as well with a good variety of weapons with multiple upgrades and modifications on offer.There is also the odd easter eggs to find which reminds you of the old shadow warrior game from 1997. Seasoned gamers will be impressed by this. Unlike Duke Nukem forever, Shadow Warrior is a funny game with humour that actually works. You have a tag along demon character who is always giving his input on situations. At first i thought this was going to become a chore but further into the game i realised how well it was working and was keen to hear his next remark.Highly recommended and took me by surprise. Something different with that classic gameplay!

content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
												Seriously, this is the best straight-up shooter I've played in years for a whole bunch of different reasons. First, the running and gunning is top notch. All the weapons are fun and useful, though none moreso than the Katana, which makes the large rooms of monsters a blast to get through. Never once was I dreading another encounter with a horde of enemies like my outings in Serious Sam. Even the most ridiculously hard fights were absurdly fun. With the variety of enemies to fight, weapons, and special abilities that you unlock... there's nothing here that feels tacked on and useless.As an added bonus, the writing in this is way better than a straight-forward shooter deserves and the game so much better for it. The dialog is self-aware and genuinely funny. I legitamately cared about Lo Wang, a man who seems to actually enjoy the fact that his name is a‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•joke, and his wise-cracking and contemptuous demonic partner in crime, Hoji. Seriously, Shadow Warrior should be used as a case-study on how to do everything right with narrative design in an action game.An excellent ride, through and through and I cannot recommend this enough to any fan of old school FPS or just FPS in general.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												There was a lot of skepticism surrounding the news that 3D Realms' 1997 shooter Shadow Warrior would be re-imagined for 2013, not least because the original game faded into obscurity compared with other Build engine games and was really remembered only for its often tasteless humour. Happily, Polish developer Flying Wild Hog went back to the original and rather than slavishly remaking it, did a wonderful job in taking from it what worked and removing or radically re-imagining what didn't. The end result is a hectic, gorgeous-looking shooter in a classic style with just enough of a modern sensibility to make it feel fresh. The most crucial aspect of the game's success? It has what the classic '90s shooters had and what modern ones very rarely possess - personality.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												Don't look at the metascore for this one. This  is an old-school shooter with tight controls, satisfying gameplay, and a fantastic-looking environment. It's also full of crude humor and general oldschool machoness. Think Serious Sam or Duke Nukem, but with a lot more melee options. The gameplay is tight, you move fast, the enemies strafe and dodge your fire. The environments are detailed and feel realistic (as opposed to Seriouis Sam, where alleys look like football stadiums). The game is linear, but there are plenty of hidden gems and secrets to be found. It's also full of references to old school shooters.This game is gorgeous, even on low settings. But if you want higher fidelity you'd have to add a bit of heat to your graphics cards. Sometimes the enemies feel a bit repetitive or even bullet-spongey. The characters are maybe a bit too macho to be likeable, the same way that Bulletstorm's characters didn't really appeal to me.

content:
Posted: January 8, 2015
												So I loved the original Shadow Warrior.  It had a different premise, being that not many other games took place in the Oriental world, and the humor was great.  So of course I wanted to play the new Shadow Warrior.  In a nutshell, it was fun, but lacking in certain elements.First off, the swordfighting is a blast, and will probably be your main means of attack.  Lo Wang carries a katana around at all times, and although you do get access to a few guns, they aren't nearly as useful as the sword.  Once you learn the Wing of Crane ability, there's almost no need to use the guns, since that ability gives you a ranged attack.  When wielding the katana, you can slice and dice your enemies into bits, and it's all strangely satisfying.  You can also throw shurikens, but there's no reason as they aren't accurate or powerful at all.As for the guns, you get access to a pistol, submachine guns, crossbow, shotgun, flamethrower, and rocket launcher.  None of them are particularly useful though.  In addition, there are iron sights, yet the game is too faced paced to properly use them, plus the iron sights aren't as accurate as you would think.  I normally turn off crosshairs when possible, but I found that the iron sights are typically set below the crosshair, so take my advice and just keep the crosshair on and skip the iron sights.The game's visuals are just amazing, and there's not much else to say to describe them.  The developers did an amazing job capturing the atmosphere and feel of the land.  In addition, enemies will split apart when attacked with the katana, and can be mutilated in different ways. As you play, you'll earn both money and karma.  Money is used to upgrade your guns or buy ammo, the latter of which I've never needed to do once.  Karma is used to earn special powers, and can be considered the XP of the game.  Every time you level up, you'll earn a karma point, which can be traded in for skills such as fire protection, more powerful Ki attacks, or faster healing rates.Speaking of Ki, there are a lot of different Ki moves available.  Some of them deal out major damage, and others are used as supportive abiltiies, such as the starting healing ki.  All Ki moves are done by double tapping a movement key and pressing a mouse button.  For example, to heal, you press D twice and then the special key.  To do the lunging stab Ki attack, you press W twice, then the left mouse button (or whatever button it is to do the primary attack).  These are simple enough to do, which adds to the simplicity of the sword fighting.My biggest complaint about the game is the lack of true humor.  The original DOS Shadow Warrior was littered with small one liners that made you chuckle a bit.  I understand that they tried to be "politically correct", but in doing so, ruined the comedy of the game.  Yes, fortune cookies are lying around, mainly just used for quick humor, and those are great, but Lo Wang lacks any of the one liners that made him "famous" in the original game.  When doing Ki attacks, sometimes he'll say something, but it's always the same line, not pulled from a pool of recorded dialog.  For example, when doing the Shockwave ability, Lo Wang will always say "Pull my finger."  It may be funny the first time, but that's it.  If you use that ability a lot, you'll be hearing that quite often.Overall, it's definitely worth a play.  The gameplay is solid and fun, and that's really what makes the game.  The story is fairly confusing at first (at least to me), but the ending scenes do tie everything up quite nicely.  I just wish there was a bit more of the old-school humor in the game.

Posted: January 3, 2015
												Fast paced, arcade style shooter with a modern twist; upgradeable weapons, active skills and passive powers that you can customise throughout. Slapstick humour mixed with semi serious tones makes for a fun story if a bit grating towards the end. Sticks to the "annoying enemy" clich√© of arcade shooters with shrieking teleporting katana women, large necromancers that summon enemies and then cast shields around themselves and berserkers who can only be damaged from the back. There are sequences when multiple enemy types are thrown at you, which can really test your patience, so be prepared for that. Finally the hit detection feels slightly off, particularly in the boss battles. Regardless, a good experience overall.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												For fans of the older Doom-style shooters, Shadow Warrior will be a decent rush of nostalgic fun. The shooting is well done, with the action keeping a fast, flowing pace throughout. The weapons aren't as fun as some of the old style shooters, however, they're all fairly bland, with the katana being the most fun to use. The swordplay is surprisingly visceral, although you will sometimes slice through an enemy and almost nothing will happen, the enemies more often are either sliced to pieces, or react as if they had been hit by an actual sword. The story is coherent and interesting enough to keep the game together, but it's so tonally different from the gameplay that it often pushes you out of the experience. The two main characters do have a nice back-and-forth, with some of their dialogue actually making me laugh. The enemies however, get a bit repetitive, you fight the same 6 or 7 enemies during the entire game, and in the last few chapters, it finally gets a bit too repititive, and the combat stops being fun almost completely. The bosses are also fairly boring, Shadow Warrior doing the big impressive boss thing that telegraphs their attacks so far in advance you'd think they were trying to let you win, with the amount of health and ammo scattered around during these fights, they're just too easy. The ending is also a bit disappointing. TL;DR: A fun rush of slightly repetitive violence with an okay story and a couple of interesting characters.Edit: It's also fairly pretty.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Shadow Warrior is a 3D hack-n-slash where you fend off thousands of demons while following blinking objectives. There is no mini-map, instead objectives are highlighted and blinking (doors & switches). The game has a few different difficulty settings. I played on casual and only died a couple of times due to gravity. The fights never seemed boring and I felt like I could still die if I wasn't careful. I can imagine some of the fights taking alot longer on a harder difficulty. Overall, the gameplay is solid, the story is fun, and the length of the game is good. I don't think I will be re-playing this title for a few months or so but I do feel like I will come back to it again in the future. If you can pick this game up on sale like I did, it will be totally worth it.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
												I'm not exactly sure how I feel about this game. There are many things I enjoyed about it, but it kept leaving me with a bad taste. I was initially surprised with how beautiful the graphics are, but the themes bored me very quickly for some reason. The combat is focused around your katana, which is fun at first, but too much melee will quickly give you a headache. The characters are funny, but they are given too few lines. The bigger story that they wanted to tell is pure garbage and completely failed to motivate me. The ending was predictable, but it still offered me no closure whatsoever. So, you kill every character that was even slightly developed, just to revive someone with no meaning whatsoever. Who is she again and why is she worth it? Something about rain? Was I supposed to care? I felt like the villain by the end. Characters looked at me with sad eyes as I was killing everything, hurting them while they did nothing to me, all of it over something I completely failed to understand. Shadow Warrior is original enough to stand out, and produced well enough to be good, but not great. You can play it, if you want a good fix of FPS. You're not going to make memories, though.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2014
												Playtime: 16 Hours (includes secret hunting)Score: 7 / 10Recommended Price: $19.99A remake of the classic Shadow Warrior featuring still the character Lo Wang. It is easy to see that much effort went into blending modern and classic FPS styles. Medkits still litter the levels yet you have the ability to heal yourself at will with a Chi spell unlocked early in the game. Many people will remember the humour of the first game and it is still here, although at a toned down level. Much of the hilarious one liners and jokes are gone or purposefully changed to lower potentional insult certain people might feel and make vocal. Secret areas do exist and are done up in the classic Shadow Warrior pixel graphics. Areas from old levels and pixel-based girls await your discovery!Much of the combat focuses on the use of your sword, which I found to be a huge plus. There is an assortment of weapons as one would expect in classic FPS titles with three different upgrades each. Different Chi-based abilities help you fight your foes. Two skills knock down or suspend foes in the air, various katana abilities help you fight at range or slay foes in a circle around you. All in all I was highly impressed and surprised at how good the overall game was in both quality and length. If you can pick it up on sale for $19.99 or less it's definitely worth it!

												Now this game is pretty great dont get me wrong, the gun play is great, the sword play is phenominal (at first i thought the sword was going to be "that melee weapon that you use when you have no ammo" in these kind of games) but i find myself using the sword alot more so then even the guns (which i still think have a good feel to them especially the shotgun and crossbow). The problem with it though for me is some of the odd things in the game, like how there are a couple diffculty spikes in the game, and one of the sword attacks called Iron Circle (allows you to swing your sword in a circle, to kill the enemies around you) seems like it doesnt do enough damage to take down or even severaly damage the that surround you, leading you to do the attack again, just swing your sword wildly for a more direct approch, or take out your machine gun and spin in a circle instead. Overall, its a pretty good game despite all this, funny dialog by your protagonist Lo Wang, Music in the game is amazing and really brings you into the atmosphere of the game. Id give this game a 9/10.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 15, 2014
												An absolutely fantastic game, a must-have for any FPS enthusiast. Shadow Warrior has it all: great graphics, awesome weapons, blood-pumping soundtrack, fast-paced action, hidden collectibles, one-liners, and a surprisingly good sense of humor. Even with the fast-paced combat, explosions, and the hail of bullets you'll be sending towards the enemy, that's not the best part. The best part of Shadow Warrior is the sword-play which combined with the supernatural powers you get is done surprisingly well. The game has great features such as a quick-slash, shuriken throwing, and consumable weapons like the demon head and heart. To keep things interesting, all weapons are upgradeable adn so are your powers. Even with all of the solid aspects of the game, it goes above and beyond with things that most games would have left out such as equippable skins for your sword, an ultra-hard final difficulty, new game plus, an arena mode, fortune cookies, and fully destructable bicycles.

content:
Posted: November 7, 2013
												Shadow Warrior is awesome!  Its made by the same devs who made Hard Reset, so they did a similar upgrade to the classic 90's formula for the modern generation.  This game has the best melee combat I've seen in an FPS too.  It has a genius control scheme that seamlessly combines Guns, Katana, and Ki power combat, using fighting game-style button combos to perform various Ki powered katana attacks and stand alone Ki attacks that can be used in parallel with the katana or guns.  There is also a sophisticated, multifaceted upgrade system to really customize the way you want to play the game.I can't recommend this game enough, buy it now, especially while its still on sale!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2014
												As much as I enjoyed the gunplay - shredding demons into bloody gibs is very satifying indeed I was totally frustrated by ridiculous hand-holding and invisible walls as well as inability to backtrack to explore. This is just infuriating.Pros:+ Really satisfying gunplay+ Somewhat funny one liners+ More or less not-a-bad story+ Graphics is also goodCons:- Inability to backtrack (doors are closed not only in front of you, but behind you. Doors you should be able to open, but for some reason you can't)- Invisible walls EVERYWHERE- Ridiculous skill spikes. I think the most hard battle was not a boss fight, but a fight with mere two Berserkers.- Finding secrets is not very satisfying as they are "hidden" in plain view. But you miss some of them because finding them sometimes implies checking where there is an Invisible wall and where there is not. It's just boring.- Complex system of skills/powers/upgrades is not very useful. I predict healing from Ki and katana strikes. Demons die faster just from WW-M1. Stamina is useful though. I have troubles with deciding what to pick for Kis and Karma beginning from chapters 7-8 because I equally DON'T need everything I don't have.- Same goes with weapons. I found the Shotty and Flamer to be quite redundant.All in all, it might be fine for someone who is looking for a shooty-blowy shooter and does not feel the urge to search every level through. If you like to rummage areas for loot I think you will be as much frustrated as I am right now.But at least it's not as bad as Duke Nukem Forever, so I guess that counts.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
												Took me about 9 hours to beat this game on normal difficulty.Overall, this is now one of my favorite action games. It's like a fun version of Red Steel. It's also somewhat similar in feel to Bulletstorm (and others have made that comparison), but I found it to be more fun than Bulletstorm primarily due to the sword-based and fluid combat. It's fun-ness comes primarily from the responsive, fast-paced, empowering gameplay. You quickly discover, right from the start of the game, how powerful all of your attacks are against the scores of enemies you encounter (unlike other action games where enemies just soak up damage). Also, the way the sword works is very satisfying - I can't think of a more fun implementation of first-person melee combat. Combined with the cool powers, it makes for a very over-the-top, violent, but pleasantly challenging game. Also, you would normally expect an action game to skimp on the writing, voice acting, and overall story, but this game provides humorous and ocasionally thoughtful writing and voice work and presents an interesting and unique story.I definitely recommend this if you know you like action / FPS games. It's kind of a hybrid because you can use a sword and guns, but you'll probably end up enjoying it if you like either.

												one of my favorite new games of the year . kick‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•from start to finish ( i guess not quite there : but close :D ) not a short play . unless of coarse your a runner and do not try to find all the coin and treasures, but runners beware the 3 way upgrade system depends on finding as many of these as you can if you hope to conquer higher levels . 16 hours in and on the last 2 levels , the only thing i could say that would make this game greater would be the addition of coop and multiplayer ability . then the game would rule ! i would love to see a Sequel .pros: multi weapon system (its not all Sword Fighting) 3 way upgrade system depends on 3 seperate collectable's in game to upgrade your charector . i really like this setup :D , navigation is pretty good few areas highlighting POI's isnt usefull to your mission.lots of bonus Karma for multikills , tons of blood shed . Replayablility cons: No DLC :p No Coop ,No MP , navigation for some missions where you had to back track to your final area has to be done on memory as no map or directional targeting available . achievements require you to play easy difficulty : ( a bit insulting to those of us who do not like to even play normal :p need more demons to fight i sent them all back to the dark realm in pieces :Pall in all a 8 out of 10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2016
												After first playthrough on normal difficultyPros:- Story is funny while not being overly crude or juvenile (despite the number of‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•jokes)- Charcterisation is good even if the characters aren't insanely deep- The plot is a good mix of both comedy and tragedy- Having the dash move really makes combat fun since you can dodge enemy melee attacks and get in and out of sword range really quickly- Game is fairly lengthy - my playthrough took nearly 12 hours and I didn't really stop to try and find secrets either. There is also a NG+ option.- Weapons are fun and upgrades enhance and transform the way they can be used- Runs really well- Some environments look greatCons:- Enemies repeat alot - there are about 6 or so main enemy types that get used throughout the whole game. You've seen pretty much every enemy by the 2/3 though mark and those enemies get thrown at you throughout the entire game.Towards the end they just take a bunch of the hardest enemies and put them in the arenas together and repeat them in waves so fights can end up feeling the same.- Maybe its just me but the constant arena after arena style of gameplay caused some pacing issues for me. You'll get out of a massive multi-wave fight and then you'll be in another one not very long after.- Finding keys and destroying colour coded shrines to open doors isn't really my bag - but alot aren't really hidden so you don't need effort to find them - so why have the plater search for them at all?- Bosses are few and far between and can be underwhelming. You basically shoot the weakpoint then shoot the weakppoint underneath the weakpoint.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												I'm surprised with how much I enjoyed Shadow Warrior. I knew that I would probably enjoy it because I love old-school styled first person shooters, but it surpassed my expectations. Don't get me wrong, it's not a masterpiece or anything more than your simple shooter, but it really is an expertly done return to the exploration and chaos of older FPS games.The gameplay consists of two main aspects, combat and exploration. The combat, like all old-school FPS games, is fast paced and chaotic. It throws a lot of enemies at you at the same time, which demands quick reflexes and projectile dodging. Lots of little things really make the combat work, like you move a bit faster than your average modern game hero and you aren't retricted to holding only two weapons at a time, you hold an arsenal of varied weapons by the end of the game. It's a nice change of pace from the combat of a lot of recent shooters, namely cover based shooting. Not that there is anything wrong with that style of combat, it's just fresh to return to circle-strafing and blasting away large hordes of monsters with a dozen different weapons. The katana in particular is a joy to use, as it dynamically cuts off the body parts that you sliced and is also relatively powerful; it's really the star of the combat in this game. Another thing that really makes the combat is the upgrade system. You have to save up three different resources to level up Lo Wang as you play: money, karma, and ki crystals which level up your weapons, skills, and powers respectively. These can really change the way that you can handle enemy encounters, like being able to use a slain demon's head to defeat more powerful foes or being able to use your katana from a distance with a light beam attack. At the end of each enemy encounter, you're given a score out of five based on how well you did in the fight. It gives you karma bonuses if you used a variety of attacks and weapons instead of just spamming the same attacks over and over. That alone, if you follow it, makes sure the combat doesn't get too old too quickly. The exploration in this game breaks up the combat nicely giving the game a nice roller-coaster like pace. After you defeat all the enemies in an area, you're encouraged to scour it for hidden secrets which will reward you with resources required to upgrade your powers, weapons or skills. The combat, levelling, and exploration and tie together perfectly to create very satisfying and fun gameplay.I was also surprised by the look of the game. While the graphics are not exceptionally good, the asian art style really helped the game stand out visually from others. Levels are filled with pagodas, candles, Buddha statues, bamboo, samurai armour displays, it really does look unique for a shooter. There are also a tonne of little details to notice throughout the game, like how enemies fall apart after you slice them up. Each chapter of the game also has a different look to it, keeping you from getting tired of looking at the same types of areas. The comic book cutscenes that divide each chapter of the game are also visually interesting, if a bit cliched at this point.The story of the game also surprised me in that it was actually interesting. Again, I'm not saying that it's fantastic, but for an old-school styled first person shooter, whose stories are usually given no thought at all, it was a welcome surprise. The real stand out writing-wise was the game's humour. Dialouge during the story bits is funny, albeit in a very immature way, and Lo Wang will spit out so-bad-they're-good one-liners during combat. The secrets can also be funny with a lot of references to the original Shadow Warrior.For all the good things I have to say about Shadow Warrior, there isn't much bad. I only have three real, but minor complaints. One, with the katana being so much fun to use, the guns seam very boring by comparison, but that's only because they really nailed the katana. Two, I played this game on the hardest difficutly and I only died a handful of times. Some more challenge would be appreciated, especially for an old-school shooter. Finally three, the levels are a bit linear for an old-school shooter, you won't find Duke Nukem 3D or Doom styled non-linearity level exploration here which I feel was a missed opportunity.However, you're supposed to judge things based on what they are and not what you want them to be. I really enjoyed playing Shadow Warrior and was surprised by how well it was done. Granted, I have not played the original Shadow Warrior at the time of me writing this, but regardless, as a stand alone game, Shadow Warrior is very much worth playing through if you liked fast paced, old-school action.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2015
												I'm really new to the Shadow Warrior genre and I just bought it during a steam sale.My first experience with the game and my take on it.+ Astoundingly beautiful graphics.+ Delicious gore.+ Very original and cool weapon designs.+ Lots of easter eggs, secrets and funny tidbits you can find when exploring the world around you.+ Very fast-paced combat, always keeps you on your toes.+ Wang.+ Very nice artwork and environmental effects. Everything around you is a freaking deathtrap if you're not careful.+ Very nice blend of horror, thriller, suspense and action.Now for the cons.- The head and weapon bobbing makes me a little nauseous. I wish there was an option to turn that off.- The lighting in some are blinding and frustrating to navigate to.- Some of the control schemes just don't make sense to me. Like the regeneration skill. Constantly pushing "D" makes you move while healing, which can be convenient at times but there are some cases where you don't want to go in the direction you're trying to heal yourself in.- Motion blur is going to make me sick. I'm normally used and accustomed to FPS games  but this one just makes me wanna puke after playing for hours for some reason, something that most FPS games do not induce on me.- The death count: Seriously, don't be like GTA or other games that reminds players how many times they messed up in the game. I'm a perfectionist so I had to delete my old save data just to start fresh and go for a no death run.- There are times where Wang is just trying too hard to be funny. The accent is a little bit thick for an asian too.- Lo Wang is not even a japanese name. I don't know Wang's backstory but when I started the game, I assumed he was Japanese. If so, disregard this.- Experienced my first death when I misread the health number and thought it read 12 when it actuallity, it was written as "92". I panicked and ran all over the place, got mobbed and died.Overall, my score for this game is an honest 8/10.Will try to shoot vending machine and dying again.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2015
												What a fantastic game. Very fun and worth the money if you can grab it for <$20. I wouldn't recommend this game if you dislike the "feel" of something like Ninja Gaiden where you see pretty much every enemy you'll fight all game within the first half of the main story. It follows the convention of just throwing more of the same enemies at you instead of different enemies. I'm perfectly fine with that but I can see why it could make others pass it up. The last few chapters become incredibly drudging however. In one section you're forced to fight two very fast and very strong minibosses at once with a vision handicap, and then they do it again in the next chapter, and AGAIN in the chapter after that. Some parts can feel very cheap and some of the mechanics as well. I found myself constantly using the Wing of Crane move because it was so damn good, but I rarely ever used the Flux or Shockwave skills. Some of the guns are fantastically good like the crossbow, but others are absolute garbage like the pistol. Pretty much everything in this game is hit-and-miss, but most of the time the positives highly outweigh the negatives, most of the time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												I don't get it... Why do you waste your time on reading this "review"? Instead you should buy this game right now and experience it for yourself. No seriously! Stop reading! Buy it, play it and enjoy it! NOW!This game is freakin' awesome!Ok... since you're already here, I'm tellin' ya why reading this is a waste of time, when you could already start playing one of the finest games developed in 2013 (or was it 2014? well who cares...?).It's a good old run-and-gun-(and-hack-and-slay)-shooter, that doesn't want you cowering behind some kind of convenient placed barrier, from where you can calmly shoot your enemies one by one. Instead you're forced to stay in motion. Otherwise the enemie's projectiles will kill you faster than a dive into a volcano... You're slicing thousands of demons with your Katana, u're nailing them to the wall with ur crossbow (Painkiller and F.E.A.R. send their regards), u're burning them with your flame thrower until they scream in agony and then you blow'em to pieces with ur 4-barreled shotgun (it has 4 barrels after u've upgraded it (which you should)). It's bloody and gory and soooo rewarding and satisfying in doing so. In addition to this u gain some magic powers. For example you'll be able to let your foes float defenseless in the air for a very few seconds, so you can shoot them like they were some kind of "meat pinatas" as LoWang states, when u're using this power.The story is maybe a little convuluted but nevertheless very interesting. It's also presented in a very beautiful way: while the present (which is appearantly the late eighties or early nineties) is shown directly in ingame cutscenes (95% from your point of view), the backstory is presented in some kind of 3D cartoon. It's a very fine crafted single player (only) shooter that'll keep you longer on your toes, than those average 5-hour-hogwash-pseudo-military-shooters... It took me roughly 20 hours to complete the campaign (the first time).The only thing I regret, is the fact, that I bought it when it was on sale. I didn't want to pay the full price for a remake of a nineties game after I had to suffer through travesties like DNF. Flying Wild Hog deserves better though. I would have been happier, if I would have paid the full price. Gearbox should take note on how to make proper old school games.Now buy the game already!

												The intro is just plain awesome. Seriously, even if you don't play the game it's worth watching. The sense of humor seen in the intro pervades the entire game, although somewhat sparsely.  That brings me to my main issue with this game, which is something that Bioshock Infinite struggled with as well - having combat sequences occur far too frequently and last far too long. The gameplay involving sword fighting and combat in general are great, but the endless waves of enemies quickly grow tiring. The good parts of the game would shine much more if only the combat was cut down a bit.The story has a strong hook in the beginning but I eventually found myself not caring much after running around on a wild goose chase. So in retrospect I really should have just played the first hour or two and stopped there.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2014
												As a hardcore gamer (albeit one who was not permitted to play the 1997 original by his parents), I was very pleasantly surprised by this game.   The story is a little incoherent at first, but becomes interesting through the inclusion of an unique companion character (who has a lot of smart‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•comments to make) and carries you all the way through.  There are a string of solid "Wang" jokes scattered throughout, and as I understand it, the modern Lo Wang is nothing like the potty-mouth of the 90's.If you had asked me beforehand, I never would have figured that the combat system in Shadow Warrior would be fun to use and interesting--typically, sword/magic/gun games are all kinds of awkward, forcing the gamer to default to gunplay as he or she suffers their way through the game, chasing the next bit of dialog.  Not the case here.  All three aspects of combat have a place, especially as the difficulty level is cranked, and it'll teach even the most experienced gamers a few new tricks about crowd control and resource management.  When things really start to click, the game rewards the player with a great feeling of being devastatingly powerful--a great carrot to chase, and something few developers do well.Highly recommend--ignore the Metacritic score and give this a shot.  If you make it through the intro where the game basically drop-kicks you into its irreverent take on a generic Asian mythology story about a sword, you'll love the next 15 hours or so.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 14, 2014
												General Overview: If you hated Borderlands or Borderlands 2 because of its off color humor you will hate Shadow Warrior as the humor is beyond Borderlands - but if you can tolerate or even enjoy slightly immature and grin and bear it humor, then this game is a great one to play. Well written dialogue, a decent story, solid shooting, well done sound, incredible graphics and smooth game play make this a shooter that is worthy of the Shadow Warrior name as a reboot and if you like shooters this is one you should pick up.TL;DNR: 8.5: A humorous over the top shooter, tons of loot, hidden secrets, decent story, great action and solid game play with beautiful graphics make this a shooter for those with a sense of humor and desire for lots of combat. Sound is great, soundtrack is fitting and there is never a dull moment.Technology/engine: 9: super smooth execution although a number of loading screens that are placed in such a way as to not be annoying and keeps the graphical fidelity high and controls responsive.AI: 8: Serviceable but a bit predictable but when the individual AIs of the mobs get mixed it gets intense and is enjoyable.Graphics: 10: Gorgeous sets, great character models, wonderful animations, great cut scenes and great use of 2D cut scenes for memories. Flying Hog deserves high marks for the graphics used in this game.Sound: 8: Sound effects are well done but occasional source to reception issues can be found in the game that prevent you from spotting the source at a longer distance. Otherwise its a solid ambient soundscape that creates immersion and adds to the game.Soundtrack: 9: Great music throughout, I especially liked the unnerving heavy metal on the appearance of the black rabbit - one of the funniest and weirdly frightening moments that was totally unexpected in the game.Voice acting: 9: Solid cheesy delivery and poignant when needed or appropriate.Crafting: N/ACustomization: 9: Customization includes various powers, skills and weapon customization all of which are rewarding and make a difference in the game.Game play systems: 9: Really well mixed variety of weapons and abilities and the game scales with a difficulty spike if you are just ripping through. A number of the fights almost feel unfair until you find a technique to deal with the situation and the tools are always there.Controls: 8: Slightly awkward controls that are occasionally unresponsive or do something other than what was intended - ie D-D-RMB is supposed to heal you but will occasionally perform the RMB function of the weapon - which can kill you of course. Perhaps when it comes out for consoles it will function better (although I hate to play shooters on console - prefer mouse and keyboard). Other than that it functions well.Story: 9: I was surprised at the quality of the story, the great use of humor and the still poignant tale that is weaved into over the top violence and silliness that really, somehow, works well.Multiplayer: N/A

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												This shooter has a cool setting and balanced feeling mechanics (including a fun melee system). Pick it up if you are after something a bit more old school.A pretty game with smart level design and mechanics. Flying Wild Hog have clearly learnt from Hard Reset, this time doing away with the flaky weapon system and adding some cool melee and spellcasting mechanics to add some variety. The awesome (but lighthearted) setting really adds a lot to the game, and improves a lot upon the dark and boring generic not-really-cyberpunk sci-fi theme from Hard Reset. Some talented artists have been given an opportunity to flex their muscles here, with some truly spectacular art (especially in the first level).The melee and spell based combat system is nice, despite some strange key combinations needed to access them. The ability to heal means the game doesn't leave you stuck without enough health if you've missed a few health packs, but can remove some of the tension from combat. The melee system is nice and fits in well with the guns. You learn new moves as you progress, so tedium is avoided. But it can make guns feel less useful.Levels can still feel very boxed in and limited compared to games like Serious Sam, and many of the secrets tend to be pretty boring. The guns can lack the authentic feel and kick you might be familiar with.But otherwise, Shadow Warrior is a good effort at making more of an old school feeling FPS, with skill based, bombastic combat making up for most of the failings.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												I never played the original Build engine game of Shadow Warrior, but this is what Duke Nukem Forever should have been - an awesome reboot bringing back the gameplay values of its era powered by a modern engine.The implementation is a little like the Serious Sam series, but don't let that put you off if, like me, you're not a fan. It's a series of semi-technical combat 'arenas' in which you need to choose your weapons and tactics carefully so as not to be overwhelmed, joined together by explore-and-lewt sections, but Shadow Warrior seems to pull it all together a lot better than other games of the same ilk. The story is.. just ok.. for the majority of the game, but it rounds it out and sets the mood well enough to make it feel as though you have a purpose beyond go-there-kill-everything-repeat.Not that that would be a big problem - the combat is immensely satisfying, with the game offering a large variety of ways to blow up, burn, electrify, perforate, and slice and dice the reasonably varied set of lesser and greater demons that you'll run into. You always have a few options on how to tackle a given situation, and throughout the game you'll be upgrading your sword skills, Chi powers, and less-up-close-and-personal weaponry to increase them.The game also features a few boss battles which, although a little samey, make for a nice change of pace from the frantic melee of the rest of the game.Hard difficulty recommended if you're a regular fps player - the difficulty paces pretty well, and by the time you're hitting the stiffer challenges of the later levels you should be good enough to whoop them if you've invested a bit of time in hunting down some of the secret xp-stashes that are lying about. Learn the special moves and make sure you've got your dodge key bound and you'll be kicking demon backside.TLDR; had a blast - play this if you like to chop things up with a sword while listening to corny 'wang' jokes.LO WANG / 10

content:
Posted: February 8, 2015
												Frustrating enemies and length undermine what could have been a short and sweet retro-nostalgia-ride.  Takes the best of old-school shooters with a dash of light rpg (namely experience and progression).  However, this game overstayed its welcome by a good 8+ hours.   By the end of it, I was praying for it to be the last level... for the last 1/4 of the game, actually.I did play on insanity difficulty.  On this difficulty, bosses can be very tedious and time consuming.  Taking nearly 30 minutes to bring some of them down.  If it weren't for quick-save, I'd likely have thrown my computer through the wall. Swordplay is ok.  Since the game overstayed its welcome, it began to feel pretty stale and by the numbers towards the end.  Similarly, the story and tone were novel at first, but the inside-jokes and juvenile humor couldn't stay fresh all the way to the end.If the charging demons were tweaked so they couldn't turn on a dime or follow you forever (these were probably the most frustrating enemies I've dealt with in a videogame in years).  And boss fights were more engaging.  And the overall length of the campaign reduced by about 20%... then this would be a near pitch perfect throw-back game! 5.5/10

content:
Posted: April 24, 2015
												This game is just ridiculously damn fun. Take a pseudo-ninja, a katana, a bunch of fire weapons, lot of humor and throw all this into a mixer along with brainless demons and you will have Shadow Of Warrior.The game is all about torning demons into pieces by any means with spectacular graphical effects.This FPS feels like the old, classic PC shooters: gameplay is fast, frenetic and "act-now-or-die!" genre. Infact, if played at highest difficulty, you will have a hard time remaining alive while facing hordes of demons.To help your slaughter you will find weapons of any sort and also will develop a set of skills that will aid you in combat: unique looking katana special moves that tear apart all the stupid demons surrounding you, generate wave of energy that spread from your blade and kills from distance, powerful blows that overcomes any protection and some defensive skills too, like healing and a ki-energy shield.The skills are a lot and during the course of the game you will have to make choices because you don't have enough ability points to take them all.The graphics is good and deep-customizable but some of the uber effects are really heavy on the GPU and CPU, so in the most populated encounters the framerate fluctuate a bit too much.Overall is a fantastic fun game that's worth buying and playing, especially if you can grab it while on-sale!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I pretty much got what I expected with this title - good old school PC FPS, and lots of it!The developers seemingly didn't wanna leave any boxes unchecked, and went all-in with powers (double tab a direction keys and press LMB or RMB), skills (permanent stat upgrade like more max health) and upgradeable weapons. Each category has its own resource - Money, KI crystals and karma. Lots of stuff is borrowed from other titles, but all things good imo. This is a lot like the "Darksiders" of FPS'es - a compilation of everthing that has proven to work in other titles.The basic FPS mechanics feel fairly solid and rewarding, but there's a certain undefinable something missing. I don't know if it's the visual/sonic feedback from hitting your target that's a bit "off" - but it simply didn't feel as tight as I've come to expect from the best FPS'es. I did experience some annoyances with the physics - dash while running down a flight of stairs and you just instantly die, and terrain climbing is awfully unintuitive - luckily you hardly have to do any, unless you're searching for secrets.The presentation is a hit and miss - The narration/dialogue is witty, and the voice acting fairly good. The sound effects decent, but some of the weapon sounds lacked personality. My biggest gripe was with the graphics - the textures and 3d models were at times pretty lackluster. Fortunately the graphics engine is feature rich, and with all the bells and whistles acivated, you essentially apply enough makeup to make it all seem passable. But whoever drew and layered the 2d comic book style "cutscenes" absolutely nailed it - suberb stuff!Sadly the 3d engine performs somewhat poorly, and the latest WHQL nvidia drivers didn't even have a working SLI profile for this game, so I spent the first couple of hours with very poor framerates until I learned that it was fixed in the latest beta drivers. Stuff like this really has to be sorted at release date.I spent 12 hours on the SP campaign which is the longest I can remember in a FPS, and even though there were some recycled parts, I enjoyed the entire game a great deal. If anything the first couple of hours was the least fun, as you hardly have any weapons or skills. Not that you REALLY need the weapons anyways, as the Katana melee weapon with it's shuriken partner is plenty powerful for most of what the game has to throw at you (too powerful perhaps).My verdict is 80%

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												For $3.90 on the Steam Sale, I think this game was worth it.PROS1. StoryWhile the game is pretty linear, the story near the end was pretty good. I won't spoil it.2. Interesting conceptsDemon heart kills were interesting. Sadly, demon heads were just weak laser beams, even with upgrades.3. Katana fightingRather than a First Person Shooter, it's more a First Person Slasher. It's refreshing to slash, instead of shoot. This is probably the most fun part.4. Upgrade system3 parts : Skills (Karma), Powers (Ki Points), Weapons (Money). Slightly redundant to divide skills and powers since they are almost the same thing. However, Weapons were interesting. You change how you use the weapons with the upgrades e.g. Crossbow has 2 upgrades, one for a piercing shot and one for an explosive bolt.CONS1. RepetitionYou will face the same monster hordes over and over again. It is most boring. The developers simply created a zone and spawned more monsters of increasing numbers and difficulty in each zone.Worst, you can fight in the exact same location you came from earlier.The bosses are also killed in the exact same pattern e.g. Run in a circle, collect items, damage weak point, rinse repeat.2. WeaponsThe rocket launcher is extremely clunky. Your submachine gun will be the most useful weapon. Flamethrowers have a minimum range problem where you can't burn someone standing next to him.3. Death by stairsYou cannot sprint jump off the middle of 3 steps as you will die. The game somehow detects you crashing into the floor at super speed.4. Generic trash creaturesThe yakuza, slasher and skeleton will all attack you the same way. They just look different. While you have a large variety of creatures ranging from the Warlord, Necromancer, Charger, Teleporting Sword Witch, Mother Demon, etc etc. Killing them in the exact same way really makes it boring. It does not help that you fight them multiple times over and over again.I use WW+Left Click, with the life steal upgrade, a lot and it kills EVERYTHING, except air units and bosses.5. Nobitsura KageYou only get to use the super slash power of the Nobitsura Kage in 1 level.6. Complicated Ki StrikesWW+Left Click/Right Click are easy and fast. All the other spells have delays in casting animation which prevent you from moving. The directional aspect of the spells ensure you can't use certain spells for offense e.g. SS+Right Click only works when you are running away.7. NPCsOddly, there are a pair of twins that are introduced that you never need to fight.8. Quest ObjectiveThe game uses golden doors to show you where to go. However, for some very large stages, the golden door is very hard to find. It would be better if they had a map since you can only progress through ONE DOOR.9. ZoomHow the hell do you zoom with X?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2015
												Best FPS I've played in a long time. There is no multiplayer, but the campaign is stellar. Plays like an FPS from late 90's-early 2000's, but with modern functions (sprinting, leveling/character building, etc). Combat is phenomenal - between your katana, ki powers, pistol, SMG(s), crossbow, shotgun, flamethrower, rocket launcher, and demon bits (yes, you use pieces of demon as weapons. yes, it's as awesome as it sounds), combat is varied and exciting. There are probably an infinite number of ways you can approach any fight. The swordplay is pretty great - the lack of a parry  is a slight downer, but the ki powers make up for it. The dialogue is drop-dead hilarious. Lo Wang's one-liners never get old, and the constant banter is what really gives this game its personality (IMO). The story might be linear with not too many surprises, but if you can get by that and take this game for what it is (a throwback to late 90's shooters) you will enjoy yourself.This is my first review ever, and until now I hadn't planned on writing one ever. Even at 10 hours (mine went a little longer after a bunch of avoidable deaths) for a playthrough, if I never played it again I think it's worth your money (or more, if you catch on a 75% off sale like I did).

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												Shadow Warrior is a very good shooter with a bit of buts.I honestly recommend playing this game to every fan of FPS games. It's fun, it's wild, it's well made. It has great humor and some dirty jokes and innuendo thrown in. We have 9 weapons, some with consierable different alternative fire mode. Overall mood of the game is mysterious and full of chineee (?) demons, ancient magic, some weird artifacts and a bit of Yakuza or other Asian mafia group. If you like games that follow the spirit of Duke Nukem 3D, classic Shadow Warrior or Serious Sam First and Second Encounter then go for it! You should not be disappointed.That was at least the short version. A bit longer and more detailed text will follow. This game has some weak spots. Lets do standard Pros & Cons.Pros:- explosive gameplay - yup, really a lot of things in this game explode- great and juicy graphics- early level design as well as well as demon world design - small town looks as it should - claustrophobic; cementary looks creepy and mysterious with all of those candles; demon world reminds somewhat worlds from Zeno Clash games. Also winter levels look good.- good looking chinese demons- badass protagonist, nice sidekick - maybe not as fun as Mad Max's Chumbucket but Hoji is still memorable- lots of guns and alternative fire modes - katana & shurikens, revolver, smg, crossbow, shotgun, flamer, missile launcher, demon heart and demon head- three separate ways to upgrade hero - you buy weapon upgrades for money, spells for ki crystals and skills (that gives some bonuses like +10 to Health Points) for Karma points that you get for killing demons and finding chalice secrets- sword fighting and spellcasting works very well- when killing demons in special way you get more points like in arcade games - when you kill a demon with a rocket you get a DETONATOR bonus, when you behead him you get HEADSHOT or BEHEADED depending on weapons used- humor is really fun, fast and sometimes references good old classic games- speaking of good old classic games - this game has a lot of GREAT and FUN secrets. You can see Godzilla in the background on some levels, you can find pixel rooms just as in the Shadow Warrior 3D so on, so forth. Oh, just to give you a taste of ingenious humor - one of the main bad guys is called Zilla and he wants to become a god. Just add those words. Ring any bell?Cons:- although the first 5-6 hours into the game are brilliant, the rest are just somewhat dull. Somewhere during play I just felt that I am slashing or shooting the same enemies over and over and over (yada yada) again. Later levels are long. Not just long but loooooooong. Winter levels can take as long as 1 hour to finish each. - whole game takes about 12 hours to beat. Although this seems fine for a shooter, it's about 2-3 hours too long. Most of the original ideas become familiar after playing for about 6 hours and there is not much more original content later.- boss fights are prolonged. I am not bickering about this one. Just compare Serious Sam bosses to this game bosses. Big Aludran reptile was challenging and the whole fight was rewarding. In Shadow Warrior after beating those big armors I felt tired. Especially second windged armor was tedious and took too long to beat. - no point in playing this game for the second time - when we have seen those levels the only thing that remain is slashing demons over and over again. If you like maxing out your characters then that's fine but that may take some time in this game.- after getting the final weapon and buying some upgrades we can see that some of weapons are not really useful. I think that the best gun for wiping weaker demons is shotgun. SMG is a bit weak, although useful when fighting bosses. Revolver is fine for flying demons as it kills them with one shot. Katana is fine. Crossbow is the weapon that you will use for most of the time as it is somewhat powerful and I recommend buying exploding bolts upgrade as fast as possible. Missile launcher is powerful but slow. Flamer is well, slow and not really that powerful imo. Alternative fire modes are fun but not really useful except revolver, shotgun and crossbow ones.- fights are fine when there are small packs of demons but battles tend to drag on when there are more enemies. You need to hack and slash through every one in order to progress to some ares. That's just tiring. As tiring as grinding in mmo. This is why I recommend boosting your shotgun with upgrades because shotgun in this game is one shot = one kill when it comes to weaker enemies.Phew, that was long. Don't hesitate after reading my Cons. These are my free thoughts on this game. Overall this a great game. Go and play it:)***A word about DLC - besides soundtrack and PDF artbook we have some katana weapons skins. We can change it to e.g. Serious Sam 3 sledgehammer or Saint's Row‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• It does not change weapon 1 characteristics, only visuals. Yeah, that means you can slash with a hammer. Makes sense in this game, I think.---------- For anyone interested in joining in on completing your own backlog; check it out here - http://steamcommunity.com/groups/completingthebacklog/discussions/5/530645446320364338/

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 7, 2016
												A reimagining of a classic that surpassed every expectation.I‚Äôm not a huge fan of shooter games but it would be a lie to say that I don‚Äôt enjoy a good shootout every now and then but what  I do most of the times is that I get a game, shoot my way through it while trying to do as much as I can in that one playthrough, and once I beat it I rarely go back to it ever. It was nothing like that with this one.Shadow Warrior takes a step forward by backtracking quite a lot when it comes to FPS gameplay, making it feel rather retro by arming you with 10 different weapons all equipped with primary and secondary fire (some even have 3 ways to use them), which is not as popular approach to FPS today as it used to be, and I don‚Äôt know about you but I personally don‚Äôt  give a s*it about it not being realistic, it‚Äôs a game it is meant to be fun, not real. First they limit your weapon carrying capacity under the excuse of ‚Äúmaking it realistic‚Äù and before you know it, we have games where you have to pay taxes because that‚Äôs also realistic‚Ä¶ Oh wait, that‚Äôs already happening‚Ä¶ Never mind, back to the game review. HP loss being permanent (unless you heal yourself) also contributes to the retro-ish FSP play but it still keeps up with the modern fast paced + tactical feel with it‚Äôs moderate tactical approach to battle situations. It‚Äôs quite a visionary reimagining of the old title and a true modern day successor in every aspect.I‚Äôll keep this on short because despite all the minor things that set this one apart from the other titles in the genre, it‚Äôs still mainly a FPS with some minor trait based character development, weapon upgrade system and gameplay that really feels like a successor of the old FPS games like Doom, Duke and the original Shadow Warrior. I guess if I had to compare it I would say that this one is kind of like the first BioShock game with a dominant samurai theme and cheesy jokes that, no matter how much you find them not to be funny, after some time, the Wang will get to you and you will have no choice but to chuckle at them. So, do I recommend it? Absolutely. For everyone, this title is so likable and enjoyable that you can play it no matter what kind of gamer you are. Casuals and obsessed hardcore challenge seekers will enjoy it equally. 70 hours of gameplay on a linear single player only FPS is more than enough to describe how much I liked this one. So yeah, it‚Äôs a yes, definitely a YES and I can‚Äôt wait for the sequel for I absolutely am left wanting more Wang!

												I suggest you play the demo first. Otherwise you will find a superb twitch FPS here. Also, don't buy Hard Reset/Redux, it will feel too much of the same. There are many positives, like a somewhat funny main character, very good gunplay/swordplay, and huge boss fights reminiscentof Painkiller. My only negative is that the game has some path finding issues, recycled enemies, and some really tough levels. The single player campaign is long, but I actually thought it was unnecessary long, as the remaining hours felt like a bit of slodge. On sale, it's not a bad way to waste some time, while you ponder buying the newest Doom game.

												Don't trust the published paid reviewers!  This game is a gem - one that shouldn't be overlooked.  Now, would I pay $50 for it?  Nah.  But it is regularly out there for $20 or less, and at that price IT IS A MUST PLAY.   The games lines are cheesy, the graphics are great, and the bad guys die by the dozens at a time by the blinding blood-spatted slasshed of your sword.  What's not to love?  The plot starts off light and vapid and evolves into a very complicated and mature one.  The closeout of the stroyline was one of the best I've seen in any game.  Folks, its the real deal.  Someone told me there are guns in the game, but I wouldn't know it - seeing arms and legs flying off their hosts in slow-mo is all I ever needed!  Mess with the bull, and you'll get the Wang.  Play.  This.  Game.

												This game.... THIS GAME! I can't tell how much I like this game. :) Where should I start... oh yes, It's amazing! content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
												This game is good. Very good. Honestly, as of late, i've become increasingly bored of first person shooters, too much of the same thing. two weapons, regenerating health, drab brown setting, it's overdone, and just feels... bad. Shadow Warrior is a throwback to classic FPS, and as a remake of a old-school FPS, I guess I expected that, but what I didn't expect by this game was to be completely blown away. The game never feels old, the combat feels so rewarding and substantial, with each sword blow and shotgun shell feeling great. The pacing is fantastic, the levels fun and unique, and the story also, while at first sounding pretty cheesy, turns out to be really interesting.My favorite part of this game, however, is the boss battles. Oh yes, this FPS has boss battles, and by god are they fantastic. The towering bosses you take on are incredible, and the otherwordly enviroments you fight them in are stunning. The fights are challenging, fun, and jaw-droppingly beautiful.Flying Wild Hog did a fantastic job with Shadow Warrior, and I am beyond impressed9/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
												Having played the original Shadow Warrior nearly some twenty years ago (damn, I just made myself feel old), I can say that I was both looking forward to and kinda fearing a series reboot since they tend to go one of two ways: an improvement or a waste of time. And I'm happy to say, this reboot was a MAJOR improvement in every way.Shadow Warrior kept to its defining roots; you play as Lo Wang and you fight demons with an assortment of fun weapons while cracking jokes, including poking fun at the original when you come across secret areas using the old, old, old graphics.For me, story is what made this a top-rated FPS (maybe my favourite). An interwoven tale of gods and demons with practical and emotionally-driven decisions provides motivation far beyond 'they're bad for the sake of being bad, so I should go shoot them'. And the buddy-cop relation Lo Wang shares with Hoji kept me laughing and, better yet, uncertain how things would end.Graphically, they didn't go for the super-duper-high-end which is always fine with me, but it's still pretty good and the enemeis and scenery were nicely varied (gotta love them coy ponds and cherry trees).The audio was decent with a soundtrack I found worth the special edition upgrade.Game-play harkens back to the old-school FPS of (eventually) packing 10guns at all times and secret areas everywhere but also adds in a few puzzles and an upgrade system for the weapons, your skills, and your magic so you can fight your way.So even if you don't have a connection to the original Shadow Warrior, this is a great game for anyone who is a fan of story-based shooters.Also, here's hoping Strife and CyberMage receive similar treatment some day.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												I pretty much got what I expected with this title - good old school PC FPS, and lots of it!The developers seemingly didn't wanna leave any boxes unchecked, and went all-in with powers (double tab a direction keys and press LMB or RMB), skills (permanent stat upgrade like more max health) and upgradeable weapons. Each category has its own resource - Money, KI crystals and karma. Lots of stuff is borrowed from other titles, but all things good imo. This is a lot like the "Darksiders" of FPS'es - a compilation of everthing that has proven to work in other titles.The basic FPS mechanics feel fairly solid and rewarding, but there's a certain undefinable something missing. I don't know if it's the visual/sonic feedback from hitting your target that's a bit "off" - but it simply didn't feel as tight as I've come to expect from the best FPS'es. I did experience some annoyances with the physics - dash while running down a flight of stairs and you just instantly die, and terrain climbing is awfully unintuitive - luckily you hardly have to do any, unless you're searching for secrets.The presentation is a hit and miss - The narration/dialogue is witty, and the voice acting fairly good. The sound effects decent, but some of the weapon sounds lacked personality. My biggest gripe was with the graphics - the textures and 3d models were at times pretty lackluster. Fortunately the graphics engine is feature rich, and with all the bells and whistles acivated, you essentially apply enough makeup to make it all seem passable. But whoever drew and layered the 2d comic book style "cutscenes" absolutely nailed it - suberb stuff!Sadly the 3d engine performs somewhat poorly, and the latest WHQL nvidia drivers didn't even have a working SLI profile for this game, so I spent the first couple of hours with very poor framerates until I learned that it was fixed in the latest beta drivers. Stuff like this really has to be sorted at release date.I spent 12 hours on the SP campaign which is the longest I can remember in a FPS, and even though there were some recycled parts, I enjoyed the entire game a great deal. If anything the first couple of hours was the least fun, as you hardly have any weapons or skills. Not that you REALLY need the weapons anyways, as the Katana melee weapon with it's shuriken partner is plenty powerful for most of what the game has to throw at you (too powerful perhaps).My verdict is 80%

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												For $3.90 on the Steam Sale, I think this game was worth it.PROS1. StoryWhile the game is pretty linear, the story near the end was pretty good. I won't spoil it.2. Interesting conceptsDemon heart kills were interesting. Sadly, demon heads were just weak laser beams, even with upgrades.3. Katana fightingRather than a First Person Shooter, it's more a First Person Slasher. It's refreshing to slash, instead of shoot. This is probably the most fun part.4. Upgrade system3 parts : Skills (Karma), Powers (Ki Points), Weapons (Money). Slightly redundant to divide skills and powers since they are almost the same thing. However, Weapons were interesting. You change how you use the weapons with the upgrades e.g. Crossbow has 2 upgrades, one for a piercing shot and one for an explosive bolt.CONS1. RepetitionYou will face the same monster hordes over and over again. It is most boring. The developers simply created a zone and spawned more monsters of increasing numbers and difficulty in each zone.Worst, you can fight in the exact same location you came from earlier.The bosses are also killed in the exact same pattern e.g. Run in a circle, collect items, damage weak point, rinse repeat.2. WeaponsThe rocket launcher is extremely clunky. Your submachine gun will be the most useful weapon. Flamethrowers have a minimum range problem where you can't burn someone standing next to him.3. Death by stairsYou cannot sprint jump off the middle of 3 steps as you will die. The game somehow detects you crashing into the floor at super speed.4. Generic trash creaturesThe yakuza, slasher and skeleton will all attack you the same way. They just look different. While you have a large variety of creatures ranging from the Warlord, Necromancer, Charger, Teleporting Sword Witch, Mother Demon, etc etc. Killing them in the exact same way really makes it boring. It does not help that you fight them multiple times over and over again.I use WW+Left Click, with the life steal upgrade, a lot and it kills EVERYTHING, except air units and bosses.5. Nobitsura KageYou only get to use the super slash power of the Nobitsura Kage in 1 level.6. Complicated Ki StrikesWW+Left Click/Right Click are easy and fast. All the other spells have delays in casting animation which prevent you from moving. The directional aspect of the spells ensure you can't use certain spells for offense e.g. SS+Right Click only works when you are running away.7. NPCsOddly, there are a pair of twins that are introduced that you never need to fight.8. Quest ObjectiveThe game uses golden doors to show you where to go. However, for some very large stages, the golden door is very hard to find. It would be better if they had a map since you can only progress through ONE DOOR.9. ZoomHow the hell do you zoom with X?

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Great game. Good fun combat and very robust upgrade system, but the story alone is worth it. It has a good ending that brings closure but also gives you something to think about. Shadow Warrior is a tale of sacrifice and tragedy; it is about the price of ambition and ramifications of forbidden feelings. What does it mean to be alive? The Ancients' memories can reveal all to you. Shadow Warrior pulls a rabbit out of the hat and the game makes it fly beautifully.One of the best games I have played this year. Think about things from the POV of the demons and every characters in the game when you finish it. I won't spoil anything. When you do that, in addition to all your insights, answer me this:Did anyone, including Lo Wang, really had any choice in the game? Think about your fun when you slice demons open too.Maybe it doesn't have the same delivery style, but Shadow Warrior plot has some theme in Dark Souls.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
												The folks that made Painkiller, Bulletstorm and Hard Reset get together and make the most fun I've had with a sword in a video game? Truly surprising. A B-list retro franchise that was a slightly fun Duke riff with Asian stereotype flavor gets an update that is more fun, more explosive, and less offensive than its forebear. This is what Duke Nukem Forever should have been.The viscera is hilarious, the limb-explosions frequent, and the dance of all the crazy slash/dodge/shoot violence ascends to actual balletic grace. You will feel like a badass. You will laugh out loud. You will kill demons by ripping out the still-beating heart of their comrade and squishing it in their faces. Then they explode. This game wants to be fun, and it is. If only more games understood that. Buy this and remind yourself that shooters can still be adrenaline-fueled stress-relief of the highest, most perfect order.The boss battles are sh*t, though. I guess you can't have everything.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
												Shadow Warrior is a reboot/prequel of the obscure 1997 shooter developed by 3D realms (creators of the legendary Duke Nukem.) The reboot was developed by Flying Wild Hog and published by Devolver Digital. After playing the original game along side the two expansion packs I was eager to get my hands on the reboot once it was announced on May 10, 2013 the trailer showed promise and looked like what a reboot should be. Once I finally purchased and started playing I was introduced to our main hero and one-liner zinger Lo Wang an assassin who works for the powerful Japanese industrial magnate, Orochi Zilla. He is sent to a mission to purchase an ancient katana from a collector named Mizayaki for 2 million dollars. Mizayaki refuses the offer and Lo Wang tries to take the sword by force which takes a horrible turn for the worse. "Let's see... briefcase full of cash... blade... million dollar smile... ready for school, ma!" This game has a soild presentation and reinstated the hopes I had for the game. The story does do its job right with interesting, funny and downright awesome characters, and the plot keeps you engaged thoughout.Gameplay wise it is almost flawless, old school with exploration for secrets in well designed levels and run and gun combat with modern elements and amazing sword fighting. Gunplay is soild and fun with great toys to play with against anything that bleeds although I would have liked to see abit more weapons and some more returning guns like the riot gun (a gatling shotgun) from the original game. Sword play really stands out and is really satisfying with full control of different swings to hack and slash any foe that dare crosses you alongside with special chi moves to bend reality to your will, you can also upgrade guns, skills and power to create more havok. There are some problem with the game unfortunately the maps can be a wee repatative, the guns are way to underpowered with the katana killing enemies with ease and the later demons can be way too annoying on the hardest difficulties.Visually the game is stunning and alot of work has been done to make the game look jaw dropping there are some low quality textures even on highest settings and some cutscenes animations look terrible but they get a pass due to being rare. On launch this game was brutal to run but thanks to a recent patch it did help abit however it is still very terribly unoptimized which is unacceptable for a PC launch games, a huge bummer that ruins the experience. The game is out on Windows and with the recent patch Mac OSX and Linux is now supported. Music, sound and voice acting are pretty good aswell with a kickass soundtrack, witty and hilarious voicework and writing and satisfying sounds this game has a good amount of polish but could have been a little better.  Overall Shadow Warrior has to been one of my favourite shooters of all time and if your even slightly curious do play it I 100% recommend it. Packed with tons of content I have not completed still and you can even play the original free on Steam. "Do you want cake or death? I should mention that we are all out of cake."

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 2, 2015
												This game is full of dumb Wang jokes, has a confusing supernatural plot, and some grating voice acting. Who cares about that, though. This is a game about unleashing the wrath of Wang on demon hoards. Let there be Wang jokes.Some of the best first-person swordplay I've seen in a game. It's just a blast to slice up bad dudes and demons into pulpy giblets. If you don't like swords, there are plenty of guns at hand. You can't go wrong. Lots of secrets to find, and useful skills (self heal, sweet sword maneuvers, etc.) to level up.It's mindless fun and you should play it.
