												Excellent game with exceptionally fun melee. The voice acting and story are surprisingly good enough to hold your attention and the graphics as well as the sceneries are varied and detailed so as to not become dull.The game lasts much longer than I would have expected, about 15 hours or so but is fully worth it. Decapitating enemies with a pink‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•has its quirks as well. The guns aren't too powerful so as to force you to use your sword but the bosses are impossible to kill without them so it's a good idea to familiarize with each of them.The normal difficulty shouldn't pose much of a challenge as I have only died by falling off platforms rather than in battle but the two difficulty levels above are suffient to pose a challenge to those who seek it.  The jokes are hilarious.It is ill advised to kill rabbits if you value your life.

												Holy wang, this game is unbelievably fun! I tried the demo first and immediatly fell in love with it. The story is interesting and captivating, at least in part because the character Lo Wang is so easy to "identify with" as a nerd trying to be a hero. The controls are also very streamlined and simple, while still having a lot of fun tricks you can master with playing around. The game feels a lot like bioshock minus the deep suspense.All in all I'd recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed playing through the bioshock series and is looking for a fun game to spend a lot of quality time with.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2015
												This is a no-spoiler review.Pros: -AMAZING gameplay. Think Quake or Doom type combat, but with some additions (i.e. katana moves and special powers). If you haven't played those games, then think about what Call of Duty or Battlefield would feel like with more than two weapons.-Nice weapons. Each one (except the pistol) feels powerful and has good sound effects. -Fair difficulty. The game gets really tough, but it never felt unfair. Near the end of the game, it gets REALLY difficult. But there isn't a single enemy in the game that takes advantage of you. Every enemy has a predictable moving/shooting pattern. It's literally your skill vs the game designers. -Nice graphics. Good shaders and textures used.-Good optimization. I don't have the best PC in the world but this game runs like a beast.Cons:-The unoptimized karma system (which involves being innovative with killing enemies) doesn't always reward creativity. For example, I might decide to kill a certain enemy using a certain weapon, but it isn't the best and the game doesn't recognize that I did something unusual. -Monotonous environments. The graphics are really good, but after a while, you end up seeing the same house or lab over and over again. -Terrible boss fights. Almost every review mentions this; the boss fights suck. But don't let this keep you from enjoying this amazing game!Summary:8/10. There are better AAA games on Steam, but after you play those, you HAVE to play this.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												I've got wang of steel.Here's the real review. I'm in the 10th chapter and I feel comfortable enough to write my review for it.Pros- A good return to the classic singleplayer FPS that was popular in the 90s-early 2000s. but polished to the point where it feels Modern.- Great melee system, it's fun to slice up demons with your katana and other powers you'll get throughout the game.- Funny. I've laughed a decent amount while playing this, Lo wang is a great protaiganist and still feels like the Chinese Duke nukem from the original shadow warrior.- GORE. Tons of it.- It looks great. - Rewards you for exploration. There are a decent amount of secrets in every level, rewarding the curious type.Cons.- Isn't really optimized for low end systems, but I can manage a solid 30fps when exploring, but you will take a giant dive of FPS when you're in a battle.- Combat can get a bit repetitive, but there is a good amount of exploration in these levels that you can take a break from if you want.I would reccomend this at full price, but I personally would wait for it to go down to 15$ or lower.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												This game is great.I don't know if you can justify $40 for it, but I picked it up on sale because of the funny trailer.  Like every other steam sale game, it sat in my library untouched for 6 months, until I saw it while bored and installed it.  It's brilliant, it really is.  It's a throwback to old school gaming, taking elements from quake, doom and duke nukem.  Fast paced action orientated combat is completely stale today, but this game absolutely nailed it.  The story was surprisingly interesting, and I found myself really powering through the game to find out what happened, but it also had a good amount of comedy mixed in.  But not too much to ruin the plot of the game, very well done.If this game is on sale, get it, definitely.  A friend said to me that it's a 'game that you play in between other games when you are bored and alone.'  I disagree.  It's one of the better games i've played in a while, I haven't enjoyed a playthrough like that in a long time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 13, 2015
												Basically, this is one of the best "retro-modern" games out there (a retro style shooter with modern graphics).  It's an attempt to bring the fun of games like Doom or Duke Nukem 3D into the modern age.  Frankly, I'll always like that style of FPS versus the more modern types with limited weapons and complicated cover systems.A special not about the best weapon in the game, the katana.  If you're one of these people who goes through a game crowbarring or wrenching everyone to save ammo, you'll love this game's treatment of the katana, probably the best melee weapon I've seen in this type of  FPS, they really put a lot of thought into it.  I'll note, however, there is also a good selection of upgradable firearms and special weapons, and plenty of ammo for them.Also, the environments are very pretty and colorful, mostly.  This may seem like not a big deal, but I find it helps differentiate this game from a lot of modern FPSs.I find the main characters (the hero gets a ghostly sidekick) to be very appealing.  He's funny and tough.  The ghostly sidekick is appropriately sarcastic.Well, for me this was pretty much a must buy, so I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Great game. Good fun combat and very robust upgrade system, but the story alone is worth it. It has a good ending that brings closure but also gives you something to think about. Shadow Warrior is a tale of sacrifice and tragedy; it is about the price of ambition and ramifications of forbidden feelings. What does it mean to be alive? The Ancients' memories can reveal all to you. Shadow Warrior pulls a rabbit out of the hat and the game makes it fly beautifully.One of the best games I have played this year. Think about things from the POV of the demons and every characters in the game when you finish it. I won't spoil anything. When you do that, in addition to all your insights, answer me this:Did anyone, including Lo Wang, really had any choice in the game? Think about your fun when you slice demons open too.Maybe it doesn't have the same delivery style, but Shadow Warrior plot has some theme in Dark Souls.

You're a low-level gangster, trying to buy a sword for your boss.  Problem is, dude won't sell.  He knows your boss is working for some demons.  Doesn't want them to destroy the world or whatever. number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												This shooter has a cool setting and balanced feeling mechanics (including a fun melee system). Pick it up if you are after something a bit more old school.A pretty game with smart level design and mechanics. Flying Wild Hog have clearly learnt from Hard Reset, this time doing away with the flaky weapon system and adding some cool melee and spellcasting mechanics to add some variety. The awesome (but lighthearted) setting really adds a lot to the game, and improves a lot upon the dark and boring generic not-really-cyberpunk sci-fi theme from Hard Reset. Some talented artists have been given an opportunity to flex their muscles here, with some truly spectacular art (especially in the first level).The melee and spell based combat system is nice, despite some strange key combinations needed to access them. The ability to heal means the game doesn't leave you stuck without enough health if you've missed a few health packs, but can remove some of the tension from combat. The melee system is nice and fits in well with the guns. You learn new moves as you progress, so tedium is avoided. But it can make guns feel less useful.Levels can still feel very boxed in and limited compared to games like Serious Sam, and many of the secrets tend to be pretty boring. The guns can lack the authentic feel and kick you might be familiar with.But otherwise, Shadow Warrior is a good effort at making more of an old school feeling FPS, with skill based, bombastic combat making up for most of the failings.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												I never played the original Build engine game of Shadow Warrior, but this is what Duke Nukem Forever should have been - an awesome reboot bringing back the gameplay values of its era powered by a modern engine.The implementation is a little like the Serious Sam series, but don't let that put you off if, like me, you're not a fan. It's a series of semi-technical combat 'arenas' in which you need to choose your weapons and tactics carefully so as not to be overwhelmed, joined together by explore-and-lewt sections, but Shadow Warrior seems to pull it all together a lot better than other games of the same ilk. The story is.. just ok.. for the majority of the game, but it rounds it out and sets the mood well enough to make it feel as though you have a purpose beyond go-there-kill-everything-repeat.Not that that would be a big problem - the combat is immensely satisfying, with the game offering a large variety of ways to blow up, burn, electrify, perforate, and slice and dice the reasonably varied set of lesser and greater demons that you'll run into. You always have a few options on how to tackle a given situation, and throughout the game you'll be upgrading your sword skills, Chi powers, and less-up-close-and-personal weaponry to increase them.The game also features a few boss battles which, although a little samey, make for a nice change of pace from the frantic melee of the rest of the game.Hard difficulty recommended if you're a regular fps player - the difficulty paces pretty well, and by the time you're hitting the stiffer challenges of the later levels you should be good enough to whoop them if you've invested a bit of time in hunting down some of the secret xp-stashes that are lying about. Learn the special moves and make sure you've got your dodge key bound and you'll be kicking demon backside.TLDR; had a blast - play this if you like to chop things up with a sword while listening to corny 'wang' jokes.LO WANG / 10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												I've got wang of steel.Here's the real review. I'm in the 10th chapter and I feel comfortable enough to write my review for it.Pros- A good return to the classic singleplayer FPS that was popular in the 90s-early 2000s. but polished to the point where it feels Modern.- Great melee system, it's fun to slice up demons with your katana and other powers you'll get throughout the game.- Funny. I've laughed a decent amount while playing this, Lo wang is a great protaiganist and still feels like the Chinese Duke nukem from the original shadow warrior.- GORE. Tons of it.- It looks great. - Rewards you for exploration. There are a decent amount of secrets in every level, rewarding the curious type.Cons.- Isn't really optimized for low end systems, but I can manage a solid 30fps when exploring, but you will take a giant dive of FPS when you're in a battle.- Combat can get a bit repetitive, but there is a good amount of exploration in these levels that you can take a break from if you want.I would reccomend this at full price, but I personally would wait for it to go down to 15$ or lower.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
												Just bought it on sale for 2.5‚Ç¨ expecting it to be a "generic" hack 'n slash / shoot 'em up, oh boy was I wrong:PROS+Combat: Let me tell you, the sword handling system is great, and it doesn't get boring with the special sword attacks you can perform. On top of that you also have guns, spells to knock enemies up, stun them, heal yourself... everything is upgradeable and opens up a lot of possibilities when fighting.+Story: Actually, it was a beautiful and saddening story, I didnt expect it to have a good plot but I got really surprised.+Graphics: Beautiful scenaries, I found myself contemplating some views for more than one minute. More than once.+Length: 12-15 hours, really good and doesn't get repetitive.+OST: Really good all around.+Has a lot of references to retro and older games, also the main character and his companion will crack you up, good humor.+Feels like Serious Sam, who didnt like that game?+Really cheap on sale.CONS-A more frequent autosave in levels would be nice, sucks to have to repeat 1-2 areas because there wasnt a checkpoint-Sometimes you sprint and die by falling 30 cm, which coupled with the above issue may be a bit frustrating.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
												This is probably one of the goriest games i've played ina while but i mean that in a good way. You play Lo Wang who is sent byhis boss to retrieve a sword called the Nobitsura Kage but it turns out it's not a normal sword and then Wang finds himself fighting demons who are invading the world. I really enjoyed this game at first. It gives you a samurai sword and some guns and lets you hack,slash and shoot up enemies in a very gory fashion and has you do so in a funny over-the-top kind of way. However once that initial enjoyment wore off the game started to feel a bit dragged out and the combat became repetetive.To be fair they did try to make the combat a bit varied with the ability to unlock different attacks and powers as well as a variety   of weapons but the game just boils down to you entering an area, the game throws a load of enemies at you, you kill them and travel through the level a bit more and then repeat. This really makes playing the game a chore after a while as it just feels like your doing the same thing over and over again. I did like the frantic pace off the combat though and it does provide a good challenge as well as being visually gory which people may like or not.The games levels look pretty good in general although there is a bit of lazy level design at times with certain areas looking like they have been copy and pasted in from earlier. In the beginning there doesn't seem to be much of a story and as the game continues it's a bit hard to follow but it does pick up going into the final third of the game and ends quite well. The Good:- Enjoyable combat with the ability to upgrade and unlock weapons and powers and rewarding damage to enemies like cutting off heads and limbs.- I liked the humour in this game and the back and forths between Wang and his accomplice Hoji are enjoyable.- Visually the game looks pretty good with some of the earlier levels in particular looking quite nice.The Bad:- Combat sections get repetetive after a while and at times it just feels like a chore when the game is constantly throwing wave after wave of enemies after you.- The game feels a bit dragged out with the middle part of the game feeling unneccesarily long.- I found the hit detection was a bit poor at times which can be irritating at times.SummaryThis is a pretty decent game although it has it's flaws.  It's a 6.5/10 from me.

Posted: September 7, 2016
												I bought this game 2 years ago, I thought that this "would be a pale piece of defecated material when compared to the nostalgia of the original (like duke nukem 3d and duke nukem forever)"...How wrong i was...This game is eternally fun.If you are new to the FPS genre, or if you are looking to get your children a fun birthday present, this game is it.It is easy to get yourself drowning in the story of Evil vs. Lo Wang.Without further Rearkissing, I shall now present to you all, the Pros and Cons. Pros Great story. 9/10Ok sword manuevering . 7/10Amazing replayability. 9.99999999999999999999/10 (basically 10/10)amazing refrences. 10/10Arsenal for the ages (other FPS games should take a hint and copy the upgrading system). 8.5/10Graphics are pretty damn good. Subjective scoring ( this one is just my opinion )Fortune cookies are hilarius. "i'm sorry your fortune is in another cookie"- A fortune cookie from shadow warrior. Cons Music is non-exeistant. ( a good song to listen to is Dividing by Zero/Slim pickins does the right thing and rides the bomb to hell when playing Shadow Warrior)Horridly linear gameplay.Spots where if you dash you die... instantly (usually when you go retro or where there are secrets).In conclusion, Shadow Warrior is a game I'd reccomend to all.I've included links to all of the things i've listed for refrence.Dividing By Zero/Slim Pickens Does The Right Thing And Rides The Bomb To Hell

content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												A solid FPS overall, with some drawbacks in design that keep it from really shining:- The Special Ki Moves are activiated by tapping a direction twice and holding a fire button. These seem to arbitrarily not work and will get you killed pretty often if you're using them in the heat of battle.- Several enemy types seem designed to take up time with Shields or other game mechanics that make them a chore to kill.- Weapon selection is a bit lacking. The starter pistol/SMG will take you through a good hunk of the game.While these are annoying, none of these keep Shadow Warrior from being a good game, just one that's not quite as good as it could've been.If it's on sale, buy it. Full Price, stay away.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 14, 2016
												This game is great.I don't know if you can justify $40 for it, but I picked it up on sale because of the funny trailer.  Like every other steam sale game, it sat in my library untouched for 6 months, until I saw it while bored and installed it.  It's brilliant, it really is.  It's a throwback to old school gaming, taking elements from quake, doom and duke nukem.  Fast paced action orientated combat is completely stale today, but this game absolutely nailed it.  The story was surprisingly interesting, and I found myself really powering through the game to find out what happened, but it also had a good amount of comedy mixed in.  But not too much to ruin the plot of the game, very well done.If this game is on sale, get it, definitely.  A friend said to me that it's a 'game that you play in between other games when you are bored and alone.'  I disagree.  It's one of the better games i've played in a while, I haven't enjoyed a playthrough like that in a long time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Having played just about everything that 3D Realms produced in the nineties, I was very interested in this Shadow Warrior reboot. It is true to the original, with updated graphics and gameplay elements. Lo Wang looks and sounds different, but the cheesy one liners, the ambiguous chinese/japanese setting and the humour are all there. Even the killer rabbits. The levels are big, highly explorable like the original and other games from the early shooters, I must say I was surprised when I thought I had fully explored a map and found I had only gotten maybe 70% of the secrets found by the end. The biggest gameplay improvement has to be the functionality of the sword, I find myself using it over any of the guns whenever possible, when it was pretty much a last resort weapon in the original (for me anyway)There are also a upgrade/perk points/skill tree system which has some useful things like upgrades to weapons, more stamina/health etc. It's not too complicated and I found that improving all the sword related abilities made the game even more enjoyable.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2014
												Not only is this a fun as hell and incredibly beautiful first-person swordfighting shooter, but the more expansive level design makes me wish other shooters took note. You can backtrack through pretty much every level, so you never feel railroaded into what the designers want you to do. Even though there‚Äôs no real point to it, I love the destruction. It‚Äôs an incredibly long game too, took me more than 25 hours for completion. I would never have expected such a deep skills system, but it becomes worth investing into when later on the game just dumps every enemy variety, gigantic or minute, onto you. The tougher the game gets (played on Hard difficulty), the more you‚Äôll be switching out different sword specials, guns, and even demon heart/heads like a multitasking maniac.Beyond the gameplay and design that respects the player, it‚Äôs probably the funniest game I played in 2013. Great tongue-in-cheek references, fourth-wall breaking, hipster jokes, ironic fortune cookies, one-liners, and a well-developed love/hate relationship between Lo Wang and Hoji that becomes surprisingly emotional towards the end.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2016
												Shadow Warrior (2013) is an excellent game.  It's a politically correct reboot that packs a punch with ridiculously fun combat as the star of the show.  The amount of badassery that comes with toting oversized guns, demonic powers, and a katana is really something else, and the quality of both its amazing swordplay and gunplay make Shadow Warrior incredibly satisfying as you slice and blast your way through endless demonic hordes.  The game is also fairly long, but it never felt like a chore to play simply due to how fun I had every during every second of game time (The incessant jokes, easter eggs, and surprisingly capable story probably helped).  Shadow Warrior is probably one of most fun games I've played in a long while, and its entertainment value makes the game a veritable steal when its on sale, so get it if you can!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												"Beware of Wang."The original 1997 version of this game could be summed up as having the gameplay style of Doom with a character who is like a japanese Duke Nukem. This remake is still that, but with a much better graphics engine and UI overhaul.You play as Lo Wang (AKA "Mr. Two Million Dollars"), a hitman who is sent to buy an ancient sword, the Nobitsura Kage, from a collector. You're orders are to obtain the sword through an offer of two million dollars or by killing everyone inside the mansion and to steal it. Neither of those options go well when you are captured by the collector with the help of his demon jester friend "Hoji." That doesn't go very well either (at least for them) when demons show up, kill everyone, and a female golem steals the sword and runs off with it. Now, it's time for heads to roll!This is a fast paced, action FPS where you utilize your skills with the katana, as well as with an array of guns, while empowered with the magic of Ki (pronounced Chee), a mystical power of balance between mind and body and gives you awesome powers to kick some demon butt! You can heal, blast foes with a wave of energy to knock them down, and empower your katana with Ki energy to perform special attacks. The game is a very well made remake of the original release and pays homage to its retro heritage through easter eggs and secret areas strewn throughout the game's 17 chapters. I'll leave it to you to go find them. I bought this game of sale for $25, and I haven't regretted my purchase. While I may not have purchased it for the full $40, I would say that for fans of these types of games, it's worth a buy.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 18, 2016
												This is just . . . a good game.1. The swordplay is some of the best I've ever seen in an FPS. You want to kill one big enemy? There's a move for that. You want to behead a group of enemies? There's a move for that. You want to clear out a bunch of dudes that have you surrounded? etc.2. The guns are funny, and by funny I mean that they are presented to you in a way that not only makes sense in context but also have funny upgrades. The sticky bombs for the crossbow are just a blast. I hate puns.3. You can self heal pretty easily, which actually doesn't feel like cheating. It makes fights strategic and really adds to the fun.4. On that point, there are almost no instances of cheesing in this game. You're going to be surrounded a lot, seldom finding bottlenecks or inaccessible areas to barricade behind. Even on casual you're going to get your butt handed to you frequently.5. The story is interesting enough, and the voice acting isn't annoying.6. Stop reading, go buy it. I feel guilty having recieved this for a song in a bundle.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												It's a shame Flying Wild Hog decided not to stay true to the original Shadow Warrior. The soundtrack is forgettable and the one liners sound like they belong in a disney movie. Lo Wang isn't Lo Wang anymore and the story is pretty damn lame. Now, I know the original Shadow Warrior didn't have much of a story at all and that's fine but in the remake it really tried to have one, and it just sounded so lame. I liked Hoji as a character and that's about it. Now, the gameplay, level design and the visuals are AMAZING. I had tons of fun and went through a second playthrough immediately. Excellent guns, excellent sword play, and tons of blood. $40 is a great price given it's 8-9 hour length on my first playthrough. It might fail in being a Shadow Warrior sequel but god damn is this game fun. If you can ignore that it shares the same name as Shadow Warrior then you won't be disappointed. This is how modern FPS should be. Buy it. Now.

content:
Posted: August 14, 2015
												A fantastic homage to the original classic, Shadow Warrior is everything a PC game deserves. An absolute roller-coaster ride from start to finish. Definitely worth the asking price, and looking forward to more SW from Flying Wild Hog.Pro's:+ Fantastic game play, including gun play. The satisfaction the Katana brings is just amazing. SW has set the bar for fast melee combat.+ Beautiful graphics, screenshots abound here. Fantastic amount of PC options for graphics, sound and gameplay.+ Great variety of satisfying weapons and enemies. Slicing humans with the Katana is just therapeutic ;)+ Feels perfectly arcade, just like the original game.+ Checkpoints are placed at logical points, with the ability to F5 quicksave, perfect.+ Fantastic one liners from Wang, in tune with the hilarity of the original, but not quite as good!Con's:+ I didn't enjoy the story as much as the mechanical elements, but it's still quite good.+ A couple of weird bugs caused a save load here and there, sometimes losing progression, but nothing major.

content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												I saw gameplay earlier, "maybe it would be entertaining" so i got this on discount.First impressions - very nice graphics, funny protagonists and entertaining gameplay, secrets almost equal with Serious Sam that made me checking every single corner and blowing up everything to find anohter supprises. But after first bloodbaths I went deeper...I never expected any deep lore from this kind of slashers, just "hey, this is big evil guy, we must destroy him by slaying one milion of smaller evil guys!". Shadow Warrior storyline could be in first approach something like that, but I think, that everyone who reccomend this game also was supprised how deep is the story and how big is immersion. Ending scene just makes me...I don't even have a world, just how game ends its amazing.Game is hard itself. I have the moment, when i just slashed everything like I am a god, but later game became more and more challenging when you are surronded by every type of enemies. Still its not broken, its ballanced and even more fun when encounters force on you to use every weapon, every skill and many time the enviroment! It's not a shame to play on easier diffulty, I played on normal and still it Was a challange to me.Enemies are varied, but game don't throw on us every type on the beginning. Some of them we can meet in the beginning, but others in the middle/slow endgame. They are realy different from eachself and force on player to use also other tactic to single one. Everyone played their role on battlefield and every demon we encounter doing something realy different, for example support his allies or summon other minion (but also still hurting us badly). Later game mix often almost all types, and from autopsy I can said this - In this game, more is better. You need to think many times to survive in bloodshed.Skills and equipment are satisfying. Many weapon, which every have their own advantages and cons, which makes every usefull. Upgrades maybe makes one more universal, but still not an ultimate massacre machine. You can see it especially in endgame, where its bloodbath overload. More interesing are skills, merits of swordfighting. I use katana almost everytime I can, so I can say that its created perfectly. I never felt that I need some other skill instead that i can use, same as perks.I fully recomend this game. Its awesome, one of the best production of 2014, maybe in whole gaming history. Entartaining and challanging.Only one con is that you can finish this game in max. 15 hours, but content loaded in this makes me fully satisfied.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												Having played just about everything that 3D Realms produced in the nineties, I was very interested in this Shadow Warrior reboot. It is true to the original, with updated graphics and gameplay elements. Lo Wang looks and sounds different, but the cheesy one liners, the ambiguous chinese/japanese setting and the humour are all there. Even the killer rabbits. The levels are big, highly explorable like the original and other games from the early shooters, I must say I was surprised when I thought I had fully explored a map and found I had only gotten maybe 70% of the secrets found by the end. The biggest gameplay improvement has to be the functionality of the sword, I find myself using it over any of the guns whenever possible, when it was pretty much a last resort weapon in the original (for me anyway)There are also a upgrade/perk points/skill tree system which has some useful things like upgrades to weapons, more stamina/health etc. It's not too complicated and I found that improving all the sword related abilities made the game even more enjoyable.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												WHO WANTS A MORE WANG! This game is awesome! Run around as um... a ninja named Lo-Wang (we would get into the Japanese vs Chinese argument, but that happened when the game first came out in 1997*). You're out for revenge (like all good ninjas), and you'll take it via lead and steel. The voice acting isn't the cartoony Chinese stereotype it was in the original, but the facepalmy oneliners still remain. The graphics are outstanding, with lighting effects, and spraying blood in every corner. The ragdoll physics are pretty good, and the coolest part of the gore-fest that is Shadow Warrior is that you can slice up foes Kill Bill style leaving a trail of gore and parts through out the numerous scenic temples and bamboo groves you traverse. A rough patch I'd say is the controls, which get a bit floaty with numerous enemies on screen, but they work. All in all, this isn't Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon or Ran, it is Rage of the Master or Hard Boiled and it does provide a thuroughly enjoyable bloody romp full of interesting enemies and scenic locations.*If you are basing your views on the thousands of years of diverse, rich cultures that encompass half of the world's population, on a (very tongue in cheek) game, then you are indeed a sad person and should probably log out, get out more.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												Shadow Warrior was a delightful surprise. A perfunctory examination indicates little promise; it looks and sounds like a pile of cliche: "ninja fights army of demons." On closer inspection however, Shadow Warrior is much more. I understand it's meant to be a callback to older shooters like Duke Nukem or Quake, titles which I never got to experience. Yet even without nostalgia, this game enthralled me despite its faults. The gameplay has little variation; occaisional half‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•puzzles always give way to more fighting, but thankfully that combat is far too fun to deride. The whimsically gratuitous carnage from carving through demon hordes with a spirit-laser firing katana is indescribably fun, and the initially lack-luster firearms can be upgraded to satisfying levels of destruction.While the storyline may be thin and unclear, the characters are engaging satires of modern cliches. Lo Wang and his questionable name make for healthy banter rather than the usual silence gravely grunts of self-insertion oriented shooters.Altogether Shadow Warrior is a must-play for any shooter fan, so long as one doesn't mind the occaisional slightly racist Wang pun.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												I genuinely didn't know what to expect going into this game.  After playing the horrendously disappointing Duke Nukem Forever, I was fairly skeptical about this rebooted title.  At the very most, I was expecting a shallow FPS/FPK(First-Person Katana-ing) with decent action and an almost vacant story.  To be honest, I was surprised.  Shadow Warrior actually contains a story.  It's not particularly deep or engaging, but it is somewhat creative and the cutscenes were enjoyable.  The interaction between Lo Wang and the shadow realm demon Hoji ranged from annoying to hilarious, but I mostly enjoyed them poking fun at each other and taking cheap shots.  The action, however, was sublime - pure and simple.  Specifically, the katana was a pleasure to wield.  It sliced up demons and humans alike with noticable heft and precision.  The damage model for the enemies fit the game perfectly.  As the game progresses, new abilities for the katana and your "ki" powers are unlocked.  These range from a brutal thrusting strike from your katana to a shockwave-like burst of energy from your free hand.  During the game, you will wield a weapon in one hand and perform "ki" abilities with your other hand (think plasmids/vigors).  Unless you are dual-wielding akimbo style, this is the format for combat.  This opens up the possibility for numerous different attack combinations and variations.  In fact, the more varied and aggressive your combat style, the more karma points you are awarded after each encounter.  Karma is used to buy skill upgrades to further increase your skillset.While the katana is the staple of your arsenal, there are plenty of other weapons at your disposal, all of which feel solid and accurate.  Some are more effective than others, of course, but all have the ability to get the job done.  My only complaints about the weapons are that the fire-rate on some of them felt too slow and sometimes hitting the reload button prompted no response.  I would have to hit reload multiple times in order for the gun to actually reload.  The only reason that stands out so much is due to the rest of the controls being so responsive.  It wasn't a huge issue, but it was annoying at times.Ultimately, this game was well worth a purchase, at least for me (sale for $11.99).  The in-house game engine produces some gorgeous visuals.  Texures look good, as do the lighting effects and the amount of color is refreshing.  No dull brown and greys here, well very little of that anyway.  That being said, I would have to recommend this title.  It's an action-packed romp that delivers on what it promises, unlike other certain titles (*cough* DNF *cough*).  I give Shadow Warrior 4 out of 5 bloody demon hearts.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
I shot a rabbit while it was getting busy with another...It turned into a demon and killed me.11/10 would die again.Serious Review:If you think shooting and slashing demons with swords and explosive crossbow bolts while dashing away from charging demons sounds fun, this game is for you. Shadow Warrior is the reboot from the classic 1997 Shadow Warrior made in the Duke Nukem 3D engine.The reboot is filled with fast-paced, horde like combat. Allowing the player to  hack and slash body parts into pieces. The game doesn't like to take itself seriously like most shooters today and will occasionally throw funny jokes and easter eggs likely to make you stop and laugh. The dash system allows you to dash towards or away from the charging demons or fireballs raining from the sky. The game begins with you and your sword which you will master as you progress. You slowly progress to different weapons as well as various attachments. This form of progression allows for you to fight the increasingly more difficult hordes of demons out to get you and left me interested in unlocking my next attachment or skill.This game might not seem as good looking as crysis or metro but the atmosphere in levels like Lo Wang's (the main characters) secret cave or looking over the hills of the cemetery can leave you breathless.Overall I had a great time playing Shadow Warrior and I can easily recommend it to anyone.    PROS:  Graphicshumorgameplaylevel designprogression style     CONS:  Only a semi-decent storyonly 2-3 variants of enemy aesthetics per class (there should be some sort of looks randomizer to make it feel like you have sliced the same demon twice in a row. This should be noted that this is a problem I have with many other games that involve you up close and personal with your target.)

content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												Great game.  It has an amazing combat system along with very nice visuals / graphics.  The story is well written and has good character personalities with great humor.  There's a good amount of enemy variety, and lots of cool skills and weapon upgrades that can be unlocked as you play through the game.  The wave defense mode is pretty solid, but there's not much there that isn't already in the main story mode.  Overall I'm fairly happy with my purchase, and I recommend picking it up if you like single player fps games or if it goes on sale.Final score: 9 fortune cookies out of 11 mariachi bands

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												Incredibly fun, quite challenging, even sometimes pretty, pretty hard (at insane difficulty). I laughed at lot with this game, liked the plot, the history behind, the communication between the characters, the combat system, the combos, I really loved the crossbow. Hands down. Even with that, I felt that sometimes the game was offering always the same, spawning mobs at certain times, at a determined locations, so you can tell when they will happen.It would be awesome if enviromental explosives things did much more damage, because it was kinda hard to lure them and get the achievement for killing mobs with them (and keeping barrels and such intact until they were almost dead).I was never running out of ammo, because you can get them almost everywhere and if not you can buy them, which is all the opposite to the original version of this game. Medikits are everywhere.Boss fights are cool, but the mechanics don't change that much. They are hard, and will wipe you if you don't pay attention!Don't get me wrong, this game is awesome, bought it when it was on sale, and I enjoyed it a lot.If you want to spend around 18 hours in an unending killing spree of demons, and punishing the evil from here and beyond, this is your chance!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												This game is just plain fun. It brings back the early style of FPS gameplay mixed with modern FPS Gameplay and does it well. The guns are fun to use but the sword is the star in this game. Not to mention a nice level/skill system. The story is also very intersting. I wasn't really expecting an actual 'plot' but it's pretty darn good. Though, there are times the gameplay gets a bit tedious, you want to finish the story. The FPS community desperatly needs more games like this. This game took the idea of taking a step back and in doing so, LEAPED 10 YARDS. Hang up your military shooters for a day and give this game some freaking love.The game is just a great big ball of fun. Worth every freaking penny. I really hope Flying Hog makes another game likes this.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 21, 2013
												It is my strongest recommendation that if you like FPS games, you get this one.  It has the perfect combination of what's new (upgrades, powers, and a great story) with the old (lots and lots of shooting bad guys!)  The graphics engine really shows off the locales in addition to the blood and gore, and the writing and story has all the feel of a labor of love from these guys.  The guns are all very enjoyable to use, and the katana helps revolutionize quick kills, gibs, and the use of the 'alternate weapon'.  I had so much fun running through this, and while I did a lot of secret searching (many of which do a fantastic job of alluding to the original), it still clocks in as an extensive game to play through.  By all means, grab this game and start enjoying some Wang!

Posted: July 2, 2016
												An excellent remake from an up-and-coming developer. Much like Hard Reset, this game features incredible atmoshpere, lots of customizable weapon options, beautiful graphics, solid sound design, and a competent series of skill and power upgrades. While not the best game around in terms of enemy variety and certain enemy mechanics, the game is a blast to play anyway. I had a great deal of fun romping through the world's levels, finding secrets and throw-backs to the original, and generally being a badass against the hordes of demons.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												This game easily has the best first person melee I've ever experienced. The katana is a joy to use and I often slaughter hoards of demons without pulling out any of my other weapons. Shadow Warrior reminds me a lot of Serious Sam where you make your way through a fairly linear path looking for loot (money, health, secrets, etc) and run in to demons along the way. My only complaint would be that the game is reasonably easy. The first few levels on the hardest difficulty are a breeze and only later on do they present a challenge. It would have been nice to have one more difficulty above that for those that want a very hard time. I haven't finished the game yet though so perhaps you unlock one upon completion.Summary: This game is a sack of fun. Hurry up and buy it.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												It's all about katana! Fighting with melee weapon for me was much easier than with guns. And it was funnier this way! Great experience! If you like games like Dark Messiah of Might & Magic or Zeno Clash you should give it a try!Good graphics and very beautiful levels. The game is full of action! Even if you use only katana there will always be something that explodes! =D (But it's very sad when it explodes next to you and you die...). Shadow warrior has some RPG elements, you can learn or upgrade magic skills, fight skills or weapons. Script writers have prepared some good jokes for you (don't forget to check out fortune cookies) =) Still, this game is not perfect... It's kind of lengthy. Story is pretty simple. All fights look the same. You enter another "room", fight demons there and after killing all of them, you can go to the next "room". But as I mentioned before, you rarely get bored, as you can always try something new in battle! Game has some bugs, but developers still release patches.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Shadow Warrior is a fantastic game. If you are a fan of old school FPS and played the original Shadow Warrior then you will get extra enjoyment out of this. For those that didn't, this is still worth picking up. A solid FPS with great humour, lots of blood and gore, good level design, amazing details and lots of easter eggs/secrets to find. There are funny one liners like in the original Shadow Warrior and other additions such as rabbits having sex, secrets that have the old school textures, you see footprints in blood, the anime looking woman bathing etc. If you are looking for a quality FPS this is a must buy regardless if you played the original or not. Using the swords feels very satisfying with dismemberment and blood everywhere. The other weapons are great too, especially firing two machine guns into a mob of enemies, or using the rocket launcher and watching the gibs fly.Most FPS games will have you simply running through from start to finish. This game makes you want to explore every area for secrets. There is a decent variety of weapons and lots of upgrades you can do to improve your weapons and skills. I highly recommend it.9.5/10

Posted: January 4, 2016
												The recreation of Shadow Warrior is probably one of the most fun slice and dice shooters to show up on the PC. I played this game on insane difficulty and it was worth every aching minute. Epic comedic voice acting throws some homage back to Duke Nukem and Serious Sam. Plenty of sword powers to keep heads rolling and kids trolling. Amazing story, lots of weapons and power upgrades, epic enemy bosses, and the minions aren't too shabby either. 10+/10 GOTY--in fact Game of ANY Year.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												Flying Wild Hog has done it again with their re-imagining of Shadow Warrior.  I love the atmosphere they pour into their games.  Both Hard Reset, and Shado Warrior had this in abundance.  The only thing I wish is that you came into contact with a few more stragglers (single enemies or very small groups of them) instead of sections of groups of enemies.  But minor complaint.The optimization this time around seems slightly improved over Hard Reset.  I mean this because on the same rig, Shadow Warrior Looks noticeably better graphics wise, while the performance may even be slightly more stable than Hard Reset. (at least no worse stable than Hard Reset)I enjoyed the weaponry, just like in the original Shadow Warrior, (although the nuke upgrade for the Rocket Launcher could be a bit more powerful).  I love the ability to upgrade them, and my abilities. I don't mind for one second that this game doesn't have any multiplayer. They made a solid single player experience. The levels are pretty big, and most are quite long.  The combat is fun, especially the sword combat.  The movement, and feel of the game is very solid. This is not a typical short FPS game like we are use to seeing these days. The music is nice, I especially like the way it added to the atmosphere. Some of the levels are done extremely well on here that make you just stop, and admire the work the devs have done!  Which you can see in some of my screenshots of the game.  The story is nice too, its an interesting telling, and the way its told is pretty nice as well.  I found myself doing a quiet little (non-sarcastic) golfclap at the end of the story, right before the credits started rolling, which were nicely done as well.I caught this game on sale for like $7.50-$9.99.  I easily got my worth, it was a great game, and I would have got my worth even paying up to $25-$30.  I wouldn't pay any more than that though. I would love to see Flying Wild Hog do a re-imagining of the 90's build engine FPS called BLOOD! I would buy that in a heart beat. That being said, I have my eyes on anything Flying Wild Hog will be working on.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Shadow Warrior is one of my favourite games of 2013, a First Person Shooter that incorporates all the mechanics that I prefer as a long time fan of the genre, adds some unique twists, and has amazing tactical depth. Above all, it focuses on just being fun.You are Lo Wang, a sort of modern day samurai, on a quest to recover an ancient sword for your Yakuza-style boss. You soon discover that the sword is also wanted by a race of demons who live in a shadow realm.The combat is outstanding, fast paced and intense. There are several types of demons, each with different abilities, and they attack in large waves, usually a dozen or more at a time. Thankfully you have access to a wide variety of weapons, and you can carry all of them simultaneously, so you can always choose the best weapon for each situation.Your primary weapon is the katana, and Shadow Warrior has some of the best melee combat of any FPS I've ever played. You have a normal attack, two charged power attacks and a spinning area of effect special move. Add to that a really useful dash move to quickly close the distance, and its surprising just how effective the katana is. Most of the guns are useful as well, when enemies attack from outside melee range, or have powerful melee attacks of their own that you want to avoid.The health system is fantastic. You can collect medkits. You can use magic. You can collect the souls of fallen enemies. Or, my personal favourite, you can absorb health from any enemies killed by the katana's special moves. So now when you're low on health, a group of demons changes from a threat, to an opportunity. Charge up the spinning attack and dive right into the middle. Glorious, and so much more enjoyable than just hiding behind a wall for a few seconds.There are three separate types of level up systems in play. Killing enemies gains XP which can be used to unlock passive stat bonuses. Finding crystals allows you to unlock or upgrade magic abilities. And money can be used to buy upgrades for the guns. Each system has lots of different options to choose from, so you can decide which ones best suit your playing style.The technical points are all positive as well. Level design is like a tree, with lots of branches coming off the main path, to explore and find secrets. Graphics are pretty good, makes good use of the Japanese theme, and I was able to get a solid 60 fps. Keyboard and mouse works perfectly, and all keys are rebindable. You can also customise how much info is shown on the HUD. You can save anywhere, and also enable checkpoints. I didn't experience any significant bugs. It took me 12 hours to complete, which is quite long for a FPS.I honestly can't find anything to complain about, and therefore Shadow Warrior is an absolutely essential purchase.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
												Gorgeous looking game with a really fun combat system. I played through the game using mainly the katana. There's an upgrade system where you can use found resources (money, Ki Crystals or Karma) to upgrade your combat abilities, powers or weapons. The story was surprisingly good.Pros:-Graphics, especially the 2D cutscenes and varied level design.-Good story.-Upgrade system where you can upgrade whatever playstyle fits you.-Lots of secrets and puns, which lighten the mood of the game, although Wang puns get stale after a while.-Sword combat is fun as hell.-A good challenging game.Cons:-Lot of bullet sponge type enemies, meaning each engagement took a while to get done with, which is understandable but it gets boring after you stab the same dude 20 times in a row. This, I felt, sort of artificially lengthened the game by quite a bit. It took me around 17 hours to beat it on Hard.-Loading times could be better considering the challenging difficulties. I had an SSD and loading times were around 10-20 seconds, which adds up if you played it through on harder difficulties like I did and die a lot.-Physics engine is coded in such a way that if you fall a short distance, such as sprinting downstairs, you would actually die from the fall damage. So don't expect to find yourself rushing through levels.

												I can certainly say that this is one of the most enjoyable games i've played in a very very long time. It combines stunning visuals with a fast paced and fun hack-n-slash-n-shoot gameplay, with a little dash of an interesting story to keep you glued to the campaign. The gameplay can overtime get a little bit repetetive, but the developpers have easily countered this by adding different combinations of mini-boss battles and the hunger to attempt to achieve a better score after each battle by trying out different combos. I would easily compare this to L4D2 in terms of gameplay, but the enemies are not as 'soft' as the zombies were in said game, but the quality of the visuals exceed that of most games being released thus providing wonderful eye candy as you progress through each level, making it a necessity to stop from time to time and just stare.

content:
Posted: November 10, 2015
												This game is awesome.If you liked Painkiller, this is highly recommended. Sword combat done really right, I haven't had this much fun with an unusal combat system since The Darkness 2. The sword is a very powerful and capable part of your arsenal, and I thought it was the most fun to use. Each weapon has 2 firing modes, much like Painkiller did, giving them a large and versatile role when things are going straight down the tubes.The game is visually stunning, and I spent a fair bit of time just walking through the areas soaking in the visuals and setting. The level design is also superb, particularly with an eye towards using lighting to help guide the player towards where they need to go. The humor was occasionally childish but otherwise had enough great lines to get me laughing plenty of times.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2016
												A polished, fun game with fantastic mechanics and enjoyable humour. Guns are fun to use, although the sword offers a much more enjoyable experience; the combination of the two and way in which the game spams enemies at you makes combat awesome fun.The mechanics for the sword, a Japanese Katana, are smooth and intuitive. Menu options exist for altering how much input is required from the player to control Katana attacks (casual, basic and advanced), alowing the player to tailor the experience to their preference. The graphics are also solid, and the level design, while linear, offers some fantastic looking locations, very well exectued Eastern-style architecture and stunning vistas. I highly recommend  this game.+ Mechanics+ Game options+ Graphics+ Level design+ Humour- Didn't care much for the story, mainly because I was enjoying the combat so much.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2016
												This game is abso-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing-lutely amazing.The combat is fun, the story is great (if that even matters), the melee is incredible, the guns fill all the niches guns need to fill and the secrets are very well hidden.I've 100%ed the game and it's been some of the best fun I've had in a video game. It's also resulted in some keyboard smashing when on Heroic (i.e. restart the level if you die), but still - there's a reason I went for 100%.The only downside is that if one chooses to forego using the katana, they'll likely find their efficiency handicapped, especially on higher difficulties, so this might be a deal-breaker for people who dislike melee combat. This grain of salt should be taken with a grain of salt, however, as the swordplay is easy to pick up on and really quite fun.This game goes on sale frequently, so the three fiddy is no price at all for the value in this beauty.10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												Incredible fast-paced run-and-gun FPS. Runs excellent on my 960 at 1080p with settings on Ultra, maintains 60FPS everywhere minus a very specific area where the flamethrower would drop the FPS to 40 while being used, however this only occured once.Gunplay is extremely satisfying - by the end of the game, it begins feeling a bit more like Serious Sam with the amount of space you have and the number of enemies you face, however the fluidity of the combat keeps it from getting repetitive.I did not find the story very interesting. I mostly played through Shadow Warrior (and soon, the higher difficulties) for the fast-paced combat, however I usually do not have strong opinions for lore behind games, so that's my own fault.I highly recommend this game for anyone who really enjoyed Quake, DOOM or the original Shadow Warrior as this effectively follows the same fast-paced genre and I'm proud to have completed it the whole way through.

content:
Posted: August 20, 2014
												Shadow Warrior is a fantastic game. If you are a fan of old school FPS and played the original Shadow Warrior then you will get extra enjoyment out of this. For those that didn't, this is still worth picking up. A solid FPS with great humour, lots of blood and gore, good level design, amazing details and lots of easter eggs/secrets to find. There are funny one liners like in the original Shadow Warrior and other additions such as rabbits having sex, secrets that have the old school textures, you see footprints in blood, the anime looking woman bathing etc. If you are looking for a quality FPS this is a must buy regardless if you played the original or not. Using the swords feels very satisfying with dismemberment and blood everywhere. The other weapons are great too, especially firing two machine guns into a mob of enemies, or using the rocket launcher and watching the gibs fly.Most FPS games will have you simply running through from start to finish. This game makes you want to explore every area for secrets. There is a decent variety of weapons and lots of upgrades you can do to improve your weapons and skills. I highly recommend it.9.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Similar to Serious Sam I first had to get a feeling of the game. Being a good looking, widely new interpreted version of the old game, it first feels...awkward. I tried to figure out the sword, and tried to figure out the guns, being frustrated, until I realized, this game isnt about finding the right time and spot to hit and shoot.Just hit and shoot your enemy.This game is all about speed and awareness.You are some kind of master assassin, who has to claim some mysterious sword from a japanese crime clan. Very fast you will be confronted with magic, CHI, KI, demons and a lot of other mythical crap.While in most games, your melee weapon is a more a tool than a weapon, this game is refreshing different.around 3/4 of the combat I could solve with the sword, the guns are for special tasks. Taking out bigger enemys, comanding and summoning units, flying ones or laying down massive AOE into an enemy group.Weapons like the Pistol and the SMG feeling totally useless in most of the fights are actually impressive against big single targets and mostly used for the massive bossfights.Everything is upgradable. While finding money everywhere, you can upgrade your weapons, making them stronger, faster and more precise. Also every weapon gets a alternate fire mode, which always is a great fun.Then you have a great set of abilitys you can unlock from faster movement, damage to using demon skulls as a weapon, healing yourself and big energy blasts.The combat system is mostly based on your movement, aim and the right use of your abilitys.The story being a little bit confusing and irrelevant, the dialogues are great work. Even while my second playthrough, I still listening to everything, and dont skipping any cutscene.The game is a great piece of classic FPS in new grafics and I hope there will be more.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
												Shadow Warrior 2013 by Flying Wild Hog is a reboot of the old FPS that goes by same name which was made by 3D Realms. Though it could as well be separate franchise, the only thing that remains is that main hero's name if Lo Wang, human Villian name is Zilla and that it takes place in modern Asian-styled world with asian demons. And that main hero has a sword. Also, no more multiplayer. All yay single-player focus.It also was released for Xbox One and PS4. No good differences that I am aware off.You also get Viscera Cleanup little spin-off with single Shadow Warrior level. A game where you clean up all the blood and gibs as a space janitor.You can get additional sword skin if you own Saints Row 4. Plus two additional skins from Special Edition of a game. Oh, Rise of the Triad and Walking Dead sword reskins are available in the game without having to have anything else. I also heard that there were additional skins depending on what platform you pre-ordered the game.Plot wise you are a Zilla's man, who's current job is to take a sword. Which will go wrong, land will get invaded by ugly asian demons who aren't related to Zilla and you will get into family melodrama of Ancients from Shadow Realm, with plot being focused more on that. It actually gets interesting. And even though Lo Wang isn't same pervy stereotypical asian old fart, he still cracks his jokes along with new spirit friend.Main core gameplay is changed. It's not old-school in same fashion as old 90s shooters as original Shadow Warrior. Instead it takes another type of old-school: Painkiller style! Where the levels are strongly divided between calm exploration areas where you search for keys, find secrets without wall-humping, destroy locks and open thousands boxes to find supplies and money. It's almost maze-like at times, but there is always a shining door which will give you a hint where to go next. It also gives you a hint which area contains bonus goodies. Protip: it's the one not behind the shiny door.And once you enter a suspiciously empty area you will be locked down into arena and the waves of enemies will begin to pour in. Though sometimes there is already somebody around. And not only that, but when the fight will end, you will get rated and given karma points. Sadly, the requirements for good rating are unclear and as it turns out, "use different weapons and be cool" isn't true. Guides say it's about multiplayer like "shredder" or "headshot" and suggest you to just use few weapons along with stun.Well, plus there are few encounters where you aren't locked into arena or rated. Happens.And levels are build around pacing these two section types around and it usually works well. Sadly, the game is a dat too long. Or at least some chapters are. In some of them, you might already complete the climax of a level, like some cool mini-boss. And yet it will still keep going and going, sending you to wander futher in mazes. Just finish already and don't drag!And as much as original Shadow Warrior was about shooting from Grenade Launcher into corners, the reboot Shadow Warrior is about the mighty sharp katana. Monsters hit feedback ismore detailed than usual, swaying around as you hit them with sword with some angles. Actually, if you manage to hit some with strong horizontal attack over neck, common fodder enemies may even die in a single hit, losing their heads. Or to lose their arms. Some say that their beat the game using katana 95% of times.But in reality is that once you put skills into katana mastery it will become more straight-forward strong melee weapon, as you will be spamming special moves and heal from them. No, there is no sword-blocking or such. Just shifting around. You know, avoiding things. Though at least monsters become more enraged when you spam special moves.But it's not all just hip sword play, as you got at least 6 more weapons, each can be upgraded to have special alternative fire modes. All of them are balanced around each other and are fun to use. Also look pretty fancy. Akimbo Uzi is back and is good for constant fire from distance. Crossbow is good for nailing things to a wall once you charge it up. Shotgun is interesting, it strong and has a cone of fire so wide that it will make Super Shotgun from Doom 2 choke up from envy. And there is a highly explosive rocket launcher.It's a bit more sad with enemies variety. They are mostly demons who are designed to either melee you, charge at you or just throw fireballs. There are also regular mini-bosses. And shield demons. It's all good and fun, but by the end of a game, everytime you see game spawning 2 of mini-bosses you just would grunt "again those bulletsponges". Oh and at least there are some bosses.It also has some RPG elements in that you can upgrade yourself by collecting recources. Money is littered around and you have to search for it, it will let you upgrade the weapons.Ki Crystals are very few, but they are almost always placed in your face. They let you upgrade your special powers. Yep, you got some and you can activate them like in fighting games, like "forward, forward, hold alt-fire". If Metroidvania can do it, then why not other genres?  Though it's a shame that Flux and Shockwave are too same, stunning enemies, with Flux being the worse one, due to making you pause for a second. Also, all yay healing and shielding.And then when you kill enemies, get big rating at fights or find blood bowls you will get karma, which is like experience points. With you getting a single point you can spend on skills once you level up, so to say. Skills are varied and all of them are useful, though I recommend you to get those sword skills up.It also has awesome enviroments and graphics, even if it's not AAA game. Asian and other-world worlds are quite fashinating and nice. Music is sadly completely forgettable, movie-like stuff. Fortune cookies are still fun, all messages are now unique through the game. Too much retro secrets though.And while the game has problems at being too repetetive either due to same pacing or because it's too long, the gameplay is simply awesome. It really makes you move and fight with tactics in mind at arenas, changing weapons and shooting them the cars to make them explode, whille getting exploring outside of them in huge non-straight-line levels. I can't say how it compares to original Shadow Warrior as it's very loose reboot, but it's one of the best Painkiller-style FPS around!

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 18, 2016
												Incredible fast-paced run-and-gun FPS. Runs excellent on my 960 at 1080p with settings on Ultra, maintains 60FPS everywhere minus a very specific area where the flamethrower would drop the FPS to 40 while being used, however this only occured once.Gunplay is extremely satisfying - by the end of the game, it begins feeling a bit more like Serious Sam with the amount of space you have and the number of enemies you face, however the fluidity of the combat keeps it from getting repetitive.I did not find the story very interesting. I mostly played through Shadow Warrior (and soon, the higher difficulties) for the fast-paced combat, however I usually do not have strong opinions for lore behind games, so that's my own fault.I highly recommend this game for anyone who really enjoyed Quake, DOOM or the original Shadow Warrior as this effectively follows the same fast-paced genre and I'm proud to have completed it the whole way through.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												I just revisited this game to play through it with a friend. And i was really blown away by just how fun the game was my thrid time through.The story is simple, is the origin story of the almighty Lo Wang and concerns his rise to the man he will eventually become and the origins of his nemesis that will continually hound him in his quest to achieve his devious machinations.First off, the weapons. While most of the weapons have a nice, solid feel to them, the weapon models tend to be on the larger side with no way of reducing them. The main gimmick of this game is the Katana and the way that it handles. You can press a direction and then press swing for it to produce different animations of cutting. While nice, this is pointless as there are no enemies that require you to use the directional slashes. You can also power it up with various abilities as you level up, and that's where the main use of the sword comes into play.Overall, it's a solid game with mostly well realised characters, witty banter and character development while keeping the gameplay old-school, fast paced and full on balls against the walls.Get it, play it and enjoy it. If you liked FPS genred games, you are sure to have a good time with this.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2013
												Shadow Warrior is one of my favourite games of 2013, a First Person Shooter that incorporates all the mechanics that I prefer as a long time fan of the genre, adds some unique twists, and has amazing tactical depth. Above all, it focuses on just being fun.You are Lo Wang, a sort of modern day samurai, on a quest to recover an ancient sword for your Yakuza-style boss. You soon discover that the sword is also wanted by a race of demons who live in a shadow realm.The combat is outstanding, fast paced and intense. There are several types of demons, each with different abilities, and they attack in large waves, usually a dozen or more at a time. Thankfully you have access to a wide variety of weapons, and you can carry all of them simultaneously, so you can always choose the best weapon for each situation.Your primary weapon is the katana, and Shadow Warrior has some of the best melee combat of any FPS I've ever played. You have a normal attack, two charged power attacks and a spinning area of effect special move. Add to that a really useful dash move to quickly close the distance, and its surprising just how effective the katana is. Most of the guns are useful as well, when enemies attack from outside melee range, or have powerful melee attacks of their own that you want to avoid.The health system is fantastic. You can collect medkits. You can use magic. You can collect the souls of fallen enemies. Or, my personal favourite, you can absorb health from any enemies killed by the katana's special moves. So now when you're low on health, a group of demons changes from a threat, to an opportunity. Charge up the spinning attack and dive right into the middle. Glorious, and so much more enjoyable than just hiding behind a wall for a few seconds.There are three separate types of level up systems in play. Killing enemies gains XP which can be used to unlock passive stat bonuses. Finding crystals allows you to unlock or upgrade magic abilities. And money can be used to buy upgrades for the guns. Each system has lots of different options to choose from, so you can decide which ones best suit your playing style.The technical points are all positive as well. Level design is like a tree, with lots of branches coming off the main path, to explore and find secrets. Graphics are pretty good, makes good use of the Japanese theme, and I was able to get a solid 60 fps. Keyboard and mouse works perfectly, and all keys are rebindable. You can also customise how much info is shown on the HUD. You can save anywhere, and also enable checkpoints. I didn't experience any significant bugs. It took me 12 hours to complete, which is quite long for a FPS.I honestly can't find anything to complain about, and therefore Shadow Warrior is an absolutely essential purchase.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 16, 2014
												How in the hell did it take so long for me to discover this gem?! If you are a fan of FPS games like Serious Sam, Doom, Quake, Duke Nukem 3D etc... then you absolutely MUST buy this game. Sure there are several guns to choose from and plenty of mayhem to be had with demonic-like powers but the real fun IMO comes with the swordplay. The swordplay mechanics are absolutely fantastic and blast to play. There is nothing quite as satisfying as slicing a demon apart limb by limb then finishing him off with a good ol' fashioned decapitation. I could literally run through the entire game with my sword out and not feel the need to pull out a gun. It's a blast! The level's are very linear with a few collectibles and "secrets" scattered about along with crystals that help you upgrade your character. They were never really hard for me to find so I am sure you won't have any trouble either. There is usually a boss of some sort at the end of each level as well, they aren't all that hard and I recommend using a  machine gun or Launcher on them as to keep distance from the melee attacks. Your character also has a talent tree of sorts which you can use the Crystals to pick whichever talent upgrade you want. You can also earn and find money and ammo via boxes or kills (think Bioshock or Farcry) and use the money on upgrades for your weapons. You can save at any point as well which I encourage you to do because instant deaths can happen and it can be frustrating.I feel I also need to say something about our main character (not much but something). He is a fairly likable Asian man with cheesy one-liners ala' Duke Nukem or Serious Sam which are delivered at tense moments to lighten the mood. They made more sense in those games because those protaganists are more big burly badasses but Lo Wang is more of an assassin so it didn't really fit for me. It still is not bad to watch though.All in all if you are a fan of Ninja's, Stupid jokes, Samurai swords or dismembering demons pick this gem up (8$ on sale sometimes!).-Casey

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												Similar to Serious Sam I first had to get a feeling of the game. Being a good looking, widely new interpreted version of the old game, it first feels...awkward. I tried to figure out the sword, and tried to figure out the guns, being frustrated, until I realized, this game isnt about finding the right time and spot to hit and shoot.Just hit and shoot your enemy.This game is all about speed and awareness.You are some kind of master assassin, who has to claim some mysterious sword from a japanese crime clan. Very fast you will be confronted with magic, CHI, KI, demons and a lot of other mythical crap.While in most games, your melee weapon is a more a tool than a weapon, this game is refreshing different.around 3/4 of the combat I could solve with the sword, the guns are for special tasks. Taking out bigger enemys, comanding and summoning units, flying ones or laying down massive AOE into an enemy group.Weapons like the Pistol and the SMG feeling totally useless in most of the fights are actually impressive against big single targets and mostly used for the massive bossfights.Everything is upgradable. While finding money everywhere, you can upgrade your weapons, making them stronger, faster and more precise. Also every weapon gets a alternate fire mode, which always is a great fun.Then you have a great set of abilitys you can unlock from faster movement, damage to using demon skulls as a weapon, healing yourself and big energy blasts.The combat system is mostly based on your movement, aim and the right use of your abilitys.The story being a little bit confusing and irrelevant, the dialogues are great work. Even while my second playthrough, I still listening to everything, and dont skipping any cutscene.The game is a great piece of classic FPS in new grafics and I hope there will be more.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2016
												I picked up this game while on sale for $5 and have to say it is well worth it.  Here's my quick run-down:Pros -Gameplay is fast and fluid; full 60 FPS on my mid-level systemMelee combat is great; shooting is on par with other FPS gamesMonster models and their AI are well doneRacy humor and language is done right; doesn't go too far to be distractingMap level designs feel right compared to the story being toldSecret areas offer incentives for those who wish to search for themGame has many chapters which extends its valueCons - Graphics are not spectacular but sufficeRepetition sets in after awhile; more monster models are neededNo map or pointers makes finding the right path difficult at times"Double press" keyboard options can be difficult during heavy fightsClimbing or extended jumping would enhance the gameplayVerdict -This game is really enjoyable so far.  I'm only up to level 7 so far, so I may update my review if needed as I get further along.  Currently I'd score this game an 8 out of 10.  The pros definitely outweigh the cons, especially at this value.
